name: Galactic Frontier
description:
From the designer.

The year is 2382 and the Milky Way Galaxy is teeming with life. The petty intra-planetary squabbles of the last millennium have given way to the hustle and bustle of interstellar commerce and entrepreneurship. Can you compete in the 24th Century? Play Galactic Frontier and see if you have what it takes!

Players select unique races (variable player powers) and set out to be the most successful entrepreneurs in the Milky Way. Players use influence markers to stake claim to resources and to keep their opponents at bay. By carefully managing their research efforts in 8 unique fields, players gain access to more advanced technology. The player who earns the most victory points by delivering rare minerals, advancing up the technology ladders, and avoiding the pesky space pirates will be the winner.
categories: Card Game, Industry / Manufacturing, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Wargame
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Quiz!: Tack för att du visar leg.
description:
A simple quiz game with cards. All in all the game comes with 160 questions in various topics.

No rules are included, other than that you play to 15 points.

name: Caçadors de bolets
description:
A roll-and-move game based on the Catalan TV show "Caçadors de bolets", aired by TV3 Televisió de Catalunya. The players try to win in this particular race of mushroom hunting, correctly identifying mushroom types.

The game includes:
- board
- 6 markers
- 112 mushroom cards
- 300 cards
- rulebook
categories: Educational, Environmental, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: A 16th Century Mediterranean Galley Wargame
description: It is a 12-page booklet describing the rules for a naval battle, intended to use with Navwar's miniatures. Each ship has maximum movement, fighting value and armament. Players simultaneously decide about movement, then each ship can fire. There are also rules covering ramming, close combat and morale.

name: Marchand de sable
description:
The game has two phases: first you have to put all the stars on the board and after this you can turn of the light and they will glow in the dark. Now that we are in the dark the second phase starts.

Each at a turn takes away one star from the board. The player who's star stays on the board as last wins the game. It sounds easy but since you are in the dark, a good memory will help.

The game contains:
- A large die
- Twelve twinkling starts
- A board
- A sandman

(User summary)

name: Elephant Checkers
description:
Elephant Checkers is basically Turkish Checkers played on an Xiangqi Board with a extra rules and additional pieces.
Each player starts with 24 pieces (soldiers). The goal of the game is to leave your opponent with no moves (capturing all of their pieces does this nicely), or to promote an Elephant (a promoted Soldier) to King on the point in the center of your opponent's fortress.

As in many checker games captures are obligatory, and a player must choose the move with the most possible captures.
Soldiers move one square forward or horizontally. They may also capture an enemy piece (or a series of them) by jumping over it to a vacant junction beyond.

Once across the river a Soldier may move two squares or capture pieces two squares ahead or to the side, or capture a piece an adjacent piece and land two squares past it.

When a Soldier reaches the far side it promotes to an Elephant (the name source).
Elephants may move to any vacant junction (since Xiangqi is played on the points, not sqaures) vertically or horizontally. They capture by jumping over an enemy piece, and can continue to any empty square beyond the capture.

"They may promote to King and win the game if on the Throne point in the center of the opposing fortress, but that move counts as a non-capturing move, and can not be made when there is a capture available."

name: Wit
description:
Paraphrased from the game's instruction sheet:

A word game for two to four players, utilizing a deck of 112 cards with individual letters on them (4 of each constanant other than Z (of which there are 2) and 6 each of A,E,I,O and U). Players are dealt a hand of 9 cards. Game play consists of laying cards to form complete words, which are scored against a table.
A player's turn begins by drawing a card from either the draw pile or the top of the discard pile, then continues with the laying of whatever words the player can make with the cards in his or her hand, then finishes with the laying of an additional card to the discard pile. Players may also capture words made by other players by adding letters to the played word to form a new word.
A round ends when someone fully discards his hand by playing a word or words. The player does not need to be able to discard a card if playing all cards into words.


A later version of this game was published together with the dice game Farkel; that game has a deck half the size.

name: Poker Face
description:
SUMMARY:

Poker Face is a board game of betting/wagering, not Lady Gaga, and money can NOT be used in playing the game. Each game consists of 7 matches. In the beginning of each match, a Match Card is drawn. Players follow the steps on the card to prepare the match, place bets and play action cards to alter the result in their favors. When the objective meets after playing rounds of action cards, the match ends. The winners receive points and the losers may receive penalty based on their bets. After 7 matches, player with the highest score wins the game.

COMPONENTS:

Board x 1
Objective Cards x 8
Action Cards x 108
Starting Player token x 1
Player token x 24
Power token x 8
Game Round marker x 1
Rule x 1







1) First edition is Simplified Chinese.
2) There are 36 types of action card, based on the ancient Chinese 36 stratagems.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Sports
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Romance of the Three Kingdoms 2
description:
Tactical level wargame based on the Chinese historical novel "Romance of the Three Kingdoms". This game covers field combat of the early episodes of the novel, and does not include later episodes siege combat.

Players control warlord forces at the end of the Han dynasty. The purpose of the game is to eliminate enemy troops.

Players organize their units secretly.
Search and leader's ability are the most important elements of the game. Surprise and preemptive attacks occur under search condition.
Leaders' duels are first resolved in battle. Then leaders attack opponent force, and finally force combat is resolved.

NOTE: this game has no direct relation with the same publisher's "Romance of the Three Kingdoms". Both games only share the same background.

name: Alles Paletti?!
description: User Summary: This game is designed to help parents communicate and find new ways to think about their relationships with their children. Using a deck of cards, the game has various kinds of techniques to challenge a parent's view, and to help them see the world differently. For example, you might be asked to role-play a scenario, but with a specific attitude alien to your normal thinking. Or the card may ask a moral question, but you have to answer from the view of different ages. There are no 'right' or 'wrong' answers, and gamers may not consider Alles Paletti?! to be a game in the normal sense. But it is designed to use methods of play to bring out changes in people, without accusations and finger-pointing.

name: Raaapidoo
description:
From the rules:

Content:
5 big leaf shaped double-sided boards
32 smaller leafs with pictures

Goal:
To find 1 unique picture on each board.
Each round winner will receive 1 small pictured card. Get 5 cards to win the game.

Set-Up:
Set all 5 board so everyone could see them.Don't matter how or which way the boards are places, there always are only 1 picture same on each board.
32 smaller cards will remain with the game leader.

Game:
Game leader (older player) has all the 32 cards. He searched the one card that matches the picture on each board and placed it secretly before him. Only he/she knows that animal picture. To make it easier, game leaser may choose the right animal and other 4 animals and mix them and then place then on the table for everyone to see. One of them is the right one. The first one to name the right animal on each board, gets to keep the card. Cards should be hidden from other players.
Each players gets only 1 guess.
This goes until one player has gotten 5 cards.
After each round, game leader collects all board and places them in any order, only making sure that already picked animals would come up again.

Winner:
Game is over when 5th card for someone is collected.

name: Siege
description:
Goal: the attacking army (red) must occupy the throne (central position of the board). The defending army (yellow) must eliminate all pieces of the attacking army.

Gameplay: The pieces are distributed over the board following pre-configured positions: the defending army around the central position and the attacking army at the border. The red army starts the game, each player can move one piece per turn. A piece can be moved to any other adjacent empty space. During the game, the central piece can be used by the yellow army. The captures are made the same way as checkers. After a capture the same player continues playing as long as he can capture other pieces.

name: PvP
description:
PvP is a quick 20-30 min, 2 player fantasy card game where players use teams of combatants to try to be the last man standing!
The game is easy to learn and play, offers many interesting challenges and replayability.

The objective of the game is to wipe out all of the opponent's characters. Each character can only take a certain amount of damage.
Each turn, players roll 6 Six-sided die three times, keeping any number of die between each roll. At the end of the third roll, players assign dice to characters they control. Each character has abilities which correspond to specific die combinations. (Eg. Fireball requires a straight, a strike requires a pair, etc...)

Characters are divided into teams which provide special bonuses if at least 2 members of the same team are present. Each of the 12 characters possess unique abilities. Advanced rules allow for customization of character teams, allowing endless re-playability!

For more info on motivation behind the game, head over to
http://www.indiegogo.com/PvP-A-card-and-dice-iOS-game?a=4762...

name: Чёрное золото (Black Gold)
description:
Чёрное золото ("Black Gold") is a modern warfare wargame with strategic elements.
Players seek to control the oil fields, and destroy opposing enemy units. Each oil field gives income, thus players may purchase additional units for battle.

name: S.L.O.POLY
description: Short for "San Luis Obispopoly", S.L.O.Poly markets itself as a Monopoly derivative, but actually has significant rules changes. Instead of the standard Monopoly board layout, the game has 45 properties. Each property costs $5,000, and the rent for each property is $1,000 times the number of properties next to it owned by the same player (so as more properties are owned in a row the rent goes up). Once all of the properties have been purchased from the bank, players can buy property chains from one another. The other major change is the concept of "marriage". When two players become land on the same square, they become married. Later, if you are married and land on your spouse's square, you sue for divorce and talk half of their property. If you are married and land on the single players square, the marriage gets annuled and the player gets sent to "Morrow Rock" (the game's equivalent to jail).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: Monster Kids
description:
When the lights go out and monsters come creeping, who is going to stop them? Monster Kids! These super powered teens are the only ones standing in the way of the monsters taking over the world. They sneak out at night to battle the fiends of darkness and get home before mom and dad find out!

Monster Kids is a fast paced, action card game. The players choose a character and work together to battle dangerous monsters. Players must use their cards carefully because the team wins, or loses, together! For those that don’t play well with others, you can play Monster Kids in versus mode battling to see who can defeat the most monsters. So whatever your taste, Monster Kids is sure to give you a monstrous, great time! - from the Official Nightstalker Games website.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Fighting
publishers: Nightstalker Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Afghanistan 2010
description: Card game for 2 Players. One player is the Americans. The other player is the Taliban. 2006-2010+ Simulation of the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan following the Taliban resurgence after the US led Invasion in 2001. Players recruit allies and steal or neutralize their opponents allies. The player with the most points worth of allies at the end of the game wins. Action and Event cards modify attacks and card play. Every Ally has a special ability that gives you an edge in the conflict. Influence tokens are used to recruit Allies as well as draw extra cards and get extra attacks.

name: Telegruv
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Telegruv is the new party game that takes the classic game, Telephone, to the next level. Draw cards illustrating popular dance moves including: The Twist, The Snake, and Brush Your Shoulders Off. Perform these moves for your teammates and get ready to laugh as your team tries to keep your dance sequence intact all the way down the line. The more moves that are completed correctly, the more points your team scores.

The game is ready to play and includes 95 dance cards of varying genre and difficulty, 5 wild cards, a 90-second sand timer, scoring pads, and pencils.

Telegruv is the party game that gets you on your feet!

name: Many Monster Dice
description:
This game developed out of a BGG dice design contest game i posted a few months ago (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/552079/my-many-monster-d...). My solo game rules for the pictured dice (which can be purchased at http://www.flyingbuffalo.com/) is as follows:

Many Dungeon Dice

You’ll need the many monster dice, paper to keep track of your character and draw out your dungeon, and a pen.

Roll the D20 to discover how many monsters you must encounter during your game and mark this value down. You must defeat this number of monsters to win the game without being slain yourself. Any gold and jewels you have left at the end if yours to keep.

Then, with the five numbered dice, assign one die to each 5 values - monster hit point die, and attack and defense dice.

Roll the map die, drawing out your dungeon as you go. Be as artistic as you like in this. Stairs and doors always have traps. Each door you roll will enter into a room, and there will always be a unlocked exit door in an adjacent wall. The T corridor branches off into other hallways and you may backtrack your path if you wish during exploration.

If you roll a door or a stair check first for a trap by rolling the 3 trap dice, if two faces match that trap is sprung.

Next, if you rolled a door, you enter the room. Roll the colored monster die to see what level of monster you will fight, and roll the corresponding colored monster die to see what you will fight. You always have initiative in an encounter.

To battle:

Roll your Battle Strength die and add that value to your Battle Strength for a magical weapon if you possess one. Then roll for the monster. Depending on the color and type of monster they will have different strengths and powers as summarized in the rules.

Once you have defeated a monster you may roll for treasure using the Treasure Die.

Explore the dungeon until you defeat/kill all the monsters you are required to. If you do this count yourself lucky you survived with your limbs and sanity intact. Spend your gold at the nearest wenchery or tavern.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Medieval, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ko Shogi
description: Kō shōgi is a large-board variant of shogi, or Japanese chess. The game dates back to the turn of the 18th century and is based on xiangqi and go as well as shogi. Credit for its invention has been given to Confucian scholar Ogyū Sorai. Unlike standard shogi, pieces may not be dropped back into play after being captured. Promotion rules are complex, and the fates of several pieces are interdependent. The objective is to capture the opponent's commanding pieces: The general, plus the governor if present, or either the banner or middle army if not. Two players, Black and White, play on a go board ruled into a grid of 19 ranks (rows) by 19 files (columns) with a total of 361 intersections. Each player has a set of 90 pieces of 34 different types. The pieces are round and flattened like go stones. In all, the players must remember 65 different moves. The pieces are generally of the same size, though black pieces may be slightly larger than white pieces. Each piece has its name in the form of one or two Japanese characters marked on its face, in white on black stones and in black on white stones. On the reverse side of most pieces are other characters in red; this side is turned up to indicate that the piece has been promoted during play. - Wiki (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ko_shogi)

name: Polish Campaign Pack
description:
This is a 10 scenario pack for Advanced Squad Leader that covers the Polish Campaign of September and October of 1939.

The scenarios are:

FE 176 Defense of Wysloka - A German Grenadier unit is attempting to bypass a mixed unit of Polish infantry and motorized artillery.

FE 177 First Invasion of Germany - German units are trying to disengage from a Polish armored force advancing toward the German border. This scenario requires board FE1. (Not included in the pack)

FE 178 Crushing Polish Victory - A Polish mixed force must attempt to block a German armored formation from penetrating to the rear.

FE 179 Jakacking Ass - Polish infantry attempting to hold a town against a German armored formation.

FE 180 Andrzejewo Aflame - Polish infantry attempt to avoid a German pincer movement in the middle Polish campaign.

FE 181 Gardens of the Citadel - German and Polish combined forces engage in city combat.

FE 182 Shredkowice - More city combat as a small force of grenadiers encounters a Polish infantry unit bolsters by some tough artillery pieces.

FE 183 Take the Flag - A Polish cavalry unit must evade German infantry in its flight to Warsaw.

FE 184 Hurrah! - Polish cavalry attempt to evict a German infantry force from a Monastery.

FE 185 Assault on Fort IX - Late Polish campaign action as the Germans attempt to breach a flooded anti-tank ditch.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Vampire Diaries Card Game
description:
Try to be the first player to collect the characters in this hit CW TV show. Getting the crow card will let you take a card from another player and having the herbal Vervain card protects your character cards. Other twists and surprises add to the fun.

-Publisher

Starting with a hand of 3 cards, Draw a card from the deck. Then play a card. You can meld a character card or use one of the other cards that have special effects. If you cannot play a card, discard one from your hand.

The first player to have collected all six character cards and the special two-sided Elena/Kathrine card winns.
categories: Card Game, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Jóla jóla spilið
description:
Contains two games in one box. From the publisher:
Giftrace: You are Santa Claus and you need to follow the path from the beginning to the end. On your way you leave one gift (a ring in your colour) on each house when you land on a house square or pass it. Score points are given accourding to who is first, second, third and forth to arrive to the end zone. The first person gets 4 points, second gets 3 pts, the third gets 2 pts and the last one gets one point. But, for each gift that you still have remaining (rings on your pawn) you get one minus point for each ring! The person with the most points wins!

Sledrace: Each player chooses a pawn and puts it on the sled in the same colour. The rings are not used in this game. The person that looks most like a racing driver starts! You throw the die and move accordingly. When you land on a square with a picture, you immediately follow the instructions on that square, then your turn ends. Please note that if you pass an X you stop right away because you just hit a tree and the rest of your moves in that turn are cancelled! The player on your left goes next. The first person to reach the finish line wins and gets the trophy!

name: Driver
description:
Promotional game for BP Strato Motor Oil.
Roll and move racing game. You can pay extra money to roll more dice (20 for 3 dice, 50 for 4 dice)
Every player tries to get all 3 cars in first. You are out of the game if you cann not pay.
With event cards.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bananen Gerangel
description:
Roll and Move game similar to Mensch ärgere dich nicht (Ludo)
Each player has 4 money pawns in one color (green, red, yellow or blue). Each monkey has a differnt tails in one of the four colors (green, red, yellow, blue).
There are four starting spaces and the monkeys start at their matching tail color and the goal spaces are also color coded for the tails.
You throw not only by landing on another pawn but also by overtaking.
Banana spaces are safe. And two monkey of the same color on one space are blocking.
The best: The six is worth 12 points and you can reroll, but 3 "6" in a row: you loose all pawns to the start, but 4 "6" in a row safes and 5 rolls of a "6" in a row is winning the game immediately.

name: Fruits: The Game
description:
Roll and move on a round board with 8 rings and 12 segments. Players start in the center and can move inwards, outwards or along the rings with one die roll.
You try to get all 6 different fruit cards. On a space with a fruit you roll 5 dice and try to get as many dice from this fruit. One reroll is free. All other rerolls cost money.
5 of a kind gives the fruit card matching. 3,4 and 5 of a kind gives money.
In the outer ring you get a fruit card only with 4 of a kind.

name: Geschenke aus Gottes Hand
description:
Card game where the player with the fastest reaction wins.

In the game there are 12 different "pairs" like: cow --> milk or hen --> egg. The first cards ist called start, the second gift (from god). Every player has a set of 12 gift card oppen in front of him. Now 1 start card is turned over an all players (wihtout the player turn over), try to find the matching gift card first to win the start card. After all 36 start card are played, the player with the most card earned wins.

name: Kommissar Rex: Wer stahl den Kohinoor?
description:
Row of four cards (A,B,C and D) should be built in the center of the table. On your turn you can play one of your 6 handcards. Start a row with an A or build on en existing row. On the card there are colored lines. A card can only be added if it has the same color as the last card of the row.
There are also jokers.
The player laying a D card gets the row as points and a player who can exchange a joker get the point for the exchanged card.

This is branded with the sheperd dog "Rex" from the TV show "Kommissar Rex"
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Dragon Surprise
description:
A memory game. One player has the green knights, the other the blue knights. In your turn you first have to turn over a knight in your color. If not just turn hide the card and next player's turn. If you find your knight, you turn over cards as long as you find a dragon. Then a fight will happen. You roll dice for your knight and the other player for the dragon. For a killed dragon you get a treasure.

This game is limited to 100 copies.

name: Mario Madness
description: Super Mario Bros branded card game. A mixture of rummy and canasta. You have to collect set and straits to get points. There are also some special cards.

name: Monster Trix
description: Super Marion Bros. branded card game. On the cards there are Monster in different numbers. All players turn over one card from their own deck at the same time. If there are 6 or more monsters of the same kind, you have to slam pn the table to get all open cards. If you run out of cards you are out.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Video Game Theme

name: Orthogo
description:
The board is a square seperated by othogonal lines with 24 crossing points. The are pieces in three different colors. At the start you have to put 2 pieces of each color on the board, so that not two of the same color are adjacent. Each player gets 6 starting pieces.

On a turn you have to put a piece adjecent to one of the same color and then you have to move the adjacten same colored pieces. If there is a piece on the space you have to move to, this piece is beaten. You have to take on of the beaten pieces back.

The player who got rid of all his pieces first is the winner.

name: Rollin' Rollin' Rollin'
description:
Time to get those dogies movin' with this simple dice game. Played with only four dice, your objective is to move the herd from the ranch to the final destination 500 miles away. Along the way you may get slowed down by grazing cattle, runaways, and stampedes.

The game has a western cattle drive theme and involves 4 custom dice consisting of the following icons, Stampede, Grazing, Runaway, Lasso, 1, 2, 3. Basically the object of the game is to be the first player to travel 500 miles (50 spaces).

During Each Turn the player rolls the dice up to 3 turns. On the first roll they keep 2 die for the final tally, on the second roll they keep 1 die, and the final roll they keep the final die.

The Breakdown of the rolls,
If a stampede is rolled, those die MUST be held no matter how many are rolled.
If a grazing is rolled, those die MUST be held, but only up to the number of die that are to be kept for that round.
If on the first roll the player rolls 2 stampedes, 1 grazing, and one Lasso, The player MUST hold the 2 stampedes, however since the number of held dice in this round is 2, the grazing and the lasso will be rerolled. If the player rolled 1 stampede, 1 grazing, 1 Two, and One Runaway, the player MUST hold the stampede and the grazing.

At the end of the rolls, movement is figured as such.
-If all four are stampedes the player will roll all 4 die one time and move BACKWARDS the number of spaces totaled up on the roll.
-For the total of all Ones, Twos, and Threes the player will move that many spaces FORWARD minus one space for each grazing die.
-For each Runaway that has not been lassoed, the player moves BACKWARDS one space.
-For each Runaway that has been lassoed the player will move forward TWICE the total number of spaces listed.

name: Geheimkrieg
description:
Geheimkrieg is a set of dark science WW2 combat rules written by Matthew Hartley, Steve Blease and Michael Baumann .

The game is a set of company level wargames rules written for miniatures from 20mm to 36mm (1/48th) scale. They recreate the ultra-secret war fought between the Western Allies and the Nazis in the last years of World War II. Refight the war you never knew happened...

Includes:
- A completely new set of highly innovative quick-play wargames rules that involve no measuring!
- The recently uncovered history of what really happened in WWII.
- Scenarios set in the top secret war.
- Statistics for historical and secret troop types for Britain, Germany and USA.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Billionaire Tycoon
description:
Build your business empire to be the first player to earn $1 billion. Start out with $100k. Buy buying companies, cutting deals, and sometimes robbing the bank, work your way up into the super rich.

Turn-based game for up to four players. A roll of the dice determines which country will earn money and where you will have the chance to purchase new businesses. People cards work to sabotage your opponents, or protect you from sabotage. An unlucky roll results in a new flash of the penalty, or bonus, for your opponents' choice.

name: Barbie Race to the Party Game
description: Two to four players race to collect a dress, a tiara, shoes, and a gift. Money is collected at the ATM spaces. Each ATM card tells the owner at which store the card can be used. The first to buy these things and get to the party wins.

name: Valhalla's Gate
description:
From the publisher's website,

"From his throne in Asgard, the god Odin looked down upon Midgard, Alfheim and Nidavellir, the lands where humans, alfs and dvergar dwell. Many were the battles fought in these lands, and great were the feats of bravery and skill, but who among the mortal warriors should Odin send his Valkyries to claim? Only one more warband could be admitted to Valhalla, the great hall of warriors, before the doors were forever closed...

Valhalla's Gate pits warbands of eight or nine humans, elves or dwarves against each other in a race for the rune stone that will admit them to Valhalla. Designed for 25mm or 28mm miniatures, it features an easy-to-learn rules system that offers the option of either a one-night game or a full-on campaign, complete with character advancement.

The rules system includes shape-shifter characters, 25 different runic spells that add magic to the combat, a fast-paced, card-based initiative system, stats for 12 monsters drawn from Norse mythology, rules for inclement weather, and 25 different scenarios."
categories: Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Mythology, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Spillet om Prinsessen som ingen kunne målbinde
description:
Based on a norwegian fairytale.

The players are searching for words that rhymes with the words that the prinsess have. The prinsess have five secret words that you can look at when you land on a prinsess spot. You collect words by landing on a "Askeladden" spot. (The hero of many norwegian tales). By landing on a king spot you can trade words.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: PUSH
description:
The game represents the combat between various Factions of psychic Operatives. Loosely based on the 2009 movie: Push.

You win if at the end of your turn you control the center of the board. Control of the center represents the fulfillment of your own Master Plot and the foiling of the plots of the opposing Factions.

The Board is an 11 x 11 Square grid. The 4 spaces in each corner are called Faction Boxes. The Center square is key to winning. Players win by controlling four of the adjacent spaces to the center: either the four orthogonal or four diagonal spaces around the center space. Operatives, represented by counters, occupy squares, and have various psychic special abilities that affect movement and attack modes.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: See How They Run
description:
A game for up to 5 children.

It is an interactive race game where the player whose mouse gets into the house first is the winner.

There is not dice in this game. Each player gets one mouse and a counter. There is also a cat which is used to mark a different color each turn.

The players take turns to guess in which hand other players hide the counters. If they guess right, they move their mouse to the next color space that matches the color marked by the cat. If they guess wrong, then it is the challenged player who advances the mouse in the same way.

If the cat catches a slow mouse, gues what! the slow mouse is not penalized, instead it gets to advance 3 spaces. A quick, fun, and easy game for 4 years-old upwards.

name: Fratzen schneiden
description:
This game is for very young audiences, and get to know different feelings by making facial expression.

The rules are quite simple:

- Draw a card: happy, laughing, funny, surprised, sad, hiding, angry
- Make an apropiate expression
- move the the meeple to the new position on the board

for 2-4 players, age above 3
includes - Playing Board, Meeples and playing cards

name: Ultimate Music Quiz
description:
Ultimate Music Quiz contains everything you need to run a music quiz night. With 50 question cards containing 1900 questions and answers with an included audio CD, two or more people can test their music knowledge in 10 different categories.

From the box:

This chart-topping quiz is packed full of fascinating questions guaranteed to keep everyone thinking until the end of the night.

Your knowledge will be pushed to the limits by 10 categories titled: Pop Music, 1960's and 1970's, 1980's and 1990's, Name That Song (on audio CD), Music and the Movies, Music Charades, One Hit Wonders, Albums and Singles, What's in a Name?, General Music Trivia.
categories: Educational, Electronic, Music, Party Game, Trivia

name: Investimento: o Jogo da Vida
description:
"Investimento" is a economic board game in which players invest in various businesses, trying to increase their profits, protect their money from inflation (which halves money in hand of players twice in a play), and, at the end of game, get more money than others players to win.

From publisher: "The game develops the minds of the participants, giving them ideas on how to invest well. The players are introduced to the financial, commercial and industrial environment. The goal of each player is invest all his gained money, exploit the acquired businesses, increase them and try to join in profitable partnerships."

Basically, it's a improved "Monopoly", with some concepts of business world.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Galopp
description:
Simple Norwegian roll-and-move horse race game. With the help of a die your horse is hopefully galloping forwards in this race. On the track there are several fences. If you land on a fence field the first time, your horse backs 4 spaces. If you land on the same fence a second time, your horse must return back to start.

The publisher Damm's game number 370, probably from around the 1960ies.

name: Tohuwabohu: Berühmt berüchtigt
description: Tohuwabohu: Berühmt berüchtigt is one of four party games in a new line from Ravensburger for 2011, and in this game – the title of which translates to something like, "Chaos: Notoriously Famous" – players must imitate various historical and fictional characters: Rip your shirt like the Incredible Hulk, box a few rounds against Rocky Balboa, pull out your best Napoleon. Whatever you do, do it quickly as you're not the only ham at the table!

name: Micro Colonial: Rorke's Drift
description:
An expansion for the Tabletop Games' Micro Colonial game. The Rorke's Drift supplement provides additional, game specific, rules to accomodate the small size of the action at Rorke's Drift (rather than British counters representing company sized formations, they represent small groups of enlisted men or individual officers).

This set also includes a map of the Rorke's Drift mission compound to be used in playing the game.

The game is part of Tabletop Games' Micro Warfare Series.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation, Variable Set-up

name: Trafffic
description:
In Trafffic, you want to be the first player to get rid of all your cards. To discard a card, you need to find or create a group of three cars positioned in the same pattern on the game board as is shown on your card.

Everyone plays simultaneously. To move a car on the board, take the green light from another player, then move a car of your choice one space in the desired direction. (If you hold the green light, you must wait for another player to take the light and move a car before you can make another move.)

As soon as you spot a matching combination, say "Beep! Beep!", then show your card to other players so that they can verify that you're correct. If you goofed, the player who spots the error gives you a card from her hand as punishment for you and a bonus for her. When one player runs out of cards, the game ends; anyone with cards still in hand receives penalty points equal to the number of cards they hold. The player with the lowest score after three rounds wins the game.

The cards with green backgrounds show more complicated traffic patterns and can be used to handicap experienced players. You can also give them to the player with the lowest score after rounds one and two to give the other players a better chance against this movement maven.

name: Tabloidspelet
description:
A trivia game based on Swedish News Tabloids from the last 50 years.

The game is to answer up to five questions on a Swedish tabloid newspaper.
The questions are in five levels of difficulty.
The die determines how you should answer the questions.
Level: Select level
Risk: Starting from level one and respond. If you answer correctly, you will have the option to respond to the next as well. Answer wrong when you decided to go ahead, you lose all points.
Double: Choose a level. Correct answer double points. Wrong answer double negative points.
All: Everybody has a chance to answer the question
Jackpot: Starting from level one and respond. You continue until you respond to failure without the risk of losing your points.
Challenge: You choose the level. answer wrong, the others have a chance to respond.

name: Rekniles Ekim
description:
An idea of doing a horse race around Stonehenge came to my mind. This then lead into the concept of BETTING on the race. From here, the basic rules flowed. Then, it occurred to me that Mike Selinker already did a race game around Stonehenge, so I felt it appropriate to connect this game to his chariot racing game. Due to the odd play nature of the betting, it is a natural that it would be alien in nature. The name is Mike Selinker's name spelled backwards, in honor of his Chariot racing game. Spelling it backwards also gives it an alien sounding name.

Number of players: 2–5

Object of the game: To score the LEAST amount of points. This represents the player, as an alien bidder, being able to best predict the future.
Getting Started

Equipment: Deck of 60 cards without the five trilithon cards.
Five trilithon cards in a separate pile
Ten disks of each color (50 total)
Five figures (neutral is not used). These figures represent chariot drivers.

The player who has the least amount of points shows themselves the best predictor of the worst racer, and wins the game. If players are tied, the player who has the most disks amongst all the tied players wins. If still a tie, then the player with the least amount of first place disks wins. If still a tie, the player with the least amount of second place disks wins. If still a tie, then least in third, fourth or fifth. If still a tie, player closest to the starting player wins.

For more conventional wagering, use the variant where the object is to score the MOST points, not LEAST.

name: FreeCelt
description:
Game Rules

Number of players: 1

Object of the game: The object of the game is to clear all the cards from the 12 by 5 grid of cards, moving the day and night cards onto their appropriate stacks face up, ranging from 1-30 in accending order for each card in the day or night suits.
Getting Started

Equipment: The deck of Stonehenge cards, excluding the Trilithon cards. 60 cards total will be used.

The object of the game is to clear all the cards from the 12 by 5 grid of cards, moving the day and night cards onto their appropriate piles, ranging from 1-30 in ascending order for each type of card. The first card in the day stack is the 1 day, and the last card is 30 day. The same goes with the night stack. Cards will run in ascending order on these stacks, starting with 1 and ending with 30. The sequence on each stack will run in the following sequence of colors: White, Blue, Green, Yellow, Red, Black (and repeat with White again and so on).

name: Pethera-Tethera
description:
Number of players: 2–5

Object of the game: Be first player to score 6 points, get 10 pieces in a row, or the last remaining player. Whenever a player scores, they move their figure from one side of the bluestone track to the other side.
Getting Started

Equipment:
The Stonehenge board.
10 disks of each color for each player.
1 figure per player, matching the set of colored disks that a player has.
Grey neutral figure (tracks where player removes piece from).

The outer track consists of 30 spaces, each with four parts, for each number (30 in all) from inside most to outside (making for a total of 120 spaces). In this game, the two day-night spaces, next to the number, on the inside are considered one space. The the next most outside space is the number space. After this comes the colored space. Outside most is a light or dark space. Each of these spaces is considered able to hold one piece in this game. As players place their pieces on the board, in a space, the first piece is put on the day-night space, the second on the number space, the third on the color space, and the last piece is placed on the light or dark space outer section.

Overview of gameplay:
Players alternate turns putting their pieces on the board into one of four spaces on the outer track. A piece either immediately comes from their reserve, or it is taken from the board and put into their reserve and then played, if the player as no pieces in their reserve at the start of their turn. After a player places a piece on the board, pieces may end up sliding towards the inside part of the outer track, and then the board is checked for scoring conditions. If there are scoring conditions, pieces will be removed from the board and put into reserve(s) and scoring occurs. After this more pieces may end up sliding towards the inside part of the outer track and the scoring process is repeated.

The game ends when one player scores 6 points (player's figure hits the last space on the bluestone track), gets 10 pieces in a row, or is the last remaining player. In event of a tie, all players not tied for win at the end of the game eliminated. Then the remaining players play until one player score more points than anyone else in the game. This player wins the game. Players eliminated from the game are treated as they normally would be in the game, with their pieces remaining on the board, but can't win the game.

name: Stackhenge
description:
Number of players: 1–50

Object of the game: The object of the game is to be the player who can stack the most Stonehenge disks in a single stack within 60 seconds, that won't fall over.

Setup: Have a level playing area with enough room to allow people to stack disks into a single pile. The box lid is recommended to be empty, flipped upside down, and set in the middle of the playing area to be used for stacking. The box lid enables disks to fall over and not roll away and get lost.

Set aside all the disks into one large area off to the side, sorting them my color. You will also need to have a space for players to hold as many disks as they bid they can stack, and also the neutral figure.

Clear the stacking area (empty the lid and flip it upside down)

One person acts as timer for the game.

The first player who stacks the amount of disks he bid in a single stack, with the neutral figure on top (before time runs out) that doesn't fall over before time runs out, wins the game.

name: Spirit Convocation
description:
Number of players: 3–5

Object of the game: By casting a series of spells, be the first to have all ten spirits of your color arrive at the base of your trilithon.

Equipment: Ten disks (spirits), figure (druid spirit master, representing the player), and ten bars (magical connections) of one color for each player, one trilithon for each player, and the deck of cards.

Ending the Game

The game ends when a player gets all ten of his or her spirits to the base of their trilithon, and that player wins!

name: Droo
description:
Number of players: 2–100

Object of the game: The object of the game is to score the most amount of points after playing a set number of rounds, each consisting of a unique game.
Getting Started

Equipment: The components needed for each game to be played.
The rules for each game.
A way to record score.

Ending the Game

Once all rounds are played, tally up the score. In event of a tie, the team that won the most games win. If there is still a tie, these teams that are tied play a last game, selected before game began, to determine the winning team.

name: Contiguity
description:
Number of players: 2

Object of the game: Connect all of pieces into one orthogonally connected contiguous group of pieces.

Equipment: Game board (each number space of outer ring is divided up into four spaces). 6 red disks. 6 white disks.

White goes first. Randomly pick who will play white.

Each player alternates turns moving one of their pieces until one player wins.

Pieces have two types of moves, a slide or a jump:
A slide move consist of moving a piece vertically (towards the inside of the outer track or towards the outside) or horizontally (to a space of a larger or smaller number) an unlimited number of spaces until it lands on a desired empty space. A piece may slide through multiple empty spaces but NOT an occupied space. A piece also may not land on the same space it started its turn on.

A jump move consists of a piece jumping over a single piece of either player, vertically or horizontally and landing on an empty space. A jump is like a slide, except the jumping piece is sliding through an occupied space. A piece may not jump over more than one piece.
Ending the Game

The first player to get all 6 of his pieces into one orthogonally connected contiguous group of pieces (vertically and/or horizontally adjacent) wins the game.

name: Contiguity Deluxe
description:
Contiguity Deluxe is inspired by the original Contiguity, but adds other elements to make for a deeper game. In this game, druid pieces and a variable set up are added. This was added as an additional game, instead of a replacement for Contiguity due to the compact nature of the rules to Contiguity.

Number of players: 2

Object of the game: The object of the game is to win the game by one of two ways. One way to win is by connecting all the pieces into one orthogonally connected contiguous group of pieces (all the pieces are connected to each other vertically and/or horizontally next to each other). The other way to win is by totally surrounding an opponent's druid.

Equipment: Game board (all spaces 1-30. Each number space of outer ring is divided up into four spaces)
6 red disks(pawns), 6 white disks(pawns)
1 red figure, 1 white figure (druids)

Ending the Game

There are two ways to win, connecting and surrounding. See below for details and configurations for each of these ways to win.

name: Lexihenge
description:
Seeing there were no word games for Stonehenge, I felt compelled to create one, and Lexihenge is a result. I would like to thank everyone at the summer 08 Spielbany event for playtesting and feedback of the game.

Number of players: 2–10

Object of the game: The object of the game is to score the most points after seven rounds.
Getting Started

Equipment: Timer (to time 1 and 5 minutes)

Dictionary or other list of legal words to use.

A way for people to write down their answers for each round.

Way to record score (pen and paper works or use the Stonehenge board with figures)

Deck of Stonehenge cards, excluding the black cards and the trilithon cards. In game, each color represents a group of letters:
White: A, B, C, D, F
Blue: E, G, H, J, K
Green: I, L, M, N, P
Yellow: O, Q, Qu, R, S, T
Red: U, V, W, X, Y, Z

A guide for each player (or team) as to which letters a color represents.

Ending the Game

Which ever player (or team) won the most rounds wins. In event of a tie, the tying players shuffle all the cards and play one more round. This continues until there is one player.

name: Fidchess Qenqe
description:
Fidchess Qenqe is an attempt to modify Fidchess so that it works for more than two players, with additional changes to make it a different game. Qenqe is five in proto-Celtic.

Number of players: 2–5

Object of the game: Be the first player to capture an opponent's Rigant, or causes an opponent to be reduced to only controlling Rigant (because all their disks are in stacks of other players or off the board).
Getting Started

Equipment: Stonehenge board, using all 30 spaces of outer track, and is considered four spaces wide for this game. All 50 disks in the game. All 5 non-neutral figures (Rigants).

Ending the Game

Once a player has either captured an opponent's Rigant, or causes an opponent to be reduced to only controlling Rigant (because all their disks are in stacks of other players or off the board), the player wins the game.

name: Fidchess
description:
Fidchess is an attempt to create a chess-like game for Stonehenge, using just the original parts in the Stonehenge game. Its name comes from the Celtic game Fidchell, which has been called “Celtic Chess”. Fidchess has little to do with Fidchell, except that they are both abstract strategy games. The name of the piece are derived from Celtic numbers, except for "Rigant", which means "Lord" in proto-Celtic.

Number of players: 2

Object of the game: To either capture an opponent's druid or all 10 of the opponent's disks that are used to make up pieces in the game.
Getting Started

Equipment: Stonehenge board (outer track). Outer track is four spaces wide (combining day and night spaces as one space) and 30 spaces round, using spaces 1-8 only.
10 green disks and 10 yellow disks
1 green and 1 yellow figure (Rigants)

Ending the Game

Once a player has either captured their opponent's druid or eliminated their opponent's Oins, Duos, Peths, or Teths (and Quens in Quen variant) from the board, they win the game.

name: Stonerush
description:
I think some of the best games have a number of characteristics in common: they have simple rules, they are quick and they have a high replayability factor. The Stonehenge games are a good example of this. With this in mind, I recalled a number of these games and all of a sudden, there was the idea of creating a game of my own; a quick racing game with easy rules and a high replayability factor: Stonerush.

Number of players: 3–5

Object of the game: The players are druids who come home to Stonehenge after a hard days work. As part of their daily ritual (or just having fun), they try to be the first to run around the great stone circle. The player whose druid arrives first on case 30 of the outer ring is the winner.
Getting Started

Equipment: - The board
- The number cards: you will need all the cards, except the "night"-cards from 13 to 30.
- The trilithon cards
- The 5 figures, also called druids (even with 3 or 4 players!)

Ending the Game

When a figure reaches case 30 of the outer ring, the players reveal their trilithon card. The player whose color matches that of the figure that reached case 30 is the winner. If this color belongs to no-one (for example in a 3-player game), the winner is the player who has advanced the most.

Variant: for a quicker game, use the bluestones as the racing track.

name: Raiding Duel
description:
After developing Raiding Stonehenge, it became apparent the game was best suited for 4-5 players. This meant the initial 2-3 players planned for the gamer were dropped and put into the unrecommended category. Seeing that Raiding Stonehenge was a good game, and feeling a need to come up with more 2 player Euro-style games, I decided to adapt Raiding Stonehenge to two players. Raiding Duel is the result.

Number of players: 2

Object of the game: The object of the game is to score the most points after two rounds of play. Players score 10 points for each complete set of disks they collect at end of game. A set normally contains one disk of each color: White, red, green, blue, yellow. Players LOSE one point for each disk not in a set.
Getting Started

Equipment: Deck of 60 cards, excluding the Trilithon cards. 50 disks, 10 per color. Each disk type represents a different item type from Camelot. 1 gray figure (to indicate start player). A way to track score.

Ending the Game

After the second round is over, the game ends. At that point, game is over, and players total up their points for both rounds. The player with the most points wins. In event of a tie, players keep playing two cards from their hand, as they have done prior. until they are down to only two cards. The player with the highest card in their hand wins. If both players tie, they each look for the next highest card in their hand. If, after that, the players are still tied, the game ends in a tie.

name: First Druid
description:
We were working on a Stonehenge game of our own when we came across the anthology box. Not surprisingly, the board and pieces were very similar to those that we had developed, so it was fairly simple to transfer most of our ideas to match those provided. Our game links Stonehenge to the magical powers of the Earth and other elements and is basically a battle for magical supremacy.

Number of players: 3–5

Object of the game: The object of the game is to use your magical powers (represented by the cards) to convince the local clans (represented by disks on the bluestones) and spirits (represented by bars on the outer ring) that you are the druid most able to carry out the solstice rituals. Building trilithons and preparing the altar stone may assist along the way and it is vital that you keep up with the necessary preparations to avoid offending the spirits.
Getting Started

Equipment: First Druid uses all of the pieces provided in the basic game box. Each player uses the pieces of one colour (along with the trilithon card of his or her colour), so if there are less than five players some colours will not be used.

Throughout these rules, the plastic figures are referred to as 'druids'.

Ending the Game

When the first player has moved his druid all the way around the ring, the game is at an end. Merely streaking ahead is not enough to secure victory, however; it is the support and alleigances secured along the way that decide which druid is the First Druid!

Each player has as many points as the number his druid piece is on at the end, plus additional points for allied tribes and spirits. Tribes and Spirits count 1 point for the first in a run, 2 for the second, 3 for the third etc.

So, the game is a complex balance of using your magical powers to race ahead and gaining allies. In addition, trilothon stones enhance your supply of magic, and dressing the alter stone may move you ahead or even move your rivals backwards!

name: Meets & Bounds
description:
Meets & Bounds is intended as a fast-playing game which has players attempting to optimize their score while managing the uncertainty of what opportunities chance will offer.

Number of players: 2–5

Object of the game: In Meets & Bounds players vie to control as many spaces as possible. Each player will attempt to establish a sector of his own while thwarting his opponent's efforts. Each player will be rewarded for the size of his sector, as well as the number of groups and bounded disks he can contain within his sector. Some players may even form more than one sector. The player with the most victory points will win the game.
Getting Started

Equipment: Board
All cards
5-10 disks per player

For 2 players use 10 disks per player.
For 3 players use 7 disks per player.
For 4 players use 6 disks per player.
For 5 players use 5 disks per player.

Ending the Game

Players earn victory points for holding sectors. A sector is a range of numbered spaces with no disks of an opponent within, and bounded by 2 of the player’s disks. Players also score victory points for friendly disks within their sectors. Finally, players score points for groups of 2 or more of their own playing pieces in contiguous spaces.

The player with the most victory points wins the game.

Scoring
Sectors: Score 1 point for each numbered space of the range. A range is always the largest possible area bounded by the pieces of a single color.

Bounded Pieces: Score 1 point for each interior disk within a sector. Bounded pieces never define a range.

Groups of 2: 1 point per piece. The two pieces must be contiguous.

Groups of 3 or more: 2 points per piece. Groups must be contiguous.

Scoring Example: White has pieces in 6 night, 7 day, 9 day, 12 day, 13 night. There are no pieces belonging to opponents in any spaces between 6-13. White will score 8 points for their sector. White will score 3 points for Bounded Pieces (7, 9, 12). White will score 2 points for the group of two pieces that are contiguous (12 day & 13 night). Note that 6 night and 7 day are not contiguous, and therefore do not score as a group. White scores a total of 13 points.

name: Druid Olympics
description:
As I looked at this board, I couldn't help but think of how difficult it would be to run in circles along the tops of the stones, constantly headed inward towards the middle. Besides making you dizzy, you would have to deal with wind, rain, and perhaps huge monolithic rocks magicly moved in your way by powerful wizards. The Olympic Games of ancient Greece came to mind. Granted we still have Olympic Games, but they are much tamer than the win or die type games of the original Olympics. What if the Celts also had a version of these games. Stonehenge would make a perfect field for such a competition. Start by running along the tops of the outer ring while trying to keep your balance, especially in strong winds. Just looking at it I couldn't help but think of it as one big obstacle course that has been waiting for thousands of years to be used again. This game is the safer version of that idea.

Number of players: 3–5

Object of the game: You are a druid competing in the games. You will have to balance yourself on the outer ring, race between the two rings, hurdle the inner ring, and then push yourself to the breaking point in an attempt to be the first one to the alter.

Equipment: Druid Olympics uses the board, the deck, one figure for each player, one disk and one bar for each player, the trilithons, and one disk of each color.

Ending the Game

The game ends when a player reaches the alter stone. This player is the Grand Champion and is celebrated as a hero. The rest are sacrificed.

name: The Square Circle
description:
The objective of the game is to collect the most valuable goods before the High Druid declares the square is closed.

The game uses ALL of the pieces in the original game.

name: Fightin' an' Drinkin' an' Stealin'!
description:
After reading The Wee Free Men by Terry Pratchett, it became obvious that Stonehenge was an ancient sporting arena built by clans of Scot-like fey trapped in our world. As I looked at the board, I began to wonder just what these sporting events might have looked like. I believe I've captured the strategy and excitement of those ancient contests, without quite so much mess.

Number of players: 2

Object of the game: You control a clan of kilt-wearing fair-folk at the Umpteenth Occasional Games, trying to earn awards in three events: Fightin', Drinkin', and Stealin'. The clan that gets the most awards not counting their best event wins! (You didn't really win if you got all the Killing Monsters awards but lost in Quaffing, Thieving, Not Passing Out, and Not Getting Clobbered).

Equipment: Fightin' an' Drinkin' an' Stealin'! uses the deck (divided into three decks), the board, all of the little colored disks, and all six of the figures.

Ending the Game

Once the seventh and final round is over, each player discards all the awards of whichever color he or she has the most of (remember that each Wee Lawyer a player has halves the value of his or her awards in that color). If two or more of a player's colors are tied, that player picks one to discard. The player with the most awards left after discarding his or her best color, wins.

name: Wilcox War
description:
From the Curious Games site: "Wilcox War is a variant of the classic game of War, adding strategy and bluffing, making a fun game for everyone in the family!"

Players play with 3-card hands, with all cards being shown to each other at the start of the game. The draw pile is also face up so players can have a rough idea what their opponent's hand is - and then they have to guess "Will they bluff?". As in traditional War, the players reveal a card, with the larger card revealed capturing the smaller. The alterations in Wilcox War changes the game into a small bluffing/strategy game.

Base rules are for playing with two decks once through, but includes rule adjustments for playing until one person has all cards, and for single-deck games.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Memory

name: Ancient Historical Battles
description: This is volume 1 of a series of ancient battle scenarios. Thirty-nine (39) different battles are represented from Megiddo (1479 BC) to Adrianople (378 AD). Orders of battle are given in terms of the popular DBA/DBM miniatures rules, though there is enough information given for adapting the battles to other rules systems as desired. While DBA usually focuses on armies composed of exactly 12 elements, the scenarios included vary in size depending on the numbers of combatants.
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Wiewiórka Spryciulka
description: A push your luck with squirrels game for children! Each turn the active player throws 8 boxes. If none of the boxes fell with the open side up the player ends his turn. If he threw at least one box on it's open side up he puts the nut that was inside the box in front of him. Now he can either end his turn and gain all the nuts he has in front of him or risk and throw with all the remaining boxes. And now: if none of the boxes have their open side up - he loses all the nuts he put in font of him this turn. Otherwise he takes the nuts from the boxes with their open side up and once again decides whether he wants to risk another throw or gain all the nuts he has in front of him. The first player to gain 2 sets of 4 nuts in one colour wins!

name: pwn_Henge
description:
Number of players: 2

Object of the game: The object of pwn_Henge is to "capture" your opponent's disks by moving one of your pieces onto a space occupied by his or her piece(s).
Getting Started

Equipment: Cards (trilithon cards removed)
10 disks of a color for each player
The game board

Playing the Game

Players must first randomly determine which player will go first as this is a turn based game. Players each draw a card from the deck. The card having the highest value determines which player goes first. If both players draw cards of the same value, the day card beats the night card.
The goal of PWN-Henge is to remove all of your opponent’s pieces from the board by capturing them with your own and be the last man standing. To capture an opponent’s disk, you must one of your pieces to that space. There are two methods for doing this:

Players may move their disks into adjacent spaces:
This may be done even if the target space is unoccupied.
This results in the defending player losing his or her piece(s.)

If a player moves his or her disk onto a space with two or more disks, the “defending” player will lose all of those pieces.

Players may draw a card:
Players may move to the space indicated on the card.
Players may move into occupied or unoccupied spaces.

Players may also move a disk in the exact amount of spaces (in either direction) of the drawn card’s value.
Players may only make one move per turn and may move any of their own pieces in that turn. If a player draws a card, he or she must play it or pass. Played cards go into a discard pile. If the deck runs out before gameplay has ended, players must re-shuffle the deck and place it face down in the middle of the board.
Ending the Game

Once a player has removed his or her opponent's pieces from the board, the game ends and the last man standing is the winner.

name: The Equinox Games
description:
Game Rules

Number of players: 3–5

Object of the game: The first player to have his color disk atop the majority of trilithons in play is the winner. That would be 2 trilithons in a 3 player game, 3 in a 4 player game etc..

Equipment: The game board. The neutral (grey) figure. One Trilathon per player. The entire card deck.
Each player will need:
A player figure. 10 corresponding colored bars. Enough corresponding colored disks to top the majority of trilithons in play.

Whoever has the most bars of any color has sway over a trilithon. Each player began with a trilithon because they had more bars of their own color than anyone else.
If at any time a player has more of an opponent's color bars than any other player, he/she replaces that player's color disk with his/her own atop a trilithon.
When ever one player has his/her disks atop the majority of trilithons that player wins.

name: Defenders of the Stone Circle
description:
In a time long past, the mystical energies of Stonehenge were incredibly strong. The concentrated magic attracted demons from another plane of existence. The priests of an ancient people wished to protect their sacred place and devised a way to create a barrier that, once completed, would keep the demons at large. They also summoned spirits of Nature to help in their fight. The priest who worked best to protect Stonehenge was destined to rule.

Game Rules

Number of players: 3–4

Object of the game: Score the most points by defeating demons and surrounding Stonehenge with a magical barrier.

Getting Started

Equipment: The board, the trilithons, the card deck, the neutral figure (dark priest), the player figures (priests), disks and bars. Required extra material: six spirits of Nature in each player color, twelve demons in a neutral color, and six demon appearance markers (use pawns and wooden cubes from other games, for example).

The game ends when the last moving demon is defeated or successfully attacks a trilithon or the altar stone. A final scoring takes place. First, each player loses 3 points per demon at their respective trilithons. The single player with most defeated demons scores 3 points. Each wall segment on the board is worth 1 point for the respective players. The player with most points wins. If there is a tie, the winner is the tied player with most spirits on the board.

name: GalaXism
description:
Your flagship has wandered into uncharted space and you've suddenly detected an unknown vessel with its weapons readied and shields raised! Will you be able to survive the encounter?

GalaXism (guh-lax-iz-um) is a starship combat game for 2-6 players that should take about an hour to play. Players control the flagships of ten different races, playing their cards as increases to shields, weapons, defenses, and various other ship statistics.

Cards are laid out around a flagship, each section corresponding to a different side of the ship from forward, aft, starboard, and port. In addition, there's the command deck where the ship is controlled. The upgrade cards have 4 icons each and are shifted up, left, right, and up-right to reveal more icons during the game.

This game is heavily influenced by Innovation but taken in a different way.

I have separated the rules from the components to make it easier on me to update the rules. This also makes the download smaller when there are changes to the rules so that you don't have to worry about printing out new components.

Current Rules: http://www.lyonesse.info/games/download.php?filename=GalaXis...

Current Components: http://www.lyonesse.info/games/download.php?filename=GalaXis...

Discussion Thread: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/614464/wip-galaxism-a-quick-...
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Hand Management, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Poodle-opoly
description:
From LateForTheSky.com:

GRACEFUL, INTELLIGENT, CHEERFUL, ATHLETIC... MEET THE POODLE!

The poodle is regarded as the second most intelligent breed of dog. They come in toy, miniature, and standard sizes with many coat colors. The breed originated in Germany as a water retriever and the English word "poodle" comes from the German word "pudel", meaning to splash in the water. They like to be in the center of things and are easily trained to do astonishing tricks involving both brains and agility. Known as a "people dog", the Poodle is a "person" and expects to be treated as one! Each one is a character and for that reason they make wonderful, unique companions.

POODLE-OPOLY IS A GAME OF TAIL-WAGGING FUN!
COLLECT YOUR FAVORITE POODLES AND PLAY HARD!

Increase your rent by buying Toys for your dogs and upgrading them to Big Bones. Sounds easy enough until you get fleas, have an accident on the carpet, or worse yet, get sent to the Kennel!

GRAB YOUR TOKEN AND ADVANCE TO GO POODLES!

Who knows! You may soon be Best in Show... or hanging out by the fire hydrant!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Westie-opoly
description:
From LateForTheSky.com:

FRIENDLY, LOYAL, STRONG-WILLED, ENERGETIC,
MEET THE WESTIE!

With BIG personality, the West Highland Terrier is a bold and energetic little dog with absolutely no idea of its true size! More commonly called the "Westie", the breed is known for its friendly, strong-willed character and remarkably bright white coat. Westies were bred in Scotland and used to seek and dig out foxes and badgers. They love their two-legged companions and are generally willing to please them... as long as they think it’s a good idea! To be fair, this is a dog bred for tenacity and if dealt with firmly and lovingly, a Westie makes an affectionate addition to any family.

WESTIE-OPOLY IS A GAME OF TAIL-WAGGING FUN!
COLLECT YOUR FAVORITE WESTIES AND PLAY HARD!

Increase your rent by buying Toys for your dogs and upgrading them to Big Bones. Sounds easy enough until you get fleas, have an accident on the carpet, or worse yet, get sent to the kennel!

GRAB YOUR TOKEN AND ADVANCE TO GO WESTIES!

Who knows! You may soon be Best in Show... or running with a pack of Westies!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Spinagogue
description:
Object of the Game
To spin the dreidel longer than your opponent. "Longer" pertaining to the length of the time the dreidel spins from the release to the finish Time of Spin (TOS), from the moment the dreidel leave your fingers to the moment it comes to a complete rest on its side. The referee (an impartial judge who is not spinning in the match) is the only one who wil keep track of a spinner's TOS with the sanctioned MLD Spinometer.

The Spin Zones are located in the middle of the Spinagogue. They are the designated "spinning areas", the only place on the spinagogue a player is permitted to spin. A player can never intentionally spin the dreidel outside of the Spin Zone. For MLD tournament play the Spin Zone decreases in size as rounds progress, usually every two rounds in "head-to-head" play depending on your bracket and every round in a "total spin tournament". The Spinagogue comes with two separate spin Zones, when placed inside of the Spinagogue comes with two separate Spin Zones, when placed inside of the Spinagogue they decrease a player's spinning area, making spinning conditions more difficult.
There are 3 more variations of play using different MLD Game Terrains (inserts): Spinnings, Target Tops & Hardwood Court.

name: Panimomestari suosittelee
description:
Tietovisa oluen ystäville.
Quiz-type Boardgame for beer enthusiastics.

Game includes a board with a trail of different types of beer with The Start spot and the Goal.

The game includes only the board and the Question cards. No playing pieces for the players are included, but the players are instructed to use bottle caps, small coins and/or anything they find from theyr pockets as the playing pieces

During a players/teams turn they answer a question presented to them by a opposing player/team from a question card that includes 2 different questions (the question asked is determined randomly)
On wrong answer they have to take one Step back and on right answer 3 forward. If the Question card includes a picture of the beer where the players piece was originally then they are awarded with one additional step forward , the first one to reach the goal is the winner

name: Estratègia Territorial
description:
Educational game where up to four players have to develop the territory of Catalonia (Spain) by establishing industries and equipments.

The players alternate taking turns moving their tokens around the board and building the different industries, buildings, and equipments.

Each player can choose among four different building strategies, each having its different Victory Points chart. At the end of the game, the player with more VPs wins.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Network and Route Building, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Monopoly: Highlands & Islands Edition
description: Version of Monopoly using locations such as Ben Nevis and Loch Ness from the Highlands and Islands of Scotland in place of the traditional properties.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Mi Gato se Incendia!
description:
Mi Gato se Incendia! (My Cat is on Fire!) A board game of escaped housecats and strange situations.In Mi Gato se Incendia! 2-6 players take the part of a family chasing after their escaped house cat.Mi Gato has slipped its bonds and is running free through the neighborhood. But with freedom, comes a price.

Fire.

Rogue Russian satellites, BBQ grills, street punks - and much more can cause Mi Gato to burst into a fiery ball of spite. Mi Gato has 9 lives and it's up to the players to capture it and return it safely home, or no one wins!

Use two decks of cards - one to move Mi Gato, the other to call in the vet, put a smoldering cat out, capture Mi Gato, and foil each others plans!

Mi Gato se Incendia is an electronic publication, available as PDFs and comes with everything you'll need to play this game. The game board can be printed out on a single piece of 8.5" x 11" paper. All cards will fit on standard Avery Business Card templates, or can be printed on plain paper.

name: Alpha Word Game System
description:
The Alpha Word Game System is a comprehensive word game system made up of three components; a deck of Alpha Playing Cards, a set of Alpha Tiles and a double set of Alpha Dice. All three components are by themselves a game system, so having any one component allows you to play several different games, having all three allows you to play even more games.

The Alpha Word Game System is based on the original deck of Alpha Playing Cards which was released in 1997. There has been a two minor changes made to the Alpha Playing Cards in creating the Alpha Word Game System. The first is the addition of the marked vowels on the semi-wild vowels cards and the second is the addition of the board grid on the backs of the Alpha Playing Cards allowing the cards to be made into game boards for the tiles and dice.

The Alpha Word Game System and its components are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 United States License; so anyone can make their own components for the Alpha Word Game System. There are free PDF files that you can use to make your own set. If you are feeling really creative, you can design your own graphics too. You can make as many copies as you like, and if you are in a entrepreneurial mood, you can sell them. If you have question about the Creative Commons License or would like more information please refer go to creativecommons.org. If you still have questions on how it relates to Alpha write to one of the designers.
categories: Dice, Educational, Game System, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Plantation
description:
A card game developed for the Quick Print and Play Design Challenge. Players take on the role of colonizers seeking to establish plantation empires in the new world. Adroit placement of sugar, tobacco, gain, indigo, and coffee plantations will yield rich harvests of gold and victory points. But watch out: native empires and geographic barriers such as mountain ranges may confound your efforts.

The game is played with a deck of game cards and several kinds of tokens (all of which can be substituted with generic game components such as poker chips). Each card represents a colony, complete with several plantations. Players take turns "discovering" colonies (collecting cards), "settling" them (playing cards into their play area), "harvesting" from them (collecting VPs), and taking other actions intended to construct the most effective plantation society. The key to the game is to place cards in such a fashion that plantations of the same time are adjacent to each other. Harvesting from these chains of like plantations yields enormous bonuses in victory points.

But watch out, for there are obstacles to overcome. Harvesting is not cheap, and players must generate the income necessary to produce. Additionally, geographic barriers cost gold to overcome, while native empires diminish harvest chains. And pirates lurk nearby, waiting to disrupt the plans of even the cleverest colonial planner.

In the end, the player who most effectively builds and harvests will win the day.
categories: Card Game, Exploration, Farming, Print & Play, Territory Building

name: Fighters of D
description:
Fighters of D is a quick print-and-play one-on-one fighting card game for 2 Players using the paper-rock-scissor mechanic with a few combos. My goal is to teach my 5,5 years old boy to learn the basics, so he can ready to play Yomi, the great card game that perfectly captures the essence of a fighting game, in the future. Then Fighters of D becomes way better than I expected, that's why I release it for everyone to enjoy :)
Each Player needs a Fighter Deck (only 7 cards one 1 sheet of paper!) and 2 HP Cards.
The first Fighter loses all his/her HP loses that Round, and the first Fighter wins 2 Rounds (best of three) wins the game!
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Česko sport
description: Expansion to Česko (Czechia), questions and answers. Adds 600 questions/answers about sport to the original game.

name: Madeline at the White House
description:
Madeline at the White House Game is the first in a series of active games from Briarpatch that encourage the players to get up and move…they have to, they are the game pieces!
Players visit landmarks of Washington on their flying carpets. The first player to visit them all is the winner. Sturdy landmark plaques and durable spinner allow for play indoors or out.
