When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Sylt, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

description:

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Thüringen, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Spore
description:
Spore is an abstract strategy game for two players that is played on a 5x5 board. Two multicolored stashes are required to play. All six pyramids of one color are the invaders. One of them is placed in any square on the board. All other pyramids are villagers. All villagers are placed randomly on the board.

Players alternate turns. Each turn, a player must activate every invader on the board. Invaders can either move and capture a villager or launch a new invader, though only one new invader can be launched each turn. If an invader is unable to perform an action when activated, it is removed from the board.

Players continue capturing villagers until every no further villagers can be captured. Players then score points for each villager captured, with a bonus for completed trees and an additional bonus for completed trees of a single color.

name: Poptrix
description:
Poptrix is an abstract strategy game for two players that is played on a 5x6 board. Each player is given one monocolored stash of pyramids. Players start on opposite short sides of the board. On the first turn of the game, each player places a pyramid of any size in his or her starting row.

Players then take turns either launching a new pyramid or attacking. New pyramids are launched from existing pyramids and land up to two spaces away. Launched pyramids must be a different size than the launcher.

If it is possible for one of a player's pyramids to attack, that player must make an attack. Pyramids of different sizes attack differently and have different strengths. Pyramids are removed from the game when defeated. Victorious pyramids have a cap placed on them that gives them a bonus is combat. Each player only has one cap. The cap is moved around as pyramids win or are defeated in combat.

Players continue to launch pyramids and attack until all pyramids have been launched and no further attacks are possible. The player with the most pyramids on the board at this time wins the game.

name: La Bataille de Nancy: 5 Janvier 1477
description:
La Bataille de Nancy: 5 Janvier 1477 covers the battle of Nancy that saw the victory of the young Duke of Lorraine René II over the Burgundian army and the death of Charles Le Téméraire, causing the end of the Duchy of Burgundy.

Forces of Lorraine have to rout the Burgaundian army that is besieging Nancy, the capital city of Lorraine.

Game mechanisms are classic (I go - U go). Turn sequence is:
- Lorraine: move
- Lorraine: combat
- Burgundy: move
- Burgundy: combat

Count density is low (Lorraine and allies 20, Burgundy and allies 10). Combat use a CRT (from 1/6 to 6/1) yielding results from attacker eliminated to defender eliminated (exchange is always possible on a 6 for 4/1 to 6/1).
Artillery bombardment is also possible.

At the end of the 11th round, players compare victory points. VPs are obtained through elimination of ennemy units. Players score additional VPs if they have enough units close to Nancy.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Zone of Control

name: Monopoly: Wiesbaden
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Wiesbaden, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Wolfsburg, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Grand Galop
description:
Saddle up with the heroines of the TV series, Steph, Lisa and Carole for a thrilling race!
In first part player must wins all four accessories to prepare your horse (saddle, bridle, brush and bucket), then place in training at the armory for master the five gaits of your horse, and finally the race on a cross country course happens with obstacles to win the rosette and be voted best rider!
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Monopoly: Football Top Clubs
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with the top football clubs
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Nord
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Nord, department in France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Pas-de-Calais
description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Pas-de-Calais, department in northern France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: City Inc.
description:
City Inc, is a city building card game for two to six players! With an easy to learn, hard to master style of play. Each player is tasked to help build a great city, while trying to tailor it towards your Agenda and Occupation. Featuring a blocky 16-bit art style coming with over 100 cards and a quick to learn rule set making it easy for the whole family and friends to learn and play!


Excerpt from the rules:

Welcome, rich sucker wise investor! As a new majority shareholder in the company, this orientation tour will teach you the basics of running a multinational conglomerate successfully. By the time we’re done with you, you’ll have the ability to shape the company’s direction as we expand into the city of Metropolitia and absolutely will not be a figurehead whose pocket we’re picking. Definitely not. Perish the thought.

Moving right along, I suppose you’d like a tour of the place? Given that you control it, that seems pretty reasonable. Well, here we go then…
90 City Building Cards
6 occupation cards
6 agenda cards
6 Headlines
1 Rules Sheet
1 Tuckbox

That’s a fair haul, huh? Just goes to show that a few billion dollars still does get you a lot in the modern world, I suppose. Anyway, on with the orientation. Has anyone mentioned to you that there are three other companies of roughly the same size and resources, all making a play for the same city at the same time? Unlikely, isn’t it? You’d think we’d plan these sorts of things a little better. Maybe that can be one of the ‘big changes’ you make around here once we’ve put you through orientation, huh?

--Goal of the game--

Our company can chase the others out of the city in one of two ways.

(1) Control 20% of the city’s total income before anyone else

or
(2) Control the greatest percentage of the city’s income when the place gets as big as it can be (10x5 tiles)

So, I know we’re essentially at war with those other corporations and there probably shouldn’t be rules about this sort of thing, but there are. If you don’t follow them, the other corporations will all call us names and tell on us to judges. Seriously, boss, stick to the rules, it’s just easier on everyone.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Building, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Monopoly: Rouen
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of the city of Rouen, in France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Guessing Sketches
description:
Party game. 12 cards are placed around the house, each card having a cryptic clue to a subject sketched on it.

Example: a phrase;
An M in the top left corner
A T in the top right corner
A rabbit's head in the middle
An E in the bottom left corner
A D in the bottom right corner
Answer = Empty Headed (MT Head ED)

The player who gets the most right, wins.

name: Découvrons la France
description:
Similar to Voyage en France.

Instead of receiving all destination cards in start of the game player draws a next card if he reaches one of destinations.

The players have to move along the board by throwing a die.
First player who has visited 5 destination cities and arrives back in the Paris wins the game.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Scramble for Africa
description:
A game where three major powers of Europe (Great Britain, France, and Germany) attempt to create colonial Empires in Africa from 1882 to 1914. The players lead each of these nations through the use of military units, civilian missions, and diplomats as they move about the African continent trying to gain control of various objectives. The main international rivalries are: Anglo-German in conflict over Central Eastern Africa (Uganda and Kenya), Anglo-French conflict over the Nile Valley, and Franco-German conflict in Morocco and West Africa.

The winner of the game is the nation that gains most points for controling various regions of Africa through the following methods: using their diplomats to negotiate colonial treaties, establishing military cotnrol by having armies detachments occupy specific locations, or creating economic spheres of influence through use of civilian missions.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Point to Point Movement

name: Hot Wheels:  Road Race Game
description:
It is a race to get to the race! Be the first player to complete all four auto maintenance tasks and get to the racetrack finish line to win.

2-4 players move around the outer portion of the game then to the inner track. If a player makes it to the center track without completing all tasks that player must continue to do laps around the inner track until the car mainenance is finished.

The first player to make it to the racetrack finish line and have completed all four maintenance jobs wins the game.

Contents:
1 Game board
4 pawns
1 die
24 game tiles (6 oil change, 6 paint job, 6 new set of tires, 6 tank of gas)
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Operation Blast
description:
Operation Blast is a game of economic and military strategy, playing with cards. You are president of a small republic at war with its neighbors. Thanks to the financial resources you have, you can afford the services of foreign powers to fight the battle.

Your territory, such as your enemies is divided into 10 provinces, materialized by tokens. In different ways, you can destroy your enemies provinces, they can destroy yours, you can rebuild, and they also. When a player's 10 provinces are destroyed, it is eliminated. The last player to have at least one province has won the war.

Apart from the money, there are four types of cards: the production units, combat units, units of action and events. These units belong to foreign powers grouped into five categories: United States, Europe, Eastern Countries, Asia and Arab countries. Depending on the money you have, you can afford the services of these units.

Combat units, such as production units, are placed on the territory of the player. For that, each time he places a card, he must pay the recruitment fee or purchase price, either by using profits from its production, either with cash it may have on hand.

Each unit can only move once per turn. They can either join a production unit to support his defense, or to regroup them (maximum 3 units can be grouped ) or go to war: for this, the player must pay the travel expenses, and the unit then join the combat zone, a "no man's land" in the center of the table. When your opponent has no more unity in the combat zone or to protect his territory , each time you attack him, your attack will destroy a province...
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Economic, Fighting, Territory Building

name: Chef d'Orchestre
description:
6 violins, 4 violas, 3 cellos, 2 basses, 5 Wind Instruments, 5 Percussion cards, 4 Brass, and even a harp and a piano are gathering for a harmonious concert.

You draw a card and put in front of you. You replay if you draw an instrument of a family You already have.
There are also 3 special cards in this game:
The conductor can take a card from another player.
Phone and alarm clock are not good for the ears and You lose a card!

Try to collect similar families and take pleasure in having the full Philharmonic Orchestra to win the game.

Contents:

31 large cards representing the instruments,
3 special cards: conductor / alarm clock / mobile

name: Triple Mémo
description:
Similar with Memory

All photos are by Francois Koch. They represent different animals. Children must not find images that look alike, but those that show the same animal.

name: Dominate
description:
Dominate is a two-player game of area domination with deceptively simple rules.

The game is played on a square 9 x 9 game board with 3 x 3 sub-regions enclosed in boxes – a Sudoku grid without numbers. For game purposes, the board can be broken down into 27 overlapping regions each containing nine squares. There are nine rows, nine columns and nine 3x3 boxes.

The board is empty at the start of the game.

Players take turns placing one, two or three stones as an orthogonally connected group on empty squares. Swap rules apply. Players may not pass a turn.

A player dominates a region by occupying any 5 or more squares in the region. The game is won by dominating 14 or more regions on the board.

name: Round the Houses
description:
From the rules:
"Two lifetimes ago, there were no cars, trains, motor cycles or even bicycles. Horses carried people on their backs, pulled coaches, carriages and wagons. Horses were everywhere and did everything. Mail coaches carried letters and parcels; stagecoaches, post chaises, wagons and carts carried passengers between towns and cities. Horses were changed at Inns and passengers were collected, rested and fed. If you walk around the old parts of our towns and cities you will see the old Inns with their arched entrances and courtyards. Their names often remind us of their coaching past."

A simple roll-and-move game where your "coach" has to go round the board and collect a passenger from each four Inns. There are a few squares that make you miss your turn or go back, and "horse bolts down the lane" squares that make you go to the other side of the board.

name: Pauntel's Got Talent
description:
It is the first season of "Pauntels Got Talent" and the competition is really ramping up! You are a badger, attempting to impress the 6 judges in order to get them to vote for you. It’s not as easy as it seems though because the judges are also competing against each other to see which of them gets the most influence over the competition. Make sure you get the right judges on your side or you don’t stand a chance!

Materials: Basic Decktet and 10 markers in each of the six suits. You may use the Excuse to hold the influence tokens collected by the judges.

Pauntel's Got Talent is an indirect trick-taking game largely inspired by Triumvirate (this may be a bit of an understatement). During the each hand player's will play to tricks which will determine which of the judges, represented by the 6 suits, gains influence for that round. At the end of each hand player's can pledge one card face down. The player who pledges more cards to any given suit wins the favor of that judge and any influence, or points, they are worth.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play

name: Panique 75
description:
The players must identify as quickly as possible a country of the world in order to land a spaceship.
The leader returns a card that shows a letter. Players try to find a country name that starts with that letter. The fastest puts one of his (her) spaceship on that country.
The winner is the first player to put his 15 spaceships on the board.

name: Five Line Poker
description:
This game involves players alternating turns placing a card from their hand into one of five lines on their side (each will have 5 cards in them, and drawing a replacement card (game uses standard deck of playing cards). Object of the game is to try to have at least 3 out of 5 better poker hands than their opponent.

The game is similar to Schotten Totten or Battlelines, but was developed before the developer actually saw the rules to either of these games.

name: Dragon Masters Expansion
description:
An expansion published in Games Workshop's house magazine White Dwarf #145.

It consists of one sheet of new Exploration Counters and rules, as well as rules for a 5th and 6th player; although for you will need material from the game Mighty Empires to play with that many players.

name: Journey's End
description:
In Journey's End, players take on the persona of an adventurer traveling in search of Glory and Treasure. The players journey together along the road, but vie for valor and the recognition of their peers.

Journey's End uses a system of skills collected from different decks, each represented by the back of a card. Meanwhile, the card fronts represent locations along the road traveled, detailing the Quests, Places, and Events the adventurers encounter. Only a portion of these cards are used each game, providing Journey's End with a multitude of game scenarios.

The game hinges on how players allocate their skills during each round of play. Chief among them are several types of bidding wars, where the adventurer who shows the most skill can complete a Quest or take advantage of an Event. Players who feel like they're falling behind can gain new skills or compete over the game's namesake, the Journey's End card. Ultimately, the adventurer with the most Valor at the end of the game can claim victory.

Journey's End provides the genesis of play popular in a deck-builder, but dispenses with the solitary nature of these games. With healthy doses of resource management, bidding, and planning, players can enjoy a quick game with all the complexities of larger and longer games.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Rummy
description: This game is not like the normal Rummy family of card games. A standard deck of cards is included along with a betting layout (like Craps or Roulette)and chips. Play begins by having players make bets in an ante style on the layout. Followed by dealing out all the cards in hands to each player including a dummy hand and the dealer. Play proceeds in a sequencing style with each player in turn playing a card from low to high in suit. When players cannot follow suit because of the missing cards from the dummy hand, a new suit is played. When a player runs out of cards he wins the chips in the Kitty section of the layout. The other betting areas are for specific cards and card sequences being played (6-7-8, etc.) with the card(s) player winning the chips in that specific layout spot.

name: Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kit Scenario Design Contest
description:
The Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kits (ASLSK) depict World War II combat at the tactical (company-sized) level, using squad-sized units in an interactive phased turn sequence based on the original 1977 Squad Leader game. The game was intended as a gateway to the Advanced Squad Leader system created from the original Squad Leader in 1985.

Discussions at the Armchair General/Strategy Zone Online (SZO) forums in 2005 led some to surmise that the ASLSKs in many ways brought back the “feel” of the original Squad Leader, having just a handful of unit types, mapboards, and rules necessary in order to play. A controversial design aspect of that original Squad Leader game was the use of four mapboards, laid end-to-end, in the design of two of the twelve enclosed scenarios. From these discussions, a contest was announced on November 29, 2005, to see if it was possible to recreate the "feel" of those original scenarios using Starter Kit components.

Pete Shelling took the prize from among a talented field of contestants, including veteran gamer Murray McCloskey, Tom Morin, editor for Dispatches from the Bunker who has since seen his popular Valor of the Guards module released by MMP, Ola Nygards, whose Eastern Front scenarios have seen print in ASL Journal, Jean-Pascal Paoli, a regular contributor to French ASL magazine Le Franc Tireur, and veteran scenario designer Pete Shelling, who has had scenarios published in The General and ASL Journal in addition to various third party venues.

Scenarios include:

Scenario A: To the Soldiers of the Ostfront
Scenario B: Exhausting But Productive
Scenario C: Thank Heavens, We Lost
Scenario D: Crimson Snow
Scenario E: Glimmer of Hope
Scenario F: Air Assault on Drvar
Scenario G: Siege Without Shells
Scenario H: Aidez L'Espagne!

name: Gravitem
description:
Like Connect Four but the game deck rotate on its axis, causing also the game pieces to be falling.

In any time player who gets 4-in-a-row he wins the game.

name: Safety Brainiac
description: A roll-and-move game where players answer safety related questions from different categories to earn tokens. The tokens can then be cashed in to earn pieces of a brain shaped puzzle. The game comes with a stack of "You're a Safety Brainiac" certificates for the winners.

name: Afriqu'enjeux: The Africa Memory Game
description: The purpose of this game is to test and increase players' knowledge of Africa. Players travel through different regions of Africa and have to answer a number of questions about the continent along the way. The progress they make will be partly determined by how well they answer these questions. Players have to pay a fine when they do not answer questions correctly, but even if they do answer questions correctly, they still have to face a number of obstacles that may slow them down. Players have to quit the game if they lose all of their money. The first player to reach "The Heart of Africa" wins the game.

name: Gym Cerveau
description:
Object of the game is to answer the questions and recognize the objects with Your senses: with Your hand, Your mouth, Your nose, Your ears and Your eyes to score points.
Gym in brain, you need to answer all your senses. You will need to reconstruct such a figure (Tangram-style) with a blindfold, to recognize a tree among several wafers fragrant, count the colors in a literary text, or find a taste on the tip of language.

Players who is the best to recognize and score most points is the winner,

name: Journey Home
description:
A discussion-based, roll and move board game,with an optional role-playing element. It can be played competitively or with elements of co-operation. Each player starts at home, is born in a different position in life, has certain life-long qualities, and is faced with certain events and choices. The aim is to go home, and the game ends when one or more players have completed the journey and acquired the necessary number of tokens.The game is different each time it is played - depending on the players and the life events that crop up.

There are two journeys:


Through age: by moving through the quadrants of the board representing childhood, youth, prime and vintage, each with a gateway into the next.
Towards home: by accumulating tokens of particular colours, representing the different strands of home: shelter, family, community, environment and inner peace.


When one player goes home, s/he is able to help others do so with any extra tokens. At the end of the game, each player may tell the story of his/her character.

The game is based on the book of the same name (formerly The O of Home) by Jennifer Kavanagh. A significant percentage of the profits will be going to a national charity for homeless people.

All materials from sustainable sources, or recyclable.

name: Happy New Year
description:
Card game using a regular deck of cards and a board.

"The Board represents a typical year; a constant struggle to pay endless bills with a fixed income and a few opportunities of supplementing it. But with good management and more good luck than bad, it is just possible to get through the year with a few pounds saved! The winner of the game is the first person who proves he can do so."

You start the year with 100 pounds, and every player starts on January 1st.

On your turn you may play a card of your choice that matches the suit on the square on the board that you are currently on. If you do, you move that many spaces equivalent to the card that you played (Jack = 11, Queen = 12, King =13). The square you now land on will dictate the suit you should play next turn so that you can advance again. Squares you land on will have good or bad instructions (Gain 6 pounds, lose 9 pounds for example), and so on.

You win the game if you have at least 100 pounds and a card that will take you to New Year's Eve.

name: Mal-Attacke
description:
The players have to draw a word that their teammates have to guess before time runs out. But that's not so easy, because 6 different categories representing more difficult. The painter must, depending on the category, draw the image upside down, paint standing with the "other" hand, humming, or standing on one leg etc.

Team who finish first the "winner's circle" wins the game!
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Real-time, Word Game

name: Palomino Poker
description:
Palomino is a casino-style table game with one dealer and up to seven players. The dealer's hand is always four cards or less, is never better than a pair, and is always completely face up. The player can buy up to five cards to try and beat the dealer, winning more money when the dealer's hand is better.

In addition to this Palomino board, which is available at the Cheapass website, you will need a deck of cards with one joker, and some poker chips.

Source: http://cheapass.com/freegames/palomino. Publisher's website.

name: Boneyard
description:
Boneyard is a silent-bid auction game in which players are bidding on buckets of money. The object is to be the first player to accumulate 40 dollars. Each player starts the game with 26 dollars.

This game is part of the Poker Suite compilation from CheapAss Games.

name: They're Off
description:
Detailed statistical horse racing game. Each race takes a few dice rolls so you can play a campaign version if you want. That won't take more than a few evenings even if it a long campaign.

Board needs mounting (only a paper printed board provided), but worth the effort.

Fast-Action Description
THEY'RE OFF! HORSE RACING
This CLASSIC collector's garnets available once more, now with TIMING SYSTEM!! Over 200 INDIVIDUALIZED horse cards of all-time great THOROUGHBREDS, HARNESS HORSES, and QUARTER HORSES! The ultimate in REALISM & STRATEGY - You decide WHEN to make your move! Run exciting DREAM races! LIMITED quantities. Complete game costs only $10 postpaid

name: Goalspree!
description:
An English football game but more linked to the business of football rather than playing football games.

The board has two tracks, the inner one for the first half of the game, where you build a team and a decent stadium to play in. Then, in the second half, you go round the outer track and hope to score as many goals as you can because goals are converted into cash.

Nice footballer playing pieces.

The most cash wins the game (which is sadly true in the 21st century British world of real football).

name: Monopoly: Limited Too
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

A version of Monopoly licensed with the Limited Too retail store clothing chain.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Plus ou Moins
description:
The game consists of 66 cards (54 numbered cards 1-54 and 12 betting cards, 2 for each players "more" or "less")
Number cards are shuffled and 6 cards are dealt for each player.

The object of the game is to get rid of his number cards first.

In his turn player plays a card on the table face-down. The other players bet on this card with their betting cards what they think is it greater or lower card as the last card.
Player who loses the bet, picks an additional card.
Some wildcards allow You to not pick up a card if You lose a bet.

name: What Am I?
description:
Bible quiz game. A card is read out and players or teams try to identify the subject. All things will be something associated with the Bible. There are 4 clues to a card, each getting easier. So, if no-one is correct after one clue, then the second clue to the same answer is tried. Then a third and a fourth, if needed. With only 50 or so cards and only one question per card, I guess replayability is not so hot.

If a player gets it right, he is given the cards and the player or team with the most cards at the end, wins.

name: LoveSick
description:
From the back of the box:

Love Sick is an quick and fun card game about venereal diseases (STDs) – and how to avoid them. .

In the game the players try to avoid a pile of disease cards - called ”the wad” - which passes around the table. If you have the right card or a condom, you can pass it on – otherwise you’ll get infected. The winner is the player with the fewest disease cards at the end of the game.

LoveSick is designed for use when teaching teenagers about sex and sexual health and it shows in an entertaining and alternative way how condoms can protect you from STDs. It’s full of important knowledge about STDs and sexuality, and it can be used both as a break from class teaching or as a foundation for talking about sex.

name: Challenge Foot
description:
You are the owner/coach/players of the football team.
Manage Your club well, choose stategy in each match and lead it to victory.

During the match roll 3 dice the ball on the total, and three players in the value of the three dice. During the management draw cards.

The owner of the best club at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Targets
description:
From the box:

"The game where everyone is a target."

"Targets is a fast paced, easy to learn game. Play cards to build your hand, whittle down everyone else's, make temporary allies or retaliate against your foes. Remember, there can be only one winner. So target your friends, take their cards, block their actions and make sure, in the end, you are the only one holding cards."

Players are dealt 10 cards each to start. On each turn, a player may either play one card from their hand, or discard one card and draw a replacement. There are three types of cards: "Power" cards which stay in front of the player when played, "Quick Power" cards which can be played at any time, and "Action" cards that cause the action written on them to happen when played. The last player with cards in their hand is the winner.

There is no real theme to the game. The cards simply display text such as "Target misses their next turn", "Destroy target power card", and so on.

name: Auto Game:  De la suite dans les idées
description:
Each player tries to collect the most points by offering up words in a given category: animals, birds or rivers for example.

The card with category is drawn and players bid how many words the category of each player be able to give.
Example: in the category Fairy tales, the highest bid is currently 5. As no other player may submit more than five fairy tales, all other players pass. The player who starts the highest bid must now name 5 fairy tales in the length of time agreed (eg 60 seconds). If successful, He wins the card. Otherwise, the player who had next biggest bid, receives the card.

If the deck is exhausted the player with the most cards is the winner.

If you want to spice up the game, you can also decide that the words of the category will start with a given letter. The youngest player then chooses the letter.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Real-time, Trivia, Word Game

name: Mr Défi
description:
In this game the electronic buzzer takes care of everything: identify questions, give answers, guide players, calculate the score and announce the winners!

Can you find a name, an animal, or a business beginning with the letter "M" in the allotted time?
Will you respond correctly to surprising electronic quiz questions? Will you guess more words to your team than your opponents by singing, dancing and doing what comes into your head?

Buzzer gives the task and the first team who solves it scores a point.

name: Kols
description:
KOLS is a 2-player perfect information card game that simulates a conflict between two opposing fronts.

The game is split into 2 phases. In the first phase you will use cards from your hand to obtain cards from the middle, attempting to increase your military strength. In the second phase you will play cards to 5 different battlefields attempting to achieve key victories and win points.

KOLS uses a standard 52-card poker deck.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Trick-taking

name: FC Bayern München Quiz
description:
The combination of card and dice game includes 288 questions in six levels of difficulty around the German national football team.

Roll "one" and answer the simple question, where correct answer gives You one chip.
Roll "six" and answer difficult question, where correct
answer will be rewarded with six chips.

If the deck is exhausted the player with the most chips is the winner.

Contents:

48 cards
1 dice
150 chips

name: Naval Bombardment
description:
Naval Bombardment should be described as a sophisticated version of the old favourite, Battleships.

The objective of each player is to destroy the opponent's fleet.

Each player provides himself with two grids of 20 x 20 squares, lettered A to T down the side and numbered 1 to 20 across the top. One of these is used for disposing the player's own navy (the 'home' chart), the other for recording salvos on his opponent's chart (the 'away' chart). In addition to these, at the foot of each chart there should be a diagram similar to that shown in Fig. 1 for the purpose of recording hits. This fulfills the dual aim of showing at a glance the combinations of salvo numbers required for locating ships and the amount of fire-power left to each player at any time. Both players should locate themselves in such a way that their charts cannot be seen by the opponent.

Each fleet is composed of thirteen ships. The following table shows the names, sizes and fire-power of each vessel
1 Flagship (FS) . . .8 squares. . .3 guns (3-3-2)
1 Battleship (BS) . . .7 squares . . .3 guns (3-2-2)
2 Heavy Cruisers (HC) . . .6 squares . . .2 guns each (3-3)
2 Light Cruisers (LC) . . .5 squares . . .2 guns each (3-2)
3 Destroyers (Dy) .. .4 squares . . .2 guns each (2-2)
4 Corvettes (Cv) . . .3 squares . . .1 gun each
The figures in parentheses above indicate the way in which guns are destroyed by successful bombardment. For instance, the flagship's first gun is knocked out of action after any three of its squares have been hit, the second gun after any six squares have been hit, and the third when it has been totally sunk. It will be seen that initially each player has a salvo of 24 shots.

In addition to his fleet, each player is provided with twelve mines. Four of these are high-explosive type, the rest ordinary, and their functions are explained later.

Ships may run vertically, horizontally or diagonally, but must of course be in a straight line. No ship or mine can be contiguous either laterally or diagonally with any other ship or mine — there must always be at least one separating square in each case.

When both players have placed all their ships and mines, a coin is tossed to decide who starts. The winner of the toss then proceeds to enumerate the 24 shots of his first salvo. As he calls out the squares both he and his opponent mark the appropriate charts — i.e. his 'away' and the opponent's 'home' respectively - putting a figure ‘1’ in each square as it is called. It is advisable, in order to avoid mistakes, for the opponent to repeat the squares after each one is called or at the end of the salvo.

The salvo having been completed and marked, the opponent then indicates what damage, if any, has been sustained. The information that he gives is restricted to the type of ships hit and the number of squares in each case — not the location. For instance, he might say: Two hits on the flagship, one on a destroyer and one on a corvette'. The only time that any further identification is given is when two or more ships of the same type have already sustained damage, as described later. It then becomes the turn of the second player to fire off his salvo, and the same procedure is observed, both players marking the squares called with the figure '1' again, but this time in the other charts. Naturally, before the second player starts his turn both will have checked to see whether he is still entitled to the full original twenty-four shots or whether any of his fire-power has been reduced. Play continues in this way, the next set of salvos from each player being record¬ed with the figure '2', and so on.

When a hit or hits are registered on one of two or more ships of the same type which have already suffered damage, the ship must be differentiated by salvo numbers. For example, player A has hit both of player B's Light Cruisers, one with salvo 2 and the other with salvos 3 and 4; if on salvo 5 he again hits one of these two ships, player B must say whether it is the '2' ship of the '3-4' ship. One way of arranging this differentiation neatly is to assign names or letters to those ships which have more than one in their class, e.g. Destroyers A, B and C, Heavy Cruisers A and B, etc.

The only square to be identified immediately is one containing a mine. When a player's shot lands on one of these his salvo comes to an abrupt end and he loses the rest of his shots in that salvo. In the case of a high-explosive mine he not only loses the remainder of the current salvo but the whole of the next one as well.

Fig. 1 shows a typical layout at the start of a game, while Fig. 2 shows the same chart but with all the "used" squares filled in — i.e. the squares actually occupied by vessels and mines plus all the surrounding squares which are unusable through the application of the ship placement rules. This is done to illustrate the importance of correct location of opponents' destroyed ships; note that although the occupied squares number only 73, there is a total of 323 'used' squares plus a further 8 in which no ship could possibly be, (designated in the diagram with an 'x').

It is noticeable when playing with beginners that they tend to pepper an identified target area instead of limiting the follow-up shots to a few well-placed attempts. This blitzkrieg approach may well knock out a gun somewhat more quickly than the more patient player, but it has two distinct drawbacks: (a) it will waste most of the salvo doing so instead of exploring other areas and (b) more seriously, the player will probably end up not knowing where the destroyed ship is and consequently not knowing which of his opponent's squares are unusable, which, especially towards the end of the game, can be a strong disadvantage when salvos are small and every wasted shot a severe liability.
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Recognition, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Wir zählen
description:
Goal of this game is to teach children counting.

The game comes with 60 domino-like tiles showing numbers, numbers written in words and objects (to be counted) on both sides.

There are several game modes:
- play domino
- sort tiles from 1 to 20
- build telephone numbers
- calculate differences
- build a tower with all tiles showing the same numbers or number of objects
- run a domino race

name: Votoms Simulation Manual
description:
Tactical level wargame based on the Japanese animated series "Armored Trooper Votoms". The game was developed over five different games published in Dual Magazine issues no. 6 to no. 10. Each game featured a different setting but used same basic rules with different map and units. Game no. 5, "Armored Trooper," serves as an omnibus edition and collects most of the rules from the previous four games.

Players each control one or more piloted Armored Trooper mecha units (AT for short).

Each turn, players choose a behavior, called an "Action Pattern" for each unit. An action pattern (such as Run, Walk, Fire (Weapon), Dive (Underwater), and Roller Dash (use roller skate-like wheels)) determines how a unit may move and how well it performs in combat for that turn. Players also plot their movement and how many shots they will fire from a ranged weapon, if any.

All movement takes place simultaneously and the players move their units on a hex map.

After movement, ranged and close combat (called "Battling") are resolved. All action is simultaneous, so results of damage do not take effect until the end of the turn.

In the basic game, each player use one Armored Trooper and battle to destroy the opponent. A skilled player can handle more Armored Troopers for large-scale battles. A few scenarios are included, but players are expected to design their own combat situations.

Game no. 3 "Outer Space Battle" is very different from the other games. It uses vector-based movement in outer space and only a small number of AT units are able to be used outside of the atmosphere.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: New Deal
description:
New Deal is a solitaire card game in which you are trying to help the US recover from the great depression. You play as Franklin D. Roosevelt and will implement economic policies and deal with various crises that arise.

There are 8 objectives in the game, each representing an area of the US economy, such as Banking, Agriculture, and Public Works. The game is played over 15 turns. Each turn consists of 5 phases in which you 1) draw 9 cards 2) Play one crisis card (if you have one) 3) Play a legislative card 4) Play a set of cards to enhance one of the objectives 5) Discard between 1 and 5 cards. At the end of the game, you determine your final score by multiplying your lowest objective score with your highest objective score.

name: Monopoly Junior: Trek Alaska
description:
Alaskan explorers circle the board buying properties and erecting igloos on them to charge "visitors" rent. There are no deeds to the properties, the color of the igloo denotes ownership. When the first player runs out of money, everyone else counts their cash. The player with the most money wins!

Comes with a game board, 24 Chance cards, 48 plastic igloos, Monopoly Junior money, a die, and four colored explorers. There's also a "Trekker's Guide" which is a National Geographic-type folio with information about Alaska. It's not integral to playing the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Mini Mouth
description:
In Mini Mouth, players race to create words with the letters on display, with the fastest mouth claiming the letters used.

To set up the game, place all the letter tiles face down and shuffle them. One player chooses 2-5 tiles and reveals them, then everyone races to name a word that includes all of the letters revealed. (One caveat: If more than one letter with an asterisk is revealed – those letters being J, Q, X and Z – then players need to use only one of these letters in their word.) The player who first names a word that includes the letters claims all of the letters used. If no one can think of a word or players simultaneously call out an acceptable word, return the letters to the letter pool. The next player clockwise then draws 2-5 tiles and the game continues.

As soon as no tiles remain in the letter pool, the player with the most tiles wins!

name: Think Thrice
description:
Think Thrice consists of 25 tiles, each with three attributes: the foreground color (red, yellow, or blue); the background color (green, violet, or orange); and the shape of the picture on the tile (sun, moon, or star).

Each player begins the game with four tiles. On his turn, a player either draws a tile from the bag or plays one or more tiles to the playing area to form one or more triads. A triad is a set of three tiles in which either an attribute is the same on all three tiles or it is different on all three tiles, as in the game of Set.

In making a play, a player may link his tiles to existing ones in the playing area or keep them separate. He also may re-arrange previously played tiles, provided that every tile in the playing area remains part of a triad.

The first player to run out of tiles wins.

name: Sky Trails
description:
A card game about traveling from San Francisco to Shanghai, China. The cards of the game of Sky Trails are divided into two parts, Map Cards and Route cars. (24 of each). The map comprise 4 sets of 6 cards each, forming an end to end in proper order and from a route of plane travel from San Francisco in the west to Shanghai China in the east. The route cards show 12 important stops along the way with a picture of a point of interest, the flag of the country, a symbol or emblem or a person or two in native dress. There are two alike cards for each of these 12 stops These cards are numbered San Francisco 5, New York 10, Gander 15, Shannon 20 and so on, Each succeeding card stop traveling East increases in value by 5 until Shanghai (value 60) is reached.

How to play: Deal 9 cards to each player and place th reminder of the deck face down on the table Players draw a card from the deck either from the face down pile of the face up discard pile and then discard a card. The object is to lay down the 6 map cards showing a complete route from San Francisco to Shanghai. The first 3 cars of the lay down must be done together. The other 3 can be laid down one at a time if so desired, After getting the 6 map cards down the next objective is to get consecutive route card in hand an play the down 3 cards together saying I am getting off in Rome which means that you laid down Paris, Geneva and Rome cards and then discarded the other card in your hand scoring the total value of the cars, in this case 90 (25 for Paris,30 for Geneva and 35 for Rome, so the further east you travel the more points you will score. Completing a flight before an opponent has laid down his map cards gets you a 100 point bonus. When playing partnerships, you can play on your partners cards until one map of 6 consecutive cards is completed and then either partner can ask “Would you like to get off in Bombay or some other stop depending on cards held to which your partner must answer yes or no, in which case the one asking is bound by the response of his partner. However one partner may simply say we are getting of in Paris and then lay down the required cards. Scorekeeper then records the score at the end of each turn. First team to 500 or 100 wins the game

name: Golden Eagle Air Combat Game
description:
A simple "action" game for two players. Each player controls a WWI plastic biplane via a control rod mechanism. The control rods cause the biplanes to fly circles in opposite directions. It appears that players attempt to unseat each others planes from the control rods, socring points when doing so.

The game features two biplanes molded in red and yellow, a cardboard playing surface with a WWI "Battlefield" printed on it, two plastic "tents" which serve as the base for the plane/control rod mechanism, scoring tracks and markers, control rods and decals.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Aviation / Flight, World War I

name: Jabba-Dabba-Dû!
description:
Game description from the publisher:

In those far-off days when people had already ceased to live on the trees, but did not yet know how to make cars, the main occupation of men was hunting. Neither mighty mammoth, nor nosy ground squirrel – indeed, not any animal could escape the watchful eyes of experienced hunters.

In Jabba-Dabba-Dû!, you'll become the chief hunter of a tribe and go to the hunting grounds as the head of the mighty men. Get the most thick and tasty mammoth, and bring it to your women. But beware as your tribe in not the only one on these plains – and these frail parodies of men consider themselves hunters, too! Prove that it's not true! Leave them behind in pursuit of the prey!

The players are fighting over 5 hunting locations. Each turn, you select two cards, playing them face down until they are revealed to the group. The cards are the 5 hunting locations while the 6th card is another caveman hunter, allowing you to double up at that location. The cards are revealed and you transfer your cavemen figures to the marker. Each turn there is a winner at the hunting ground based on the highest number of cavemen there. The winner gets the highest number of victory points, which varies from hunting location to hunting location. The player with the most points wins!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Augsburg-Quiz
description: Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Augsburg. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Ísland-opoly
description:
Ísland-opoly is a licenced Monopoly clone which theme is unsurprisingly Iceland. The properties are famous landmarks, tourist attractions, building and so on.

From the publisher:
How do we make a board game about the most fun country in the world?
It's impossible to put all the great places of Iceland in one board game so we have chosen fun places and landmarks all over the country. We start in the Hvalfjörður and travel all around the country that keeps surprising us with natural disasters and unexpected happenings.

How do you play Ísland-opoly?
You can buy famous places or landmarks all around the country, up the rent by buying houses and upgrade them to hotels. Sounds easy? We'll figure it out! Traffic jam, radar guns and the police can make it harder for us, but that's just more fun!

You pick a fun pawn and go to the starting place, perhaps you'll become the richest person in Iceland... or just stuck in a traffic jam because of the ash cloud!

Get ready for the game! This is our country... and it's your turn!
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company, Sena ehf.

name: Glory of the Three Kingdoms: Guandu Core Set
description:
Glory of the Three Kingdoms is a living deck-building game (LDBG) in which each player takes a role leading an allegiance in the Three Kingdoms period and battles for total victory or for victory points.

As in most deck-building games, player acquire additional cards to add to their decks. In GOTK, player may acquire cards depicting heroes, military, strategy, items, etc., and some cards provide victory points for endgame scoring. Unlike other games of this type, GOTK has a battle phase during which each player secretly deploys military cards (foot soldiers, pikemen, calvary and archers) and battles for Glory. The victor takes a glory token from the defeated player and a free card in the neutral zone. The victor may also capture and recruit the defeated general – or have him beheaded.

When two out of four card decks are depleted, the game ends and the player with the most victory points wins. However, if one allegiance acquired six or more Tiger Tally or all of opponent's glory tokens, the game ends immediately and the allegiance wins.

The first battle theme of GOTK is Guandu, the first major battle in the Three Kingdoms period. The Guandu Core Set, a two-player game, comes with Cao Cao and Yuan Shao allegiances. Lu Bu and Liu Bei allegiances will be available in a future three- and four-player expansion.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Sixx
description:
Sixx is a quick game with Magical pyramids (18 pyramids of 6 colors and 3 sizes).

The goal of the game is to create out of these pyramids your secret pattern you have on your goal-card.

Sixx is a simplified version of Pyramideto game played with six cards only instead of 36. When children master the Sixx game, they can easily switch to Pyramideto.

To buy: http://mwe.cz/cart/index.php?route=product/product&;product_id=73
Rules: http://www.mwe.cz/images/gettingstartedwithpyramids.pdf

name: Über Stock und Stein
description:
From the box:
"Not only speed counts at the steeple-chase, it mainly demands skills. Only the one who jumps over the fences safely and manages to sidestep the other obstacles is the winner. A game of skills for 2-4 players where the horse tokens have to be flipped through the show jumping course."

A steeple-chase course is created using the 2 pieces of string supplied. 5 high obstacles, on bases, are placed at regular intervals around the course. 10 ground obstacles are arranged between these. 16 horse show tokens are placed in the middle of the course and the horse figure to the side. This is the starting point.

Each player takes 1 small and one large coloured horse token (with horse sticker on) and placing the large token on the supplied piece of felt, uses the small token to try and flick his horse around the course, following the flicking rules laid out. As soon as you successfully complete the course you may take a horse shoe token from the middle. First player to collect 3 horse shoe tokens is the winner.

Nice components. Neat, portable game.

name: Armored Knights North Africa: Operation Crusader
description:
The British offensive to relieve Tobruk / November 18 - December 8, 1941

Armored Knights North Afrika - Operation Crusader pits the numerically inferior but tactically superior Axis forces of Rommel against the British forces trying to open a route to Tobruk and free the trapped garrison there. The game provides a framework for Operational level combat that highlights the interaction between the various combined arms elements present. The game system uses a variable strength table that players use to determine how much benefit they get from the various different combat multiplying forces. Engineers, Anti-Tank, Anti-Aircraft, Recon, Close Air Support, and Artillery all work together to enhance you chances of success. And sometimes they don't do it right and don't work as well together as we would like. This creates a great deal of excitement in the battle and makes you think twice.

The battle for Tobruk started on 18 November 1941 with the British moving 3 Armoured Brigades and a host of Infantry Divisions toward the port and perimeter. Some were fast cruiser tanks and others were faster American built Stuart tanks. The British would get a jump on the Germans and Rommel would be slow to realize there was a major offensive underway. There would be a number of major engagements to include two battles for the Sidi Rezegh Airfield, one for Bir El Gubi, where the Italians turned in a good account of themselves, and Rommel's famous Dash to the Wire. His dash was a failure, but he recovered in time to fight successful second battle for Sidi Rezegh.

All units modeled as battalions, companies/batteries.
Hexes represent approximately 2km of terrain.
Each turn represents 2 hours of ff daylight or 2-4 hours of night.

This game comes with:
• Armored Knights North Afrika Rules
•(5) 11x17 Scenario Cards
• Numerous Player Aides and Examples
• Game Turn Record Track
• (16) 11 x 17 Full Color map sections
• (4) Full Color Order of Battle Charts
• Very Sturdy box
• Approximately 1200 double sided unit counters and markers

(from box and publisher's website)

name: Sahara Search
description:
Players are archaeologists digging for treasures in the desert, working together to collect as many valuable treasures as possible.

A Desert Dig area is formed in the center of the table by creating a tableau of face-down cards in 4 rows of 6 overlapping cards (similar to a solitaire set-up). Only the top card of each row is available for play action. Players are then dealt a hand of action cards that allow them to move cards in the tableau, search the dig field, dig in one column of the field, or load cards onto the camel train (in a separate area). "No Trespassing" cards will block digging in a particular column and force a player to play a (limited quantity) "Deal" card in order to access any valuable treasure locked above that card.

When the camel train contains 15 treasures, the game ends and the team of archaeologists determines the value of the treasures collected. As this is a cooperative game, the goal is to obtain the greatest possible treasure score as a team (a perfect game being a score of 115).
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Isoroku's War 1941-1943
description:
Campaign level wargame for Early half of World War 2 Pacific Theater.
The game map covers from Ceylon to Hawaii. The game not include Chinese front.
Each unit represent one capital ship or one battle ship and its escorts, land aircraft or land unit.

Players control either Japanese Navy or Allied Navy. Players manage movement and combat. Japanese player also manage naval fuel.
The game map divide to two type of positions, points and areas. The point represent port or aircraft base. The area represent sea between points. The aircraft carrier can move and attack both points and areas. Other units can only move to points and can only attack to points, but surface fleet is require for conquer of points.

Winner determined by victory point. Each important points has a random victory point chit. Allied player can examine those chits at any time. Japanese player can not examine until occupied by Japanese force.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Cha-Ching
description:
8 Card Rummy with Dice & Money!

Cha-Ching gives you the rush of rummy with a blend of dice for added SPICE! Players attempt to build an eight card hand to equal the sum of the house number rolled each round from various cards values. But players can cha-change things up mid play with CHACHING! Cards that allow you to re-roll the dice or trade hands with another player but don’t get caught trying to change things up before someone goes out each round.

name: Papillon
description:
Papillon tries to flee the Devil’s Island, to do that the piece must be moved off board. The other player tries to catch Papillon. Each piece can move one step per turn. If a piece is enclosed by two opposing pieces, it is taken off the board, but not if a piece actively moves between two pieces. If Papillon is taken off, the game ends.
In a variant the pieces can move any distance and Papillon must be enclosed on four sides.

Similar to Ard Ri, except on a 9x9 board.

name: Micro FUBAR
description:
From the publisher's website:

"A lot of people started asking if we could produce a version of FUBAR suitable for the increasingly popular 6mm scale. Here is the development draft of what we have done so far."

This can help FUBAR players to tailor their games from the 25/28mm generic base FUBAR to a more wide 6mm battlefield. With the inclusion of some rules for vehicles, this ruleset does not differ a lot from the basic one. It is obviously a one page ruleset in the FUBAR philosophy.

name: Barons of Tea
description:
Barons of Tea is a game for 2-6 players ages 8+. Put on your fancy hat, hop on your boat and get ready for adventures on the high seas!
The British Empire spans across the entire globe and the empire is thirsty. With Barons of Tea you get to step into the shoes of a tea merchant. With 300 pounds of silver in hand and a ship to your name you set off across the sea in a race with other players to be the first to amass 3,000 pounds of silver.
The game play is focused around a commission system, where players race to ports across Africa, India, China and Japan so that they can be the first ones back and receive the highest sale price. The game features seven unique teas, including two special varieties, grown in land-locked regions.

In Barons of Tea there are many different events that can change your fortunes for good or for ill. Each time an odd number is rolled a new event card is drawn. These can bring both good and bad tidings, from finding treasure to finding a dreadful sea beast.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Monopoly: Best Buy Edition
description: A promotional Monopoly edition given to Best Buy MVPs (according to the back of the box). Features Best Buy money, yellow houses and black hotels, store departments instead of properties, and Best Buy Mascot and Shrink Stomper cards.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Star Wheel
description:
An expansion of Gnostica, adding materials from the astrological game Star Encounters. Homemade components and a regular d12 easily substitute for the Star Encounters properties.

Player tokens move around a zodiac board during Gnostica, and enhance different card powers based on the player's position in the zodiac. Additionally, players have the ability to roll for a match which will award them extra card draws.

name: Sound It! Found It!
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Take a card and get other players to guess what's on it by imitating the sound it makes! AH-CHOOO! CUCK-OO! VROOOM! Those are just the easy ones...but guessing the sound is only half the fun. Once the sound is identified, the source of that sound must be quickly found amid one of the eight illustrated scenes that are filled with action and surprises!

SOUND IT! FOUND IT! is a fun & completely new patent-pending "2-in-1" board game in which two compelling play patterns are brought together for one amazing game! Building off the popularity of the guessing game format, Sound It! Found It! challenges players to guess the picture on the game card by listening to the (sometimes crazy) sounds that other players make. Once players guess what's on the cards, they then must race to find that object on one of eight scene boards.

With 96 cards and eight giant scene boards, each drawn in a hilariously original style, Sound It! Found It! combines visual hilarity with the unique twist of guessing sounds, offering hours of laugh-out-loud fun for the whole family.

name: Rikka no hana
description:
User summary:

The goal of the game is to form a party, venture into the ice forest to find the Snow Flower, that will cure the king's disease.

The game is split into two parts; in the first the players will recruit their party using a drafting mechanism, and in the second, they will compete to be the first to find the mysterious flower. Each character has special values in physical and magical attack power. During the monster fighting, the player who is last will draw and deal monster cards to all players. Each player then selects if they want to fight the monster they have, or rest. If the group has higher attack than the monster's defence, it's defeated, and the player go deeper into the forest. Players can also use the special abilities of the characters in order to increase their attack power.

The first player to defeat the final boss wins the game.

name: BrainBox: London
description:
Did you know that Marble Arch was moved from outside Buckingham Palace in 1851? And that Big Ben is the largest four-faced chiming clock in the world? BrainBox London is crammed full of interesting facts and figures about the UK’s capital city. An added bonus is that the cards can be linked together to form a large map of London.

The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner. This simple concept can be played by all ages and in large groups as well as a 1 person game.

Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material and designed in the UK, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!

name: Orionus
description:
Simple, two-phase science-fiction game for 2-4 players, loosely based on Die Götter aus dem All comic series.

The first phase is a race to planet Orionus. Every player (up to two on each of the "rocket" and "ufo" sides) starts with six starships, and rolls a die to move, although one can choose which of the ships to move during their turn. Either shorter and harder or longer and easier route can be chosen. The ships can be destroyed by comets, monsters, or just crash during landing on the planet.

Only the ships that survived the race can take part in the second phase, played on a separate board that illustrates the surface of Orionus. This phase is more tactical, played "rockets" vs. "ufos", and the goal is to take over opponents' starting docs. It is possible to destroy enemy's ships by "landing" on them. The winner of the game is the person that will lock the most ships in opponents' starting docs.

name: Unit Organizations of World War II
description:
The purpose of this book is to present a Table of Organization & Equipment (TO&E) for several basic ground combat units found in most armies that directly participated in World War II

Each TO&E Chart identifies division to platoon sized units that can be easily duplicated in any scale.

Each of the units can be duplicated on a 1-on-1 ratio where an actual 42 man platoon is represented by 42 scale men with appropriate equipment and weapons

name: Shuggy Hall Brawl
description:
One-on-one fight game in a Shuggy Hall, in the world of Judge Dredd. A Shuggy Hall is a futuristic amusement arcade as described in the comic 2000 A.D. Players are various characters, all trying to be top dog in the fight.

Players choose actions - hit someoine very hard, throw a glass of beer at someone, that sort of thing. Dice decide how successful you were in your choice and, if successful, the affect it has on the recipient.

The game was included in Warlock (Issue 11 - Aug/Sep 1986).
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Square Grid

name: Sixth Tackle
description:
A statistical game based on Rugby League. (For those that don't know, at the end of six tackles possession of the ball passes to the opposing side, which then has six tackles to try to advance up the field).

In the designer's familiar style, teams are rated based on their performances in recent years. Various charts are used as dice rolls are compared to the action in that turn.

The original Lambourne Games edition was published in 1988. The later version licensed to Owzat Games features team cards for the 1999 English domestic competition.

An expansion based on the 2003 Australian National Rugby League competition is also available.

name: Adventure 7: The Rescue of Princess Millandriell (fan expansion for HeroQuest)
description:
This adventure has a very simple story line. So to make it more interesting we started the Heroes from beginning stats and built them up as the story moved along. The Oger and Giant Wolf really added a lot of excitment to the game so they were used a lot. We hope that you will have as much fun with this adventure as we did creating it.
The pages for this adventure are available to download at "Dragonkingdoms.co.uk" and yahoo's group site "HeroQuest-Adventures" for free. You do need to join the group to access the file's section where they are stored. The photo section of this site will allow you to read the story and look at the maps to see if this game is something you would like to play. Your adventure awaits!
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Fantasy, Miniatures

name: Adventure 8: The Horror Inside the Ancient Halls of Sunca (fan expansion for HeroQuest)
description:
This Adventure takes place right after the end of The Frozen Horror, so we let the Heroes keep all that they had collected from the expansion games. My Heroes really liked having the extra mercenaries, so we made them a permanent part of the team. This changed things. As Zargon I used more monsters with stronger powers, The Yeti and War Bear are great monsters. This Adventure moves along quickly and I'm sure that you are going to have a lot of fun playing it.
The pages for this adventure are available to download at "Dragonkingdoms.co.uk" and yahoo's group site "HeroQuest-Adventures" for free. You do need to join the group to access the file's section where they are stored. The photo section of this site will allow you to read the story and look at the maps to see if this game is something you would like to play. Your adventure awaits!
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Fantasy, Miniatures

name: ASH Poker (Auction Stud-Hold'em)
description:
ASH Poker, which gets its name from being a fusion of Stud and Hold'em Poker. It is a game in the poker family, which adds auctioning off draw cards so players may fill and improve their hands. It borrows the dealer button, and large and small blinds from Texas Hold'em and also each player having their own set of cards from Stud Poker.

In the game, after the big and small blinds are set, and cards are dealt, there is a round of betting. After this, draw cards are auctioned off, with money paid to obtain draw cards put in the pot. After this, another round of betting occurs. High hand takes the pot, or high hands split the pot.

The game has a number of variants that vary the number of draw cards and rounds of draw cards per hand, and also determine whether or not there are limits on bids and bets.

name: GourmetSmarts
description:
From the manufacturer:

Just how much of a Foodie are you? Test your skill and knowledge with this fun and educational game, Gourmet Smarts. Complete with 100 questions, a guide and a scorepad, this is a great item for anyone that's interested in cooking, entertaining or just having fun. Comes in a sturdy flip top box.

name: Bluffjack
description:
Bluffjack is a hybrid of poker and blackjack. It borrows the bluffing and betting against other players from poker, and the trying to get close to 21 without going over from Blackjack (21).

In the game, players are dealt one card face down, and one card face up, and players wager. Then players get cards, and try to get close to 21. After this players will engage in another round of betting.

Bluffjack offers the chance for players to win if a player went over 21 and everyone else folded. However, if all players remaining players went over 21, everyone loses, and their best are set aside.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Push Your Luck

name: Pocket Quiz: Shakespeare
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

All the questions are all about famous English poet William Shakespeare.

name: Checker Can: Das Checker Quiz
description:
Game description from the publisher:

What's in goat poop? Why do shoes stink? And what makes a hot air balloon rise? These and 1,197 other multiple-choice questions await you in Checker Can: Das Checker Quiz, based on the television show of the same name. For each correct answer, you advance on the scoring track, and the first player to lap the track wins.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Pocket Quiz Logik-Rätsel
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The ultimate knowledge-check! Test your skills on the subject of logic puzzles! Confusing and challenging puzzles to think about.

SOlve the puzzle first and get the card.
Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Pocket Quiz Teekesselchen
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 100 word puzzles. The backside of each card contains meanigs of the words and additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

In this game there are words to solve what have multiple meanings.

name: The People vs. O.J. Simpson Trivia Game
description:
Object of the Game: As an investigator, your job is leave your color start position and make your way, by answering questions, to the six locations on the map, and return to your position before your opponents do.

Possibly a prototype of a game that was to be sold and money raised was to be used for OJ Simpson's defense. The game may have been banned and/or rejected and never mass produced.

name: Kiyomori Gunki: Hogen and Heiji Rebellion
description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #12.

Operational level wargame on Hogen and Heiji rebellions during Japanese Heian period.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hōgen_Rebellion
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heiji_Rebellion
This game include two scenarios for each rebellion and two type campaigns for combined rebellions.
A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).
Kiyomori is a famous Heian period person.

The game map covers city of Kyoto for movement and combat. It also includes main part of Japan for reinforcement march.
Each unit represents a lord (daimyo) or samurai warriors (retainers). All units has a battle rating and belong to one of the four clans. The clan is affect for unit activation and special ability. Certain lords (daimyo) have also special abilities.

Players control one side of each rebellion. Most side contains more than one clan.
Each turn players determine active clan by die roll. Activated unit are flipped down at end of their activation. So each unit can only activate once per turn, but Fujiwara clan's special ability allows them to reactivate flip down units.

Winner is determined by several victory condition per scenario. For example, elimination of highest lord, occupation of important areas, etc.

name: Terapia
description:
Terapia

It is composed of a quad-fold board, the rules are printed on the back side of the box, 6 pawns (black, orange, red, blue, green, yellow) and 600 question cards. Themed on medical science, all questions are about medical (but not psychological) affairs.

The game goal is to be the first to move your pawn along the complete circle on the board from your starting color rectangle to the same position. There is a single pile of cards in the center of the board. Rectangles and cards are identified with 3, 2 or 1 dots. The player at your right asks you the question on the upper card of the pile. You must give right answer to the card question to be able to advance a single rectangle or 3 or 2 if dots stated in your actual position match the current question card dots. That has a maximum of three consecutive advances. Then the turn goes to the player at your right. If you fail a question the pawn moved is the one belonging to the player who asked the question.

name: Dingsda
description:
Objective: score most winning points with your team after 5 rounds
- acting by turn -
active player tries to explain a term by pantomime within 2 minutes - no talking/drawing/writing allowed;
if successful (somtimes with deduction due to allowed prodedures) there will be a bonus question;

content: 396 cards - splitted into 9 sections, 2 boards "dactylology", 1 card case, Kartenhülle, 1 notepad, rules.
remarks: compareable with 'body talks'

The board game is based on the popular 1985-2000 and 2001-2002 German game show of the same name, for which in turn was adapted from the short-lived 1982-83 American Game Show Child's Play.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Tutatis
description:
