Players play cards before them to form groups; these must be of rising ranks. These groups are then used to fight to win the 8–10 cards representing political power. Each turn, players choose a political role that will influence this battle, and each player also has a hidden role that he should try to keep secret throughout the game.

Game ends when all policital influence cards have been taken, at which point the player with most such cards, added to that the played cards of his hidden colour, wins the game.

name: Market Day
description:
Game from 'The Children's Book of Games, Puzzles and Pastimes.

Simple roll and move game

A game for two played with a dice and two counters. Throw a six to begin. One starts from Elm Farm and the other from Hill Farm and the first to reach the Cattle Pen, obeying the instructions on the way, is the winner.

name: Play Win
description: Play Win is a predatory game. Move your pieces toward opposing pieces along empty lines up to one fewer cell as you have pieces in play. Maximally capture opposing pieces by a series of short bent leaps. Win by capturing or immobilizing all opposing pieces. "It's called Play Win because you play it, and somebody wins!"
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Point to Point Movement

name: Wild Cards: For the Love of Dogs
description: Here's a game for dog lovers of all ages! Boost children's IQ with memory and matching games while teaching them about caring for the family pet. Each of the 36 playing cards has fascinating facts about dogs and introduces children to 18 family-friendly breeds. The companion book is packed with more facts.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational

name: Kruissom
description: A Scrabble variant with numbers. The board consists of squares, some of which have numbers printed on them. When placing a number with one or more your digit tiles, it must be divisible by all numbers that it covers (or by five if it covers none). You then score the sum of the individual digits.

name: Tähekabe
description:
"Letter-checkers" in English

At start the 16 letter-tiles are laid on the table to 4x4 grid.
Each player gets 4 game-pieces and in his turn player must form a word moving his pieces from square to square acquiring letters for that word.

Objective is to reach to last row of opposite side with all four game-pieces first.

name: Tooth & Nail: Domination
description:
Tooth & Nail: Domination is a revamped, Tooth & Nail: Factions-themed edition of Bhazum.

The game begins with players drafting the 64 character cards to form two 32 card decks, one for each player. During the player's turn, the player gains actions to play Character cards into his district. Each character belongs to one of the four cliques, and many have special abilities, called Traits, that occur when they are placed into a district from a player's hand. Additionally, at the end of a player's turn, the player will place a card from his hand face down on one of the council cards. When a Character with the Ksari trait is played in a district, the corresponding Clique Council is convened, and the player with the highest value of face down cards wins the support of the convened council.

Players score points for the Characters in their districts, as well as points for the Council support they have received.

name: Dream Buck
description:
Deer Hunting Card Game

From the back of box:
Every hunter dreams of stalking down that once-in-a-lifetime buck - the perfect 12 pointer, the 200 pounder or maybe even a record size rack. Finally, there's an exciting card game that lets you experience the thrill of deer hunting anytime, anywhere. You'll be amazed at how closely the playing strategy and results simulate an actual hunt.

--

Players draw an initial hand of 5 cards, trying to acquire enough Buck Cards with the minimum number of total "points" needed to "shoot" the deer with a Shot Card. Along the way players will draw Problem Cards such as "other hunter in area" or "major wind" preventing one from taking a "shot". Remedy Cards will be played to get rid of Problem Cards. After everyone bags a buck or after a set number of times through the deck (days of the hunting season), whichever comes first, the player with the largest buck wins.

Each card has multiple sets of values on it that are used in various phases of the "hunt".

name: Zombie Attack on Meeple Island
description:
Life was good on Meeple Island: multiracial harmony, farming, raising animeeples, building wooden roads, more farming. Then someone discovered the Necromeeple's Cave and everything changed. Now meeples are pitted against meeples in a battle for necromantic dominance.

In Zombie Attack on Meeple Island you play a tribe of colored meeples forced to adapt when the dead begin to rise all over their island. Do you cooperate with your fellow meeple tribes or don the black mantle of the necromeeple and claim power over life and death for yourself?

This card game answers the age old question: which gaming genre will reign supreme, Euro or Ameritrash? Find out the answer over 10 rounds of simultaneous card play each followed by a bidding phase for control of the necromeeple. The cards include many of your favorite game mechanics, zombie tactics and a few surprises. Do you bide your time in a euro-optimization holding pattern or go for the jugular with a necromeeple power play and brain buffet?

The winner is the player who ends the game with the most meeple survivors or the necromeeple player if zombeeples overrun the island. Special win conditions, meeple and zombeeple upgrades, and AT superweapons ensure that whoever wins, Meeple Island will never be the same.

Got wood for brains?
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Secret Unit Deployment, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game, Trading, Variable Player Powers, Voting, Worker Placement

name: Decathlon
description:
Decathlon is said to be one of the hardest competitions in athletics. In this game, the players are athletes who must perform the 100m sprint, the long jump, the shot put, the high jump, the 400m, the 110m hurdles, the discus throw, the pole vault, the javelin throw and the 1500 meters race. Players will need the ability to run, jump and throw. Balance those three abilities, and win the total competition to become the King of Athletes.

The goal of the game is to collect the VP (Victory Points) on the medal cards. The player who has the most VP when the game ends wins. For each of the 10 events, a player must finish first or second in order to get a medal card.

name: Eestimaa mäng: Seiklusrikas mälumäng
description:
"Estonian Adventure Trivia game"

Players roll the dice, move through the Estonia and answer the trivia questions or do surprise actions in certain places.

Game ends if someone reaches to finish. Player with the most correct answers is the winner.

name: Kalale
description:
This board game bring the players to fishing trip.

Players have cards in hand with different fishes and special cards. In his turn player either move his boat to different fishing place on the game board or change the fishing tool. Then player may play cards.
Different fishes need different places and tools to catch them and they score points.

Game ends if the card deck is exhausted and first player plays his last card. Players add up points from the cards.
Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Manspel
description:
Manspel is a two player game with fairly simple rules.
Each player starts with 12 pieces (men) arranged in opposite corners of the board. The object is to occupy the corner-field of the opponent with one of your own men. Pawns of the opponent are caught by jumping, like in checkers. Certain fields in the corners in the middle of the board may be jumped, but not occupied, excepting of course the one corner-field that must be conquered.

name: Shake'n Play
description:
From the box:
Shake'n Play is an acoustic memory game and consists of 16 nearly identical shakers arranged on an eight-sided board. The 16 shakers make up eight matching pairs, each pair with a distinct sound. The object of the game is to find the matching pairs by trying the sound of one shaker and another in turns.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Music

name: Brake & Win
description:
This is a "Mensch Ärgere Dich Nicht" typ of game. It is played with trucks (as pawns) and with the same rules but has one extra rule that gives it an extra twist.
If you land on specific fields you get one extra token (regenerating brake system). These tokens can be spent in future turns to go extra steps.

This game was given out by REXROTH (a Bosch Group member)

name: Tell Me a Story: Circus Adventures
description:
Brandon Reese’s circus animals inspire action-packed stories of adventure and mishap. Stilt-walking cats might find mischief despite the ringmaster’s best intentions. Will all be put right by the time of the Big Top performance? Only the storyteller knows…

Variations for gameplay exist. The essentials for winning are: build a hand that includes the elements needed for a complete story and then be the first to tell (or present) the completed story.

Deal a starting hand to each player, then trade/discard/draw until a completed story is in hand. First player to place a complete story down and "tell" the story wins!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational

name: Die Lieben Sieben: Auf dem Jahrmarkt
description:
The game board is a sliding lane with six fields, each showing a fun fair attraction. At the end of the field, there are three wooden "tin cans" stacked up.
The active player draws a card and tries to slide the marble slider onto the corresponding field. If successful, s/he gets the card. For two of the same cards, the player gets a free ride chip. If the player flips up the tin can card, s/he has to try to topple the three tin cans to get a free ride; if unsuccessful, the other players can try (in clockwise order).
At the end of the game, the player with most chips is the winner.

name: TriviaNatura
description:
This is a roll-and-move spanish trivia game where players must answer only environmental questions at specific spaces to get progress toward victory, like in Trivial Pursuit. Same gameplay with different and cheaper components.



Un juego español al estilo Trivial Pursuit, pero sólo con preguntas relacionadas con el medio ambiente. Misma mecánica de juego con componentes diferentes, aunque más baratos.

name: Motor Team
description:
A race game of motorbike that you have to ride your team to victory obtaining more points with your team.

Each player has a team of three motorbikes (Yellow, purple, red and green).
The aim of the game is to move all your team to gain the highest score by summing the result of the arrival of the 3 motorbikes.
The movement of each motorbike is done by a wheel with an arrow in the middle, at the turn player spins the arrow on the wheel, that will indicate how many squares move the 3 motorbikes.
The tactic is dodging oil spills, and take the wake of the bike in front of you.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Turno
description:
Turno consists of a hexagonal board divided into 96 triangles, with two players arranging thirty pieces (four cannons, eight bowmen, and three knights each) on their starting positions as marked on the board. Each piece has a red side and a gold side; players pick a color prior to starting and place their pieces with their chosen color facing up.

Players take turns moving. Pieces may be moved to unoccupied adjoining triangles (triangles that share a side, not a point.) After having moved, if an adjoining triangle is occupied with an opponent's piece, a player may announce an attack, which will result in a capture or a kill of that piece. Captured pieces are turned over to match the attacking player's color, killed pieces are removed from the board, never to return. (A captured piece may not be attacked for one turn.) The outcomes of attacks are determined as such:

Kill
knight kills knight
bowman kills bowman
cannon kills cannon

Capture
knight captures bowman
bowman captures cannon
cannon captures knight

Players may prevent attack by moving a piece in danger to a triangle immediately next to a potential attacker. (Pieces must move before attacking.) The winning player captures or kills all of the opponent's pieces. One optional advanced rule is included, allowing knights to move through the small hexagons that cover the points of all the board's triangles.

name: Pulce
description:
A Halma variation for two players.

('Pulce' is the Italian word for 'flea'.)


Game components:


- A wooden board with 7 rows and 7 columns of sockets (a total of 45 holes, no holes in the four board corners).
- 8 black and 8 red pawns.
- 1 yellow pawn (first-player marker)


Game goal:


The objective of the game is to be the first player to get his pieces over to the opposite side of the board.

Set-up:


Two adjacent board sides (containing 10 sockets) are chosen as the destination field for one player's pawns (player A, positions 1b-1f and 2a-6a), while the opposite sides are assigned to the other player (player B, positions 7b-7f and 2g-6g). Players then placed all his pawns as follows: player A, sockets 4e, 4f, 5d, 5e, 5f, 6d, 6e, and 6f; player B, sokets 2b, 2c, 2d, 3, b, 3c, 3d, 4b, and 4c.
The yellow pawn is placed in the central socket (position 4d).


Game rules:


The game is played over three rounds.

On each round:

On player takes the yellow pawn and places it in front of him. He is the initial player of the current round and makes the first move. Game continues with every player moving a pawn alternatively.

During his turn, a player must move a pawn according to the following rules: pawns can be moved to an adjacent free socket or else jump (in any direction) over a pawn of whatever color onto a free socket behind it. The enemy destination sockets can not be used for jumping. Consecutive jumps are also allowed and the jump direction can be changed as desired during a series of consecutive jumps.

Important: the target sockets must be always accessed orthogonally, i.e., moving the pawn from a socket orthogonally adjacent to a destination socket or else jumping over an occupied socket orthogonally adjacent to the landing destination socket.

Pawns that have reach a destination socket cannot move any longer.

Game end and rating:

The round is over when a player has placed all his pawns in his destination sockets. If this player was the starting player, his opponent can make and additional move. Therefore, it is possible that all pawns from both players have reached the corresponding destination fields at the end of the round.

Any player whose pawns are all placed in his destination field receives points according to the distribution of his pawns:

1 point: 5 pawns are on one side of the destination field, 3 pawns on the other side,

2 points: 4 pawns are on each side without symmetrical arrangement,

3 points: 4 pawns are on each side with symmetrical arrangement.

At the end of the third round, whoever wins the most points is the winner.

name: Eins Zwei Drei Käse Hoch
description:
Rules:
Each player chooses a color. Red is for Edam cheese, yellow for Gouda. The 18 pieces are placed on the 18 circles in the board according to their color. A coin/die is tossed to decide who goes first. The aim of the game is to stack three cheeses in your color on top of each other.
Each player in turn moves a disk in his color one space in any direction (orthogonally or diagonally). Disks can either be moved onto an adjacent empty space, stacked on a disk of whatever color, or removed from the top of a stack and moved one space further (only the top disk on a stack can be moved). A lone disk cannot be moved onto an empty space. A player must move a disk when his turn.

The winner is the first to stack three disks of his color on top of each other, or to block the opposing player so that he can no longer move on the board.

name: Die Maulwurfshöhle
description:
Die Maulwurfshöhle (The mole cave)

Each player receives 9 mole tiles and 2 busy tiles in his color.

Rules:

The starting player, determined using whatever method the players agree, starts the turn and everyone take each round clockwise. The starting configuration for four players is as follows: each player selects one board corner and places his nine mole tiles in the square at that corner and the eight squares on the board sides closer to that corner, four tiles on each side of the corner tile. For two players: opposite corners are occupied. For three players: three corners are occupied.

During a player's turn a tile must be moved. The possible moves are:

a) any tile can be moved in all directions (diagonal or orthogonal) to an adjacent empty space but not to a square with a mole cave symbol or with a 'busy' tile on it.

b) Push: a tile is moved onto an occupied square, pushing the original tile in the direction of movement as well as all tiles that were continuously connected to the original tile in the line of movement. If a tile is pushed into a mole cave, it stays there until it is pushed out. It cannot move out on its own. Exception: pushing is not possible if it results in a tile going off the board or else a 'busy' tile would be moved.

When a tile lands in a tunnel entrance, the player must dig immediately, i.e., the token must be placed to any other free tunnel entrance. If a tile is passively pushed to a tunnel entrance, nothing happens during this turn; but if the tile still stands on a tunnel entrance or was pushed on it and it is the player's turn, this must dig immediately.

A player who has occupied all four squares orthogonally adjacent to a mole cave must place a 'busy' tile there; this tile can no longer be moved, but the four mole tiles are operational beginning the next turn. If a 'busy' tile is placed on a mole cave where there's already a mole tile of whichever color, this tile is removed from the board.

The winner is the first player to place his two 'busy' tiles on two mole caves.

name: Malifaux: The Depleted
description:
The Depleted are a group of minions for the Neverborn. They are mean to complement the Dark Debts crew.

From the Malifaux Tactica wiki page:
The Depleted are basically cheap targets for the Hungering Darknesses.....hunger for Brilliance. He heals more with them, but they take more damage, and they are drawn to models with the Brilliance trait. They're insignificant, unless within LOS of the hungering darkness.

The Depleted are the empty living shells of people who have been using Brilliance for too long, as such they are not combat monsters. They have a below average Cb value with a lower-end damage spread. These low stats can be slightly deceiving however, because the Depleted get a positive flip to damage against models with Brilliance and any model they wound receives one burning token, upping their damage potential a decent amount. This has some possible synergies with Iggy, the only other Neverborn minion who currently uses burning tokens and a Ht 1 Woe who can be taken in a Ten Thunders crew with Lynch.

Reduced to Cinders is a defense trigger with great offensive potential. When killed in melee with this trigger up, the Depleted explodes like a mini-Papa Loco, giving all models within 2" 2 Dg and Brilliance. One important thing to note about this is that the depleted are Hard to Kill - This means you know when they're on one wound, and when they will be killed, so you will know exactly when to cheat in a crow (Preferably a low one), to trigger this.

The Depleted form the throw away tarpits and objective grabbers of Lynch's crew.

They can be startlingly fast once buffed up, capable of pushing 5" towards a model with brilliance, then double walking another 10" (or 12" with The Source up), for a grand total of 15"-17" of movement in a turn, which ignores severe terrain. Although they are Insignificant on their own, this goes away when they have LoS to the Hungering Darkness. When given Reactivate by the Hungering Darkness, these guys can (1) interact with objectives up to 20"-22" away in a single turn, and the loss of such a cheap minion can be an acceptable trade for those final victory points. The push action also allows them to easily escape combat, making them very hard to lock in place.

Reduced to Cinders is an extremely useful way to get the Hungering Darkness into position. The Depleted gets thrown up into the enemy lines and dies, exploding for damage and handing out Brilliance. At the same time the Hungering Darkness comes into play and can activate and attack with all of the Brilliance buffs already in effect. This can only be triggered by enemy attacks.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Modern Day Gladiators: Wrestling Game
description:
Modern Day Gladiators (MDG) is a pro wrestling-themed game that brings many of the aspects of the wrestling world to bear in one, simple game mechanic. Using a normal deck of playing cards (and a 12-sided dice if you prefer to roll dice instead of flip cards), with a few simple charts that also follow the same mechanic, you can play out a myriad of matches where wrestler's do all the moves you see on TV.
With MDG, you can play solo - booking matches, running segments and interviews, & playing out the matches with run-ins from other wrestlers (or not) - all of which go into making a wrestling show. The only difference? You won't know how this script is going to play out. Those matches and segments will affect the company you are trying to run, growing it into a global phenomen or watching it crumble before your eyes.
Of course, you can also play in a group adding one, very important element - each person takes the role (or several roles) of a wrestler. Narrate a segment or cut a promo on your opponent and it will impact the mechanics of the game and your wrestler’s options in the ring. And once the bell rings, not only does the mechanics allow you to choose what moves your wrestler does, but it gives you a beginning set of tactics drawn from the real-life wrestling world, tactics to attempt (each with their own advantages and disadvantages). As for those not directly involved in the match, they'll be the crowd and impact the match in a very real way.
This FULL RULEBOOK adds several different match-types (cage, extreme, tag, triangle, battle royal). In addition, the advanced rules continue adding depth by introducing aspects to the game mechanic that turn up the realism such as: Counter ability, Weight & Height, Manager's impact, Intimidation, Stamina (fatigue, injury, tag team fatigue, wearing an opponent down, wrestling with injuries), blood, referees that impact the match, wrestler's individual advantages & disadvantages, how to make a wrestler and let him grow into an Icon of the wrestling world as well as a world for that wrestler to exist - including 21 original, fully illustrated wrestlers existing within a backdrop as wide-open as your imagination. This world is constantly growing with at least 4 expansions already planned within the game's 1st year.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Role Playing

name: Younglings Penny Arcade Promo Character
description: A 2011 PAX promo character card for the Penny Arcade deck building games. This adds a new playable character to select from. The Younglings always go first, and start with 5 quarters and 7 tubes, but on the first turn get a temporary additional 2 tokens and 2 power.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Triangle Mountain
description:
User summary

A kid-friendly multiplayer abstract game in which all players try to get rid of as many tiles on hand.

All players get a random starting hand of triangular tiles. There are three types of tiles: racoon dog tiles (that point upwards), fox tiles (that point downwards) and triangle tiles (that can point either way). All tiles exist in four colours. Players take turns placing the tiles to form a mountain built by triangles, but there are placement restrictions, such as tiles must always face the same direction (raccoon dogs must always point upwards and fox tiles always downwards), fox tiles and inverted triangles can only be placed in between two other tiles and must share a colour with one of them, and so on.

As soon as a player can't place any of the tiles he has in hand, he is out of the game and gets penalty points depending on what tiles he has left. Round ends when all players are out of the game, and the game is played as many rounds as there are players.

name: Cassette Juego: Carrera de Bolidos
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portatile boardgames that were created in spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other southamerican countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

Carrera de Bolidos (Formula 1 race) was nicknamed Formula 1 and was about racing with cars in a circuit, were the spin number tell you what happens if you accelerate, brake or if you need to stop for fuel. Great for the Formula 1 Enthusiast.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: American Civil War Rules for an Army Level wargame with 2mm or 6mm miniatures
description:
ACW does not use a turn sequence. It has a “variable length bound” instead of fixed turns.
ACW uses an order system. Each command -brigade, division and corps - operates under orders. Orders should contain reference to a ground feature or specific enemy force. They may not be conditional or contain the word “if”.
A Change of Situation (COS) may be enemy forces appear, you are fired upon, you receive a message etc. COS happen at every level, so a COS for a brigade is also a COS for every higher level formation. The rules list 13 kinds of COS and provide for each a set of possible responses. Responses include sending a message, taking defensive action, etc.
Movement is simultaneous. There is no “movement phase.” Players simply begin acting on orders until a COS occurs.

This is a very interesting set of rules. There are major “gray areas” but I guess given the nature of the rules that is to be expected. They are clearly meant to be more of a skeleton. For example, they do not spell out if you remove strips or just track casualties on a roster. They refer to many events but do not spell out how they are to be handled - that is left up to the ruling of an umpire or to be worked out between the players.

These are especially tempting for playing big battles in small spaces. At 22 cm to the mile, Gettysburg would fit on a 6x6 table!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Eye Know: 100 Card Booster Pack #1
description: Eye Know: 100 Card Booster Pack #1 consists of 100 new image trivia cards for Eye Know, each with three trivia questions on the back relating to the subject depicted on the card.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Set Collection

name: BABEL
description:
User summary

A Japanese indie card game with the Tower of Babel theme.

Using card drafting, players select cards from hand and reveal simultaneously. These cards are used to build a personal tower. Each round, cards are drawn to see where and how God's wrath is directed, which may destroy the player's towers unless they build carefully.

The game ends when one player managed to build the 6th floor, at which point the highest valued tower wins (1 point per building block, and 1 per floor)

name: Rolling for Amusement
description:
There is only one thing greater than going to an amusement park—Building One! You have a great opportunity to not only build a grand park, but to build the greatest collection of amusement centers in the world! But, be aware that there is competition. There are others who want to do the same and they will try to undermine your efforts. So get ready for the ride of your life. Grab a handful of dice and Roll for Amusement!

Rolling for Amusement is a push your luck dice and card game with a unique "take that" element! Your goal is to build the greatest collection of amusement parks that the world has ever seen. If you manage your cards right, undermine your opponents at the correct time, and make a rise-to-your-feet dice roll, you just might be the owner of the greatest amusement parks on the planet!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck

name: Top Hat
description:
TOP HAT is a resource management and market trading game where each player controls a Top Hat making company through 2 Years (8 rounds) of manufacturing and selling top hats. The in-game economy being 100% player driven, much of the strategy involved consists of being the player who can control and predict the market price of the different manufacturing goods.

From buying of the manufacturing goods to selling the finished product, the players control everything that was involved in manufacturing hats in the 1850’s. Market fluctuations are powerful tools for those who know how to wield them and clever use of capital will triumph over rigid business plans.

Will you become a household name in men’s fashion, or another bankrupt company soon forgotten by history?
categories: Bluffing, Economic, Industry / Manufacturing, Print & Play

name: Battle of Cannae
description:
Wargame with some abstract elements. The games simulates a battle between armies consisting only of infantry and cavalry. The game mechanics simulate the tactical characteristics of the Punic Wars, but it's possible to extend them to any battle where the role of artillery is null or negligible (as for instances many medieval battles). It's possible to play the light edition on a normal chessboard, using ordinary chess pieces and checkers.

Each player can move 1 infantry, 1 cavalry or both (1 infantry and 1 cavalry). Infantries can be used to "push" other pieces, triggering the shift of an entire group. Cavalries are used to charge the enemy's infantry (if they results isolated after a push movement).

The first player that manages to eliminate all opponent's infantry wins the game.

The Light Edition is completely free: to play "Battle of Cannae - Light Edition" players need just an ordinary chess/checkers set and the games rules.

name: King Bling
description:
King Bling is a card game where you predict your possible number of tricks and you will be rewarded with points if correct. Action cards offer additional possibilities. The rules are easy to learn. With luck and strategy, you become the King of Cards.

Each round you will be dealt a different number of cards. Before play, you announce how many tricks you will take until all cards are played (one for each trick, highest card will win). After each round you earn points but only if all announced tricks were successful. If there was any difference you will get only minus points. There are 4 special cards like the thief, the magician, the fortune teller and the villain (called Bös Trös) which can mix up your prediction of a trick.
There are King Bling‘s people card values 1-10 in bronze, silver and gold, King Bling‘s wife, worth 11 and King Bling himself, worth 12.
After each round the player with most points in total gets the crown but also all other players will go after him.

name: Shadowrun: Sprawl Gangers
description:
From the publishers homepage:

The next big release for the year occurs with Catalyst’s publication of Shadowrun: Sprawl Gangers, a tactical miniatures game designed by Ross Watson and Randall N. Bills.

Sprawl Gangers is a competitive, skirmish-level miniatures game for 2 players, with everything needed to game right in the box. Players will take on the task of building gangs (Ancients, Halloweeners, First Nation, and so on) following specific point values of a scenario, and modifying the various miniatures based upon what new resources (weapons/gear/magic/tech) a player gained through previous games. Gangs won’t simply fight for the sake of fighting, but will actively building their turfs and resources. Among other things, this will allow for the hiring of the exact right shadowrunner when they need that ace in the hole. All this adds up to the experience of watching your gang grow and expand through exciting play across a swath of games.

Sprawl Gangers will be sculpted and manufactured in conjunction with CoolMiniOrNot, who have run three of the most successful miniatures game Kickstarter projects to date: Zombicide, Relic Knights, and Sedition Wars.

“We could not be more excited to be a part of this new facet of Shadowrun. When we initially started talking about the possibility of doing a Shadowrun miniatures game with Catalyst, I personally jumped for joy. We have some big fans of Shadowrun in the Cool Mini family; so you know Sprawl Gangers will be receiving some major blood, sweat and tears from our staff. Old and new Shadowrun fans alike would do well to expect great things from Sprawl Gangers,” said Kevin Clark, Director of Research and Development at Cool Mini Or Not.

name: Kugel-Snap-Spiel
description: The board consists of a grid of 6x6 holes. In each hole is a colored ball. You must collect (according to version) all colors or 3 of the six. To collect, you press a construction in 3 adjacent holes (solo version: 4 holes) and you pick all the 3 (4) balls. If a hole is empty, you don't get a ball there of course.

name: Who am I? No. 2
description: A second card game in the Who Am I? Bible Game series. A quiz type game with 44 cards, describing Bible characters, 22 from the Old Testament and 22 from the New Testament. A "reader" announces one clue at a time for each character, and players (individually or as groups) try to guess the Bible character. The first to identify the character is given the card to keep, and the player with the most cards at the end wins the game.

name: Turncoat
description:
"Turncoat" is a simplified version of the historic "goose"-type board game and was extremely popular during the Revolutionary War. Soldiers would gather 'round the campfire at night and play this simple, yet challenging game. It was also extremely popular in neighboring villages and settlements. - From the rules sheet.

Players take turn rolling a die and moving their pawn from the camp to the battlefield and back. First to make it there and back wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Imagine That! The Puzzling Memory Matching Game! African Safari Edition
description:
User Summary

Imagine That! is a matching game for young children. Tiles are shuffled and laid face down for players to search in turn order. As a player discovers a pair of creatures, he or she adds one of those tiles to their player board which consists of a faded image of an African savannah. Certain bonus tiles exist, giving the discoverer extra flips or a free tile. The 'croc' forces a tile to be discarded.

name: Monopoly: Lüneburg
description:
Monopoly set of Lüneburg, a city located at Northern Germany.
All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Stebuklingasis kalnas
description:
In this game players are dwarves, trying to climb the magic mountain. In order to move, dwarves have to solve various tasks. On their way they gather magic feathers and diamonds. Magic feathers are used to fly over the obstacles dwarves run in. When the first dwarf reaches the top of the mountain, game ends and the player who gathered most diamonds wins.

This roll and move game teaches young players mathematics. In order to move players have to perform such arithmetic operations as addition, subtraction and division. Also it improves decision making skill. Players have to decide whether to gather diamond and fall into the pit (move backwards) or use magic feather and fly over the pit leaving the diamond where it is.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kharberg
description:
Kharberg is a simplified form of the moorish game Damma, but with a difference.
The gamepieces may be moved in any given direction, so the player has the choice of eight directions for each pawn. This gives Kharberg game an edge (far more mobility) over the games where the pieces only may be moved forward.

To play KHARBERG the players need:
12 white pawns
12 black pawns
1 board consisting of 25 squares (5 x 5)
On each square a pawn is placed. The middle square of the board is unoccupied at the start of the game. The gamepieces are placed on the board in the following order:
In front of the player the pawns of his color are placed on the first two rows. The two remaining pawns are placed on the two squares to the right of the centrepoint.

The 'black' player has the first move. Object of the game is to capture all the pawns of the opponent. Pieces are caught by jumping over the square they occupy.

Purpose of the game:
The purpose of Kharberg is to catch all the pieces of the opponent or to block them so that they can’t be moved any longer. Whoever succeeds wins the game. Draws can also occur (if both players have an equal number of game pieces on the board without the possibility of a decision).

Turn and stroke options:
Each piece can move a field in a horizontal, vertical or diagonal direction (forward and backward). Capturing pieces is done by jumping over them.
If the opponent refuses a stroke or overlooks the pawn that had to be caught, his pawn must be removed from the board (the so-called blow). The playing piece must be taken off before the player moves his own piece. If a move has already been made, the option of removal expires.

The player with the black pawns starts the game.
In the next game, the winner gets the black pieces.

name: Idaho Smith and the Terracotta Terror
description:
User Description

Idaho Smith and the Terracotta Terror is a miniatures mini game.

The game is set in 1932 and is about Idaho Smith and his travels to find the fabled white Pyramid in China. Smith finds the Pyamid but awakes evil sorecer and his army Terracotta Warriors. The aim of the game is to fight off to Terracotta army.

All the players takes the side of the explores and the Terracotta Warriors are controlled by rolling a dice on a reaction table.

The rules are simple and can be played solo if desired.

The desciption is based on the rules published in Ragnarok, issue 43.

name: Cyber City
description:
A trick taking game with a cyberpunk theme.

Players take turns playing cards in thematic suits (Android, Executive, Hacker and Ronin) then choose reward cards from a display with the players who used the highest ranked cards choosing first. Lower rank cards have special abilities which can change who wins, however, so players must choose wisely.

Players score based on their accumulated reward cards at the end of the game. There are four sets of reward cards that score based on how many of the set a player collected, and location cards that are always worth 3 points each but some of which can double the value of the collected set cards as well.

The game was originally made as a gift for a friend of the designer, themed around the stories from her web comic series (Arcana Jayne). Both sets of cards are available here to print & play.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Wer kennt Dresden?
description:
"Who knows Dresden - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Dresden.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Wer kennt Karlsruhe?
description:
"Who knows Karlsruhe - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Karlsruhe.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Wer kennt Heidelberg?
description:
"Who knows Heidelberg - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Augsburg.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Wer kennt Linz?
description:
"Who knows Linz - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Linz.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Denarii
description:
The denarius was minted by the Romans and was in use during the time of Christ through the era of the apostles. It was a silver coin, a bit larger than a dime, bearing the image of the reigning emperor and denarii (plural form of denarius) have been found bearing the image of all 12 Roman emperors. While competing in the game, you will be given 12 denarii to help you along.

On your turn you role two custom dice and move your marker farther along the track on the board. Depending on what color you land on you will be asked a different question from the trivia book. Answer correct and you stay where you are, answer incorrectly and you must return to the last denarii space that you passed or pay a denarii from your supply. To land on the last space you must role the exact number of spaces needed to get there or you can move backwards to give yourself more room.

Denarii was created to help individuals, groups and especially families increase their Bible knowledge and have fun together at the same time. Learning is the main purpose, but there is competition, strategy, challenge and lots of excitement, too.
Even if a player does not give all correct answers, he will learn from others and could still be the winner of the game! There is little advantage for the Bible scholar. Everyone who plays will learn and want to play again!

name: Wer kennt Mainz?
description:
"Who knows Mainz - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Mainz.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Wer kennt Ulm & Neu-Ulm?
description:
"Who knows Ulm and New Ulm - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Ulm and New Ulm.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

name: Drehwürmchen
description:
27 wooden disks show a little worm on one side, nine each of three colors. These are shuffled facedown on the table.
Players take turns rolling a die. When a player rolls a worm symbol, s/he can start flipping over disks (with one hand). Whenever s/he finds three of the same color, s/he takes them. However, the other players continue rolling in the meantime. Another worm means scoring: The active player may take a raspberry tile for each set s/he claimed, flips back and shuffles all tiles. If a raspberry is rolled, the player leaves the remaining open disks open and another player continues the flipping until a worm is rolled, etc.
When all raspberry tiles have been claimed, the player with most raspberries is the winner.

name: Twenty Six
description:
From the Publisher:

Twenty Six is a game perfect for those who love to play with letters and want a quick moving game that offers the opportunity to take a chance to win!

Each round, players start with two cards and then take turns choosing to be dealt another card or passing. The goal is to score points by spelling a word with at least two cards, but be careful the your hands doesn't go over 26 points or you will bust. Manage to use all of your cards to spell a word and earn bonus points! At the end of six rounds the player with the highest score wins.

name: Dancouga: Wild Battle Simulation Game
description:
A free game that came with a Japanese anime magazine.

The game uses the anime show Dancouga as the background setting.

It is a simple 1 to 4 player Solitaire/co-op game. Players pick one of the four main character of the anime show, each of which has different set of traits.

All characters have a Movement Allowance and Combat Strength. Combat Strength increases during the game with accumulated "power".

The map have 37 hexes divided into 6 areas. Most hexes are marked with an enemy strength and event name. At the start of each turn, a player rolls two dice: one indicates which area and the other indicates in which hex of the area the event happens. The player moves his character counter on the map to encounter the enemy marked there.

Comparing the combat strength of the character and the enemy, the higher side wins. The character will get the stated number of "power" if he wins.

The players win the game once there are no more active events on the map. The players lose if 40 turns pass without them meeting that victory condition.

Component:
A rule book (also a characters and mechanical design art book of the anime show)
Counter sheet (at the back cover of the rule book, the counters must be cut out before play)
A map (the other side of the map is a poster of the other anime show, Zeta Gundam, not related to the game)
Six-side dice are required but not included in the game
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Wien!
description: Based on the same game concept as London: The Board Game, Wien! is a simple family game that lets the players explore the city, discovering the history of the Austrian capital. The board is divided into two areas: the city map and the Timeline. Moving on the city map, the players reach the most famous locations in town and collect historical cards that can then be played to advance on the Timeline. The first player to complete the path on the Timeline wins. Specific knowledge of the history of the town is not required to play the game because Wien! is not a trivia game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Oneonta Domino Whist
description:
This game is a take on Oneonta Whist for 2-7 players. Like in Oneonta Whist, this game involves precise bidding, and can be played with 2 players and also cooperatively for up to 7 players. Variant rules for solitaire play are included, but the nature of dominoes makes the solitaire play not as good as that in regular Oneonta Whist.

The Domino part of the name comes from the game use dominoes or a deck of playing cards that are dominoes. In this a player would end up leading with a card, and announce which of the two sides is the suit, and the other side is the value in the suit. Players would follow the same.

The trump suit is determined by flipping over one of the no pip cards.

In addition, players can bid to take as many tricks as they can take, and lose what they bid if they fail to make it, or make what they bid if they make as many tricks as the bid, and lose one point for each trick more.

name: Gekitoh Tabaruzaka
description:
Gekitoh Tabaruzaka is an Operational level board-wargame of the Battle of Tabaruzaka in Satsuma Rebellion. Gekitoh means fierce battle, and Tabaruzaka was the most important pass in the battle.

Players control either Imperial Japanese Army or Rebel Force of Satsuma Domain, and manage military operations. The main engine use chit-pull activation and leader counters play an important role.

The winner is determined by control of important places on the map.

This wargame was published(and printed) in pages of Japanese Tactics Magazine Renewal Nr.3, and separate components are not provided.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Knappe kijkers
description:
This game teaches children to look at a set of cards with pictures, to select corresponding properties in three special dice.

- Preschoolers from 3 to 4 years play with the blue set and search for: a card with a certain background color (red, green or blue), a sun, moon or star-like shape on the figurine and a pattern (dashes, dots or squares) on the clothing.
- Infants from 4 to 5 years throw with the dice and red set. They search for a given position of the eyes (open, closed or wink), the site of an accessory (for clothing, wall or background) and the shape of the corners of the card (rounded, straight or angled).
- Children from 5 to 6 years play with the blue set of dice and find a map with some fingers in (1-2-3), the letters p-b-d on clothing and the direction of the nose (left, right or down).

There are two variants to play the game:
1)Either each child receives equal cards and places it in front of him. If the dice combination matches one of his cards, he turns it around.
2) All open tickets are in the middle of the table and all children search simultaneously to the matching card. The player who's the first to have three cards is the winner.

name: Differix Extrem
description:
Differix Extrem features the same gameplay as the earlier title Differix from the same designer, but with an added dimension of extremeness.

The game includes four playing boards, and each board features sixteen nearly identical images. In one of those multiplied images, for example, the dog might be wearing a pair of tiny goggles, while in another his tail is on the left side of his body instead of the right. Competing against both a timer and opponents, each player wants to find the correct matching image for a revealed tile before anyone else does, claiming that tile as a reward – and whoever claims the most tiles wins!

Reimplements


Differix

name: Onderweg!
description:
Toddlers put their first steps in strategic and logical thinking with this game.

They have to find the way home from the the playground as soon as possible, but of course there must first be fulfilled orders on the way...

In the game are 2 games included: The rescue & Shopping

In 'The rescue' is a lot of misery on the go! Debris on the track, a hole in the ground, a big dangerous dog on the street,.. Defeating all problems first as quickly as possible and reach your house.

'Shopping' helps your strategic thinking ahead to retrieve all your messages. Put your arrow cards as good as possible and get try to complete your shopping list first!

Each game further consists of 2 versions. You can choose to play with or against each other. Play together, it becomes a race against time. A cooperative game for the little ones ...

name: Spy!
description:
Equipment
One game sheet (reproduced on graph paper or photocopied), consisting of an upper and a lower field, and a pencil for each player.
Object
The aim is to be the first to deduce the opponent’s secret network of lines by systematically ‘spying’ on the opponent’s upper field.

Make two copies of the game sheet on graph paper (or by photocopying), and give one copy to each player. In the upper field of his game sheet, each player lays out a network (without letting his opponent see it) consisting of six lines - each of a different length, ranging from one to six grid unit lengths, inclusive. The lines must be drawn either horizontally or vertically, must be connected together (in any order), and must turn at right angles at each connection point. The lines may not touch each other except to where one ends and another starts. Illustrations 1 and 2 show networks that tin have been laid out correctly. Illustration 3 shows an incorrectly drawn network. (See images for the examples.

Play
1. One player spies by asking the opponent about the contents of a space in the opponent’s field (such as
1A, 2B and so on). If there is a line - or two connecting lines - in that space, the opponent announces: ‘hot’.
If there is no line in that space, but it is adjacent to a space containing a line, the opponent announces: ‘warm’. Squares which touch diagonally are not considered adjacent for this purpose. In all other cases, the opponent announces‘cold’. The opponent then asks about the contents of a space and the first player replies, thereby completing a round.
2. Each player uses the lower field on his game sheet for keeping track of information he obtains by spying.
3. In any round a player may, instead of spying on a single space, spy on from two to five connected spaces belonging to a single horizontal or vertical row. Whenever a player makes use of multiple spying, he must cross out below his upper field a square containing a number equal to the number of squares spied upon that turn. A player whose six numbered squares have all been crossed out may no longer use multiple spying, and the
opponent should keep track of this by using the squares under his own lower field.

At the end of any round either or both players may try to reconstruct their opponent’s network. A correct reconstruction counts as a single victory for the player. An incorrect reconstruction counts as a double victory for the opponent. (Thus it is possible for a tie to occur or for one player to win as much as a triple victory.) A player , who has made an incorrect secret construction or given the opponent incorrect information, automatically loses.

If the horizontal two-unit line in Illustration 1 were moved one grid unit to the right and connected with the four-unit line rather than the one-unit line, identical information would be obtained from spying. In such a case, either reconstruction would be considered correct.

Variation
Advanced players may agree to use more lines. Even the addition of an extra one-unit line greatly increases the strategic complexity.
publishers: Games International, GAMES Magazine, Gamut of Games

name: Pop The Question: Rock
description:
The ultimate Pop trivia card game enters the world of Rock, with a host of new artists and bands for you to identify!

The first player to guess wins that card and whoever has the most cards at the end of the game is declared the winner.

name: 70's Music Trivia
description:
Presented in a mini collectable 1970’s style Vinyl Deck, this retro quiz will take you back to the golden days of music. Includes questions from artists such as Led Zepplin, Stevie Wonder, ABBA, Fleetwood Mac, Bob Marley, Jackson 5, Earth, Wind and Fire, David Bowie, James Brown and more!

Ask the question and the player who answers correctly first gets the card as a point. There are also 3 variants on some cards.

Player with the most cards at the end is the winner.

name: Charades In-A-Box: 80s
description:
Charades game with 80's theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Party Game, Real-time

name: Charades In-A-Box: 70s
description:
Charades game with 70's theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Party Game, Real-time

name: Charades In-A-Box: Rock and Roll
description:
Charades game with Rock and Roll theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Music, Party Game, Real-time

name: Charades In-A-Box: Hollywood
description:
Charades game with Hollywood theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Real-time

name: Charades In-A-Box: Celebrity
description:
Charades game with Celebrity theme.

Players must perform and guess a whole host of fun charades that will have everyone laughing out loud. Each charade is ranked by difficulty – the harder the charade the more points your team can earn by guessing it correctly. The team with the most points after 10 rounds is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Party Game, Real-time

name: Dreh' und nimm!
description:
Objective: be the first completing your image/figure
- acting by turns -

each player chooses a figure to complete & turns the spinner (6 symbols - right/left arm, right/left leg, body, head); active player may take one correspondent piece out of 6 different figures (representing professions), distributed over the table;
you may play the game with older children, turning pieces upside down (memory effect).

name: Wild West
description:
Wild West is played with 48 cards made up of 14 different sharp shooting characters and four plastic pop guns that fire a ping-pong ball.

Contained in these 48 cards are 8 cards illustrating wanted outlaws. These 8 outlaws are also hiding in the rest of the cards. One special agent card is also included which, when played, automatically entitles the player to arrest any one of the wanted outlaws.

The object of the game is to collect three of the wanted outlaws.

Place all the wanted cards face up in a circle in the centre of the table.
Each player takes a gun and places it in front of himself on the table.
Choose a dealer, who shuffles the rest of the cards and deals them out one at a time face down to each player until the pack is finished. Each player then stacks the cards face down in front of himself .The player to the left of the dealer starts the game by playing the top card of his hand face up in front of himself. Play continues in a clockwise direction.
When any player turns over a card which he thinks is a wanted man, he should shout "Ambush" and go for his gun.The one who sees the wanted man first obviously has the advantage but he does not win the wanted card until he shoots any one of the players who have now become the outiaws. The one that shoots and scores first wins the wanted card and places it in front of himself. Should the player accidentally shoot the wrong sharp shooting character he should either:-
1. miss a go if he holds no wanted cards and be shot by the other players or
2. lose one of his wanted cards and place it back in the centre of the table and be shot by the other players.
When the players have played all their cards the dealer should shuffle the cards and deal them out as above.
The winner is the first person to collect three wanted cards.
categories: Action / Dexterity, American West, Card Game

name: Trivial Pursuit: Food & Drink
description:
Pocket version with questions about about food and drinks. Comes in a special two-part container that holds the questions and pie wedges, and is played by two players or teams. In this version there is no board. Just a category-die to determine in which category the player gets a question.

Each player has a circular playing piece with six pie-shaped holes. The goal of the game is to collect a pie in each color. The colors correspond to different question categories.

Upon the right answer the player gets a pie token to fill his playing piece. Whoever fills his piece first with 6 different colors wins the game.

name: Monopoly: Fortuna Düsseldorf
description: Monopoly with Fortuba Düsseldorf, the famous soccer team from Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Hamburger SV
description: Monopoly with Hamburger SV, a famous soccer team from Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Vom Niederrhein ins Bergische Land
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Nordrhein-Westfalen, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Luzern
description: Monopoly set in Luzern, Switzerland. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Takeaway
description:
Takeaway is a simple card based game for 2 - 6 players where the object of the game is to make money by serving as many customers and or making deliveries while the take away is open.

Game play is simple - The game is played over 15 rounds. Each player has 1 turn per round. On your turn you get to perform TWO actions from the following list in any order. They can be the same action twice or two different actions.
1. Pick up two Menu Item Cards
2. Pick up one Delivery card
3. Serve one Customer

Deliveries are worth more but the menu items are unknown to the player when they take the card.

At the end of each round move the clock one space along the time track.

Once the time token has been moved to 02.00 then all players have one more turn then the game ends. The game will also end if there are no more customers left to serve – if this is the case then all players get to finish off the round.

The winner is the player whose orders add up to the greatest value.

name: Terry Wise's Introduction to Battle Gaming: Including His Unpublished Wargaming Rules
description: Terry Wise was one of the great early wargamers. This book describe how to start wargaming and includes three straightforward sets of rules on Ancient Warfare, Horse and Musket and WWII
categories: Ancient, Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: MindTrap Geometrical Riddles: Genius Level
description: Travel size MindTrap card pack what focused less on the storytelling mysteries and riddles like the classic game and more on pattern recognition, logic problems and well, geometric riddles.

name: MindTrap Geometrical Riddles: Novice Level
description: Travel size MindTrap card pack what focused less on the storytelling mysteries and riddles like the classic game and more on pattern recognition, logic problems and well, geometric riddles.

name: Monster Truck Rally
description:
From Designer's Web Site

Welcome to the world of Monster Truck Rally! You are the driver of a monster truck, bent on the destruction of the smaller cars. Will you race to the finish in the races, or will you smash the course in the freestyle course?

Monster Truck Rally will have three different types of game play,you will have Racing, Free Style Stunt events, and a 12 part Campaign game using both racing and free style.

Winning Conditions:
The winning conditions depend upon which style of game play is used. If you only use the racing aspect of the game, then it is the fastest truck. If you use the freestyle aspect then it is the truck with the highest point total. However if you use the campaign game the winner is the truck with the most points (money) after all 12 events.
mechanics: Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sailor Boy
description:
This is a simple spin the spinner and move game where you begin your adventure at sea as the lowly CABIN BOY and by successfully moving around the board eventually get promoted to Captain and win the game.

Complete game: 10 game pieces, spinner, & box. The bottom of the box is the game board

name: Gusto Choklad
description: Trivia game that combines choclate-tasting with knowledge about choclate. Each correct question advances the player's meeple along a track and at specific stages in the track, the players taste the chocolate. Then at the end a blind test of all chocolates will take place and each correctly identified chocolate adds points to the players score. The person with most points at that stage wins the game.

name: Gusto Öl
description: Trivia game that combines beer-tasting with knowledge about beer. The game is played in 3 rounds, consisting of a set of questions and a round of beer tasting. At the end, the player with the most points win.

name: City of Fortune
description: City of Fortune is a combination of role selection and worker placement game with a hint of map building. Players take turns selecting roles and placing buildings to collect resources which can be used to gain points based on the roles that were selected. Roles change every round, so the game is constantly changing. There's very little luck involved, which makes this game a deep strategic masterpiece.
mechanics: Modular Board, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: 2nd El Alemein
description:
2nd El Alemein is a low complexity wargame on the Second Battle of El Alamein. The game can be played either solitaire or two player.

Each player has an objective that he or she must meet in order to win - either number of units destroyed or occupying certain hexes. Each counter can move one hex per turn. The combat is a simple system in which the players must roll greater than or equal to the number printed on the counter to achieve a hit.

The rules are only three pages long. The game also includes a counter sheet and a map that can be printed at 11x17 (A3) or 8.5x11 (A4).
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Asteroid Junkies!
description:
Space Miners of the Remna Sector are cutthroat crews. They’ll do anything to score the next mother lode! When the government opened up a new Parsec for mining, they leapt at the chance to be the first in!
Players are competing to harvest the most value out of Asteroids around the game board. Many asteroids are of hidden value and so player totals are secret, so you never know the true winner until the end!

The primary mechanic is drafting one-at-a-time, and then programming in "Commands" for your ship from a pool of Commands cards dealt anew each turn. Matching Commands can be assigned to "Special Commands" that do special (and mostly powerful) things. There are six ships to choose from at the start of the game, each with a different set of Special Commands. The gameboard is composed of modular squares, so the board changes every game.
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Stop-Over Essen
description:
This game consists of two sub-games. In the first game players take the role of journalists and try to get to the sat-van as quick as possible in order to upload the three pictures they have to capture in this game. The pictures are all Essen-buildings or sites and have a UFO sighting on them.

This is a Malefiz kind of adaptation.

In the second part the game, journalists try to get the cover-story before the other players can by running up the stairs of the publisher trying to beat the others to his office.

name: Xenoid: The Arcade-Style Solo Space-Shooter Card Game
description:
A new menace is threatening Earth and its inhabitants. Earthbound observers detected a huge armada of exotic, bionic spaceships, the Xenoids, headed towards our home planet. You are a veteran pilot piloting a heavily armed prototype fighter spacecraft, the "Exterminator". Equipped with state of the art laser and shielding technology, your piloting skills and the "Exterminator" are the only way to stop the armada of invaders and save humankind from certain damnation. Will you be able to stop the Xenoid intruders?

This card game for one player tries to emulate the gameplay of classic arcade-style top-down space shooters. You control a spaceship that starts with 3 Lives, 3 Shields and a Weapon with Power 1. You are facing an armada of enemy (Xenoid) Spacecraft which move downwards towards you while you try to destroy as many of them as possible by performing one out of 3 actions each turn: Move - Shoot - Charge (your Weapon).

The Game features 5 Waves (Levels) with enemies becoming stronger and more numerous as you advance through the stages.
You collect Power Ups (such as Weapon or Shield Upgrades or additional Lives etc) which pop up at random when enemy crafts are destroyed. In between stages you can buy Power Ups by spending points you acccumulated during the Waves. Each destroyed enemy goes to the Score Pile and may be used to pay for Power Ups in between Waves.

The goal of the game is twofold: The primary goal is to survive all five Waves. When all your shields are depleted you lose one life, and when all lives are lost it means "Game Over". The secondary goal is to strive for the highest possible score by destroying as many Xenoid ships as possible. Again you score points for every destroyed enemy spaceship. So in your first game you will set your initial high score which you can beat in consecutive games. Note that you even set a score if you don't beat the game...
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Dice, Fighting, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Simulation

name: Monopoly: Duisburg
description:
Monopoly set of Duisburg, a German city in the mid-west region.
All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Winning Moves Germany, Winning Moves UK Ltd.

name: Monopoly: Offenburg
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Offenburg, a city located in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Föhr
description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Föhr, a North Frisian Island in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Karmageddon
description:
This is definitely one of those games where the name directed the mechanic. The concept of karma – good and bad, owing or being owed a debt, and both being a responsibility – and a meta game element of card destruction (making every deck unique) and Real World ™ consequences (in the form of a verbal contract to play) sort of came after the pun of Karma and Armageddon.

The most important part of this game concept is that players may “help” you, even when you don’t want it, and that this will exact a real consequence to clear the debt. Of course, like a gambling debt, this isn’t enforceable. However, entering into the spirit of the thing is the whole point. Why cheat? You’re only robbing yourself…

Set up
There are two elements to this game:

1) A card game played with (what starts out at least as) a standard deck of cards. If there are Jokers, bridge rules or instruction cards, include them.

2) Redemption of Debt where cards used to help other players are IOUs for an hour of a player’s time on any reasonable, legal and responsible task.

To play (the first time) a Sharpie or permanent marker and a standard deck of cards (with jokers) is necessary for 2-4 players. For more than 4 players an extra deck of cards is added for each additional player up to 8 maximum; ideally this should have a different back design or be different size to allow separation for future 2-4 player games. These cards will be torn, ripped and marked, so will likely not be useful for other games afterwards.

NOTE: a deck where cards are missing (otherwise useless!) is fine as a starting deck. Subsequent play will likely not have all the cards anyway, so one or two missing now won’t matter. Reuse/Recycling!!! I feel better already!

Set up for the Meta-Game (the redemption of favours) is merely the agreement of all players that they will commit to an hour of time helping one another for each “Debt Card” they end up with. Where this occurs in game, the card will be ripped in two and both parts signed by helper and helpee; its recommended that a phone number or email address for each is also written down, unless players are well acquainted. The helpee then uses their half in play (for that game only) and later as a reminder that they owe a favour. The helper keeps their half to call in the debt.

NOTE: The hour of time and the task are to be mutually agreed between helper and helpee. It could be anything crom mowing a lawn, babysitting, fixing a computer, whatever is acceptable and doable.

NOTE 2: Debts do NOT cancel out. If Mike owes Paco a debt and vice versa, they don’t call it quits. They both do an hour for the other. This is a matter of honour!

Once a debt is paid, “Done” is written on the helpers half and “Paid” is written on the helpees half. Cards can be kept as a memento, burned ceremoniously or binned.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading, Trick-taking

mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Pi mal Daumen
description:
Educational card game issued by the German Goverment for political education (Bundeszentrale politische Bildung):
A card is drawn an read. There is some trvia like "How many cows live in Germany? Everyone writes an estimate on a paper. The papers are revealed and read aloud, Now everyone choses one number. The number closest to the real number scores points.

name: Hello Sunshine!
description:
Hello Sunshine! is a charmingly simple game that will have you and your child laughing and playing together! Play hide and seek with Sunshine – an adorable plush toy – while teaching your child positional words such as: In, On Top, Below, Next To, and more.

Game Play:
1. Grown-up selects a card and hides the plush Sunshine according to the card.
2. Grown-up shows child the card and says, "Can you find Sunshine ______ ?" (example, UNDER the table)
3. When child finds Sunshine, everyone celebrates!
4. Try another card.

name: CityProGame Berlin
description:
Objective: Using the detailed street map of Berlin each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

name: Rules for the Napoleonic period
description:
Rules for Napoleonic miniatures war games. The rules are primarily for use with 25mm figures, though the ground scale can be adjusted for different size figures. Each figure and commander is assigned a points value, so players can create armies with a set number of points.

Players form up their miniature units based on their points values and use them to recreate actual or hypothetical Napoleonic battles. The terrain is varied and is supplied by the gamers. The rules concisely cover movement, combat and morale effects. Battle casualities are determined with dice rolls and the use of a rotating casualty disc "tool" (which the players have to assemble from 2 pieces of card stock and a pin.

name: Trust
description:
Economic game in which players play either company, bank or government. A player puts down a package of asset and debt cards - but only assets are face-up. The next player can either accept the package, add cards and pass it on, or doubt that the assets cover the debt cards. The wronged player gets permanent debts, and at the end of the game, the player with the lowest debts wins.
Each player also has a rating that influences his/her hand cards, so the challenge is not entirely an uninformed decision.
