Game mechanic: when the card of Tyrannosaurus is revealed by one of the players, this player takes Tyrannosaurus into his or her hand, and all other cards of the herd are discarded.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Memory

name: Post-Time
description:
The object of the game is for 2-4 players/owners to purchase and race with the option of betting on horses.
During the game, ownership cards for 2- and 3-year old trotters, pacers and thoroughbreds are gained through a roll and move mechanic, where spaces on the game board represent the different horses. If the horse is currently unowned, the player may purchase the horse with the price equal to the number on the horse multiplied by the dice total times $100. If the player declines to purchase for that price, the player pays a penalty of $50. Any fines or other monies paid due to "Risk" cards go into the "Winner's Circle" in the center of the track. Players go around the track twice before each of the four races occurs. The first player to finish each tour is given Post Position #1, the second #2, etc.
During the racing phase, owners determine if their horses will race, with a fee of $100/horse being paid. Placings in the race are determined by the post position times the roll of the dice. Awards for win/place/show in each race are given in a table in the rules, with each successive race having a larger purse. Horses that win/place/show are marked with a colored clip.
During the races, betting can occur beforehand with each horses odds ti win are determined by the number on the ownership card times the number rolled on a single die. Maximum bets are $100/horse. There is an odds dial to keep track of each horses' odds. Odds to place or show are reduced by 1/2 and 1/4, respectively.

Winners of the four previous races are entered into the "Blue Ribbon Invitational" at the end of the game for the largest purse. Before the start of the invitational race, money is counted by the players and the total recorded on a piece of paper before all monies are returned to the bank by the players before the invitational race and the total recorded. Betting is unlimited in this final race and you can bet on any horse.

The winner is the player that has the most money at the end.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Only Fools and Horses DVD Board Game
description: Based on the BBC Series, Only Fools and Horses, this is a game of watching clips and answering questions.

name: Cosmos
description:
In Cosmos, players take turns exploring the universe, building far-flung colonies, and collecting taxes (for once, we're on the right side of taxes!). The goal of the game is to make the most money from the economic opportunities of exploring space, while elbowing out the market competition. Central market mechanics allow players to compete by increasing or decreasing universal resource prices, while limited resources make each region of space a hotly-contested competition for colonies. The game ends when the universe is totally explored--meaning if you're sitting in dead last without a hope, you can explore your heart out and rush the game to an untimely conclusion.

Cosmos is very straightforward to learn, and a typical game takes around 30-45 minutes. Cosmos is simple enough for casual gamers to play (and win), but complex enough to keep the interest of more competitive or experienced gamers. Turns are quick, and the game mechanics are easy to remember.

Most conflict in Cosmos is indirect, making this a great game for two players--even those who may be mismatched in competitive nature or gaming experience (read: the hobbyist and the spouse). At the same time, Cosmos allows up to eight players, making it a decent party game, although it gets a bit crowded and far more competitive at six.

Overall, this is a highly replayable, very entertaining game with a really broad appeal and low commitment requirements.
categories: Economic, Exploration, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Modular Board, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: IconGame
description:
IconGame
Do you know how you say "pencil" in Spanish? And "rubber"? And "sharpener"? Learn all these words and many more with IconGame.
It's easy: You choose a card, and if you know how to say it correctly in Spanish, you win the corresponding Picnics (points) according to their degree of difficulty. At the end of the game, the player who accumulates more Picnics wins.

Includes 50 vocabulary cards (with pronunciation guide) and plastic sandwich.


IconGame
¿Sabes cómo se dice “lápiz” en inglés? ¿Y “goma”? ¿Y “sacapuntas”? Aprende todas estas palabras y muchas más con IconGame.
Es muy fácil: Eliges una tarjeta, y si sabes cómo se dice correctamente en inglés ganas los Picnics (puntos) correspondientes, según su grado de dificultad. Al final de la partida, gana el jugador que más Picnics acumula.

Incluye 50 cartas de vocabulario (con guía de pronunciación) y sandwichera de plástico.

name: Romans vs Britons
description: Romans vs Britons plays out an ambush of a small troop of Roman soldiers marching along a Roman road sometime in the mid first century AD. They are in a valley when they spot fearsome Britons coming down from the surrounding hills. Orthogonal movement and custodial capture Captains (2 each) can capture more that one enemy. Three different levels of win depending on whether the loser manages to escape, surrender or is entirely defeated. Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

name: Vikings vs Saxons
description: Vikings vs Saxons plays out a skirmish between the Saxon settlers of dark age Britain and incoming Vikings some time in the 8th century. They meet at a bridge and fight to the death. There are three categories of men: Swords-men (movement: ortho/diag 3/2 squares); Axe-men (movement: ortho/diag 2/1 squares); Spear-men (movement: knights move). Two levels of winning depending on whether the loser surrenders/escapes or is entirely defeated. Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

name: Slicks: Tuning – Expansion #1
description:
Time to tune your Slicks racing car and make it unique with specific tires, flights and boosters.

In Slicks: Tuning, you can choose between six different types of tires, from hard to extremely smooth. Some show a high performance over the first rounds, but suddenly explode; others start with less-than-perfect performance, but maintain that level for a long distance.

This expansion comes with a full set of tuning tools for all six players, allowing each player to establish a personal set-up that matches his strategy and favorite driving style.

Material:
6 sets of tuning tools, each consisting of
- 3 stripes "tire" (double sided)
- 1 Marker "Flight" (double sided, +1 for green and yellow)
- 1 Marker "Booster"/"save tire"

name: CRMA: The Battle for Colony ZXC123
description:
The futuristic colony ZXC123 is under attack by an enemy group known as the Boss Squad. Four members of the colony have been given CRMA (Combat-Ready Mechanized Armor), highly upgradeable equipment that they'll use to protect their colony and fight off the Boss Squad.

In this solo roguelike game, players work through the card deck, fighting enemies and dealing with events around the colony. The order of these is randomized through shuffling, and each encounter is removed from the deck after resolution. Cards also act as items that the player can attach to their CRMA to increase their effectiveness, trade at caravans for other items, or break down during combat to influence dice rolls. Card backs are used as vital stats indicators, and two of these are removed from each game for the player character, further randomizing each game experience.

The goal of the game is to build up your CRMA's strength to the point where you can defeat three Boss characters in combat. If you run from three Bosses, you lose. If you only defeat two bosses and the deck runs out, you still win.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Gaido
description:
Medieval Japan has so much to offer in the way of scenery! Vast mountains, quaint villages, hidden shrines and much more. The real treasures however are those that jump and fly - the rare brown squirrels, cranes, egrets and eagles who make their homes in remote locations. These hard to find creatures are the ultimate destination of any tour of the countryside.

In Gaido, players take on the role of guides and travelers journeying through the countryside of medieval Japan. Guide duties are shared, with each player taking the responsibility for one day of their journey. The guide directs the group of players through the Japanese landscape, to their journey’s end. Only the current guide can decide when a journey is over.

There are four animals the group is trying to spot, squirrels, cranes, egrets and eagles. These animals are found in four different locations and represent the end of a journey. On the play table, players will create four stacks of cards, called Journeys. These stacks represent the different paths to the four animals.

Every Journey card has a Kanji symbol on it which indicates how many points each player will receive when that stack is scored. Cards can be played facing any direction. There are sixteen Journey cards and four Journey’s End cards which, when played on one of the four journeys will immediately end that journey and score that stack of cards.

Gaido offers interesting play choices, with a strategy that’s deeper than it first appears and a simple play style. Only 20 cards and 24 counters in size, it’s played in an average of 15-20 minutes.

name: Tilt
description:
Tilt is played on a hexagonal board divided into six horizontal and six vertical channels by raised squares. Each player has a set of square pieces numbered 1-5, with more of the lower numbers (plus a "flag" piece) which move along the channels.

Pieces can be moved individually or as columns of adjacent friendly pieces. A piece or a column can push an opposing piece or column if it stronger (i.e., if the sum of the pieces' numbers is greater). Flags cannot move on their own, but must instead be included in a column.

Pieces which are blocked from moving (even temporarily) can be removed by the owner if it is to their advantage. It is also legal to push your own pieces if you like (even off the board).

The object of the game is to touch or immobilize the opposing flag.

name: Simon Dice
description:
Simon says "roll the dice!"

One player takes the role of the master, rolls the two dice, and reads aloud the results. The other players try to obey those instructions. If anyone can't obey the instruction, doesn't obey it, or falls over while trying then they are eliminated. The last person standing becomes the master for the next game.

The two dice are a "question" die and an "action" die. The question die stipulates a condition, and the action tells you what to do if you meet that condition. So, you might roll the two dice and read out "If you are a boy, stand on one foot" or "If your first name contains an A or an I, hold your left arm out straight" or "if you are smiling, stare at either your feet or the ceiling". You have to keep obeying all prior instructions as you execute new instructions.

Some actions give players a choice, such as "put your right hand on your head or on your stomach". If such an instruction comes up again later, the players have to pick the option they aren't already doing, and do it instead.

All you need are 2 dice to play. You can either create custom dice, or use two differently colored dice and look up the results on a simple table.

name: Dictator of the Sea
description:
Dictator of the Sea is about a battle between navy and pirate.

Perform one of the three actions below. As soon as the action is done, your opponent begins the next turn.
1. Select one face down Board tile on the board and flip it face up.
2. If a tile from your side (Navy or Pirate), the Whale tile, or the Shark tile is face up on the board, activate one of these units.
3. Spend Treasure to bribe an opponent's unit. Replace one of your opponent's units with your own unit.

Game ends when
1. If one side no longer has any units on the board
-> The player who still has units on the board wins. This player wins even if all his or her units are face down.
2. If 10 turns pass after all tiles are revealed
-> Add all the ranks of captured enemy tiles and the ranks of any of your remaining units on the board to determine your score. The player with the highest score wins. Equal scores means a tie.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Rufa
description: An early and unuusual game by De La Rue c. 1900, copyright by Ernest Legh. The goal of the game is to build a pagoda with specially designed cards without causing the structure to collapse. The pasteboard box the game comes in serves as a base for the building with gauges that ensure that the first story is correctly formed. It seems complex with rules for attempting to replace partial collapse and foul placement of cards.

name: Kättä päälle
description:
A quiz game.

Each round starts with a question and the setting of a 30 second timer.

Each player has two opportunities to answer the question (the questions are open, for example "Name a car brand that begins and ends with a consonant", so there are always lots of possible answers). When a player answers, she puts her hand on the board. Next player puts her hand on top of the first hand and so on.

When the timer goes off, round is over. The topmost hand scores five points, the next hand scores four points and so on. Scores are recorded and the next round begins. The player with the most points after 20 rounds wins.

name: Χρηματιστήριο
description:
In this game the players are stock market share holders, trying to put their opponents out of the game by bankrupting them. The game is based on the Greek Stock market of the 90s and the press of the era.

It has many similarities to Monopoly, but in place of real estate now there are company shares. Houses and hotels are replaced by percentage of the company in stocks, owned by the player. Paying money based on stocks they own to other players as well as various taxes and public service bills may cost money to the players similar to monopoly.

An interesting change is the fact that two players can merge their shares in order to get a bigger percentage payment from other players.

The goal of course is to take out of business your opponents by causing them to go bankrupt.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading, Trick-taking

name: Tumblin' Tree
description:
From the publisher:
Take turns growing a tree by adding leaves and branches onto a wobbly, not always cooperative trunk. Whoever causes any part of the tree to tumble must pick up the pieces. Trunk can be adjusted to increase difficulty, making this fun for the whole family. It is made up of natural wood. An outrageously fun eco-balancing game with lead free paint.

User note:
This might be an uncredited and/or unauthorized version of the SdJ Kinderspiel winner, Arbos.

name: Noris Schach
description:
A game of Chess for 3 players, Noris Schach (Noris Chess) is played on a hexagonal board divided into triangular cells, with a bight of 5 cells taken out of every other side, leaving a total of 106 triangles and three corner areas of the board where pieces will begin from. Each player has the normal complement of Chess pieces, but for an extra Pawn and another piece called the Cardinal, which moves like a Queen but cannot capture and can only be captured under narrowly defined circumstances involving both other players.

The game is then played according to the usual rules of Chess, but for the complications of an extra player and additional directions of movement resulting from the triangular cells.

name: Rawen TCG: Frost Wolf Promo
description:
Promo card given out for free during the Spiel 2013.

Name: Frost Wolf
Domain: Iceland
Mana Cost: 2
Attack: 2
Hit Points: 2
Special Powers: Frenzy, Mail: 1
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game

name: Fire Call
description:
"During the earlier days of firefighting, volunteer fire brigades used deception to compete with one another in order to be the first responders on scene, and subsequently receive payment from the property owner's insurance.

Fire Call positions you at the front lines of modern-day firefighting with a heated twist reminiscent of the combative early years. As you battle opposing fire departments, pull out all the stops to gain control of the most districts by collecting equipment, sabotaging opponents, and successfully completing fire calls to win the game."

The game objective is to become the Fire Department (player) with the most occupied districts by collecting and using the necessary equipment to complete Fire Calls. Once all the districts are covered, the Fire Department with the most occupied districts wins the game.

On their turn, players roll the die and move their markers along the track. The space they land on can have one of a number of effects. Players may gain fire equipment, have the opportunity to complete a fire call and occupy a district, gain cards for special effects later or sustain on-the-job injuries and be put in hospital. Players will also gain ranks throughout the game, starting off as Firefighters and being promoted up to Fire Chief.

When fire calls are completed by players, the corresponding district is covered and occupied. Immediately after all 11 districts are occupied, the game ends and the player with the most wins.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tavulotto
description:
Each player has a 3x3 board that he randomly fills with tiles, which have parts of words. The rest of the tiles are shuffled and one of them is turned face-up.

Players try to make a word matching the tile to one or more of their tiles on the board. The fastest one takes the tile and removes the used tiles from his board. The one who clears the board first is the winner.

name: Mise en Place: The Culinary Knowledge Game
description: Mise en Place: The Culinary Knowledge Game is a fun and educational game designed to be played by up to six players or teams. Players are immersed in a restaurant environment where they encounter nearly 1200 questions based on culinary terms and concepts. Players begin as entry-level employees and are prompted to answer questions in each of the six certification areas in order to be promoted to Apprentice, Sous Chef, and finally to Executive Chef to win the game. Along the path to promotion, players encounter tally it up questions on measurements, recipe conversions, and the use of fractions and percentages.

name: GötzenDiener
description:
GötzenDiener is a quick set-collecting card game.

The deck consists of five types of cards representing objects of worship, numbered 1–5, of various quantities. On a player's turn, he picks a card, then either keeps it or sends it to another player who cannot refuse the card. If a player gets a hand of four cards, he must discard all cards of any one type from his hand, applying the effect on those card(s).

The game ends when either the deck runs out, someone has a hand of three identical cards, or someone discards a 5. All players then show their hands, earning points for the most common object of worship in hand and the runner-up, and being penalized for everything else, those objects being heretical symbols.

name: Mechabrick: Gangs of Neon City
description:
Mechabrick is a range of precision molded plastic kits to convert your minifigs into 1/144 scale fighting robots or 'mecha'. You can upgrade your mechs with weapons and accessories and then battle for supremacy in a fast-paced board game using buildings and scenery built from your favourite plastic toy building bricks.

The first game in the Mechabrick product line is Gangs of Neon City. Set in the back-streets of a futuristic far-eastern metropolis the game uses durable plastic gaming boards (supplied in the game box) printed with a brick-standard grid pattern (4-bricks square) upon which movement and shooting range of the robots is measured.

It's up to you and your imagination to build, change and rebuild the buildings and scenery on your game board from plastic toy building bricks and create your perfect battle environment.

The game sets two or more players in a head-to-head battle of turn-based play using 'action points' to choose whether each robot should move, shoot or both in each turn. Customisation and upgrades to your robots are key to a decisive win, but be careful not to weigh down your mech with too many upgrades and make them too slow to fight!

The printed rulebook supplied with the boxed game is only 4 pages long and is designed to be fun and fast-paced for all the family. We will be publishing free add-ons and expanded rules for the game to keep even the most hardened gamers interested for many years to come.

The boxed game includes four of the 'Wakazashi-Class' mech kits (two black and two white), four plastic game boards, a decal sheet to customize your mechs and your scenery, two D6 dice and a full rule/instruction booklet.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: Borarada!
description:
User summary:

An idol dice-rolling game based on the anime "Love Live!"

Players are dealt a hand of cards representing idols. Each idol has 2 effects: one that is applied pre-dice rolling and one that can be applied after.

From a selection of possible concerts, players choose simultaneously which one to try on, and in turn, they roll 6 dice, trying to get as high a total as possible; the higher total, the higher points, depending on the concert card. Prior to rolling, the player can play one card from his hand to apply the "pre-rolling" effect (which essentially decides certain outcomes), and after rolling, the player can play any number of cards applying the "post-rolling" effect; which usually change one dice into another or adds to the total.

The player with the most points when all concerts are finished wins.

The title is short for "Bokura no Live, Kimi to no dice", meaning "Our live, the dice with you".

name: Middle Elementary School Wars
description:
User summary:

A battle card game themed as a fight between 10-year-olds.

Each player gets a team of 3 kids with traits in attack, defence, imagination and ability to carry. These are deployed onto 3 areas (with a max of 2 rom each side in one area). Each turn, cards are drawn from the item deck and the active player can do one action with each of his characters: pick and equip an item, attack the opponent in the same area, move to another area, use an equipment or imagine.

Points are awarded to defeat the opponent by inflicting 4 damage, or by reaching the imagination limit of that character. First to 6 points wins.

Items include all sorts of weird things like love letters, rain boots and bus stops.

name: Appalachian Trail
description:
Welcome to the 1920's and the Appalachian Mountains! You have been commissioned to create a section of the Appalachian Trail, something that will eventually extend 2,200 miles through 14 states! It is your job to forge the best trail possible, with varying terrains to cross, scenic views, and majestic native wildlife. Unfortunately, others have also been commissioned to create sections of the trail and might try to stop you!

In Appalachian Trail each player is given a section of the trail to complete. This is accomplished by matching up similar terrain cards to each other. However, your opponents might put an obstacle in your path, forcing you to change the direction of your trail.

There are also trail improvements that increase the value of your section of the Appalachian Trail so that it attracts more hikers.

Completing your trail first is important but winning is based on victory points which are accumulated through: trail completion, longest trail, set collection, and more.

name: Quiz Göteborg
description:
Trivia game about Göteborg with 1500 questions.

The object of the game is to be the first to claim an area of the city by answering questions or being lucky with the dice.

Event cards can be used to steal questions and more.

name: Flambé
description:
User summary:

A game in which players start with a mountain of dice. Game starts with players being dealt a random one of 4 numbers (like 5 or 11). Each turn, a player places one of his top dice on the appropriate tile (numbered 1–6) on the board. When placing a die on a tile, if there are exactly 2 or 4 dice on the opposing tile, the player scores those dice.

Game continues until no player has any dice to place. The players who have managed to score exactly as many dice as the number he was dealt is the winner. If not, the player who is closest wins.

name: Monopoly: VfL Wolfsburg
description:
Monopoly with VfL Wolfsburg, a soccer team from Germany.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Schwabing
description:
The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Schwabing, a district of Munich, a city in Germany.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Hanau
description:
Monopoly set to Hanau, a city in Germany.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Witten
description:
The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Witten, a city in Germany.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Io canto
description:
Each player chooses a pawn and take the 6 pieces of its color.
Put the pawn chosen at the beginning of the board.
Shuffle the 'unexpected' and 'guests' cards in the appropriate spaces on the board.
Shuffle the 24 cards songs and arrange them in the appropriate spaces on the game board.
Insert the jury card inside the bag. If you play in 5 or 6, put them all, or, in the case of 3 or 4 players, only enter the 8 cards numbered from 1 to 2 .
The players alternate in singing receiving the votes of the public (the other players) and the judgment of the jury.
The game is played in 3 rounds plus a final.

Round 1
The current player draws the card song on top of its pile.
Read the songs and decide whether or not to accept the card, otherwise goes to the player to his left until this is chosen by someone.
If all pass, the card is given to the player who had drawn it.
The player who is assigned the card chooses one of the songs written on the front and draws an "unexpected" card.
The player performs the song choice with track on the CD and respecting the rule reported on the "unexpected".
At the end of the performance each of the other players pass a covered card of values.
The player draws a jury card.
The turn passes to the next player. In the first run you must show all at once.
At the end of the performances the players reveal their cards and advance their pawn based on the score received.

Round 2
In the second round the players are performing in duets.
The player chooses a card from the relative number of bunches . Choose a song and a player with which to perform.
The players perform together.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on one area related to one of the two players who have just sung.
Each of the 2-player draws a card and places the jury in your area.
As in the first run will add up your points and advancing the pawn.

Round 3
The last in the standings takes the bunch of songs for the third exhibition and chooses a card based on the type they prefer, without reading the songs.
Then draw a card guest, choose a song and a famous singer and performs alternating a normal singing voice imitation of the chosen guest.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on the area of ​​the board on the turn player.

Final
The two players with the highest score in the final play.
The cards not used are shuffled. Players draw a card and perform the song. The other players vote.
Players then draw a card jury.
The player with the highest score is the winner.

name: Stamp Albums
description:
A Decktet Game for 2-players in which you try to buy as many "stamps" as possible for your album in competition with the other player.
Each player has their own shop and a market place runs down the centre of the table. Players may purchase from any row using the cards in their hand.
For the time being rules etc. can be viewed at http://wiki.decktet.com/game:stamp-albums

name: Wintersport-Spiel
description:
Goal: Be the first to race to position '50' (basis station)
Game Play:
Typical 'roll & move' game - Roll the die by turns and step forward - ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Notes:
Contains pewter pawns

name: Shattered Empire
description:
When mankind first discovered warp points, the gravitational anomalies that allowed him to travel to the stars, humanity spread like wildfire. A mighty Empire of Man grew in all directions. Colonies were planted on any planet that could support them. New spacefaring races were encountered, trade established, wars fought. Until finally the Empire of Man grew too large; internal dissention and external jealousy conspired to destroy it. First the far-flung Empire became too difficult to control centrally. Outer systems demanded more sovereignty, leading to rebellion and civil war. And once that war was lost, neighboring races pounced, snatching what they could. The collapse culminated in the bombardment of Terra and the subjugation of most of the remaining colonies.

Now, years later, humans on Old Terra have finally recovered. Humanity has spread all over known space, but humans on Mother Terra are ready to reach again for the stars. Ready to reclaim their Shattered Empire

Shattered Empire is a Print and Play (PnP) solo game in which the player takes on the struggles of the people of Earth to rebuild and defend their new star empire. The map depicts the systems around Old Terra and, beyond that, the regions controlled by other governments and races. Each turn represents about a decade of time and each ship counter is an individual starship. Players try to expand and defend their empire and score victory points over a 150 year period of time (less if your empire completely succumbs to its foes).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Treffpunkt Mars
description:
The goal of the game is to reach Mars or Venus or both. To extend the playing time, it can be agreed upon if it's necessary to return to earth. The game is played with 3 dice. Upon arrival on Mars and Venus the players get wooden cubes, representing valuable metals. The player who gets the most cubes wins the game.

The game was published in the 50s or 60s.

name: If I'm Going Down: Taking Back the Town Promo Cards
description:
Two oversized promo cards for use with the Special Scenario - Taking Back the Town.

Includes: 1 Construct Zombie and 1 Scenario Card.

For use with the "If I'm Going Down" Dying Card Game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Zombies
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game

name: Decktet-Uno
description:
Decktet-Uno is inspired by Uno mechanics and it's a game in the family of Decktet games.

Each player chooses a card and places it on top of the face-up card at the center, starting to form a pile.

Each time a card is played by someone, that player gets awarded a total of points calculated as:
[Number of symbols on the face-up card on the top of the pile] X [Number of matching symbols on the card the player is placing on top of it]

After playing a card, the current player finishes the turn and draws a card from the deck.

The game goes on until all cards have been played.

name: Dogfight
description:
Take to the Skies!

Fly a patrol over the trenches and tangle with enemy planes in this set collection card game!

Climb and dive as you jockey for position, attempting to line up the perfect shot. Choose from over 20 different historic aircraft, each with different performance attributes which suffer as the plane takes damage. You may wind up an ace, or go down in flames!







A World War I aerial combat set collection card game. In Dogfight players strive to collect then play sets of cards in order to shoot down their opponents. The game is over when only one side remains, or when the victory conditions of the scenario being played are met.

The game features set collection, card drafting, and variable player powers.

Dogfight contains 54 cards used to form the draw deck during the game. Each card is from one of six Attack Sets, as noted by the title across the top of the card: Crossing Shot, Diving Shot, Head On Shot, Strafing Run, Trailing Shot, and Turning Shot.

Attack Sets may have special conditions governing when the set can be played. Before trying to damage an enemy plane, you must collect a number of cards from the same Attack Set equal to the card’s Set Size. These cards are then played together as a Bid for Damage. If the attack is successful, then the target plane suffers damage equal to the Damage Value listed on the cards.

Some cards in the deck have a Defensive Value and can be used to avoid an enemy attack.

The draw deck is also used for randomly assigning specific types of damage to target planes. For each point of damage inflicted, one card is flipped over from the draw deck and the listed damage is applied. The information along the bottom of the card is used solely for this purpose, and is ignored during the set collection portions of the game.

name: Professor Pugnacious: Mythos Monstrosities
description: This Lovecraftian themed mini-expansion for Professor Pugnacious features a new Setting, the Maze of Unnatural Geometry, and a new Finale, the Maddening Monstrosity.

name: Playout: The Game
description:
Playout: The Game™ makes fitness fun for people of all ages and fitness abilities. Turn bodyweight exercise into a fun competition with over 10 unique games and infinite exercise combinations, all using a single deck of cards. Why workout when you can PLAYOUT!


Play alone or with friends
No additional equipment needed!
Full body fitness in 10 minutes of fun!


Playout: The Game™ is an exercise card game that makes fitness fun through social play, competition, variety, and adaptability. With Playout, you can get fit while having fun, anywhere, anytime.

30 BODYWEIGHT EXERCISE CARDS - 10 Upper, 10 Core, 10 Lower - A comprehensive full body calisthenic routine for all fitness levels. Each card features an individual exercise and includes direction and tips on how to perform the excercise. In addition, each card includes three rep counts to vary the difficulty as well as a point value for completing the reps for the exercise.

12 WILDCARDS - Challenges to increase the difficulty and variability of the exercises by adding reps, incorporating new motions or body positions, slowing down motions, or adding new exercises. Depending on the game played, the Wild (i.e. Joker) cards include directions for each of the difficulty levels that can be applied to an Exercise card to make it more difficult. Additional points are awarded for completing the Joker cards.


8 MINIGAMES - Intensely fun competitions that push you to the limit. When these cards are encountered, a mini game occurs that really ratchets up the game. 10 or 20 additional points can be earned for both participating and winning the minigame.


Stretch, Warm-Up, Cool-Down, Rule, and Information Cards

GAMES

The Playout deck can either used as an activity to facilitate an exercise routine, or it can be used to play several games. These games can be played as individual players or team vs. team:
Playout Pro (High Intensity)
The 6 Minute Playout (Moderate/High Intensity)
Playout Rummy (Low/Moderate Intensity) - Be the first to get rid of all you cards by making sets. From each set made, choose an exercise for yourself and opponents to perform. Award points to those who complete the exercises.
Playout Grand Prix
Playout All-Star



SCORING

In general, scoring works as follows:
Exercise Card:
Full reps - 10 points + WildCard value
At least half the rep = WildCard value
Less then half the reps = no points

MiniGame Card:
Qualify = 10 points
Winner = 20 points




The player (or team, if playing in teams) with the most points at the end of a particular game (or set of games in the case of a multi-game competition) is the winner.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Sports

name: Auf den Spuren seltener Tiere
description:
In this roll-and-move game the 2-4 players are wildlife photographers, traveling around the globe to the wildlife reserves for photo shoots of endangered animals. The rarer the animal the more points the photo is worth in the end. The player with the most points wins.

The game theme is based on a popular German animal documentary TV series of the 1960s and early 1970s.
categories: Animals, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: El Joc de TV3
description:
A trivia/party game based on TV3, Catalonia's public television. It's released to celebrate its 30th anniversary.

It has 1400 questions and challenges, all are about TV3's history.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Mr. One Minute Challenge
description: A game from Wilkinson's self-published 'Mr.' range. The aim of One Minute Challenge is to complete five one-minute long challenges, for example naming forms of transport or types of curry, or memorising a shopping list. The game comes with a deck of cards each containing a challenge and a sand timer. A player who successfully completes a challenge keeps the challenge card, and the first player to reach the target number of cards wins.
categories: Card Game, Memory, Party Game, Trivia

name: Battroborg
description:
Battroborgs are motion controlled battling robots that are built for combat and fueled by your fists.

Players control their robots via handheld nunchuck style remotes. Robot punches correspond to each human punch and move the robot forward. A solid blow to the face scores a point and is shown via led. The first to score five points wins as their opponent becomes disabled.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Electronic, Science Fiction

name: Helballa 80-talet
description:
How well do you actually remember the eighties? A time when phasmatidaes were a pet and when the popsicle stick was sometimes a piece of chewing gum. A time when we played UNO, ate kassler with pineapple and knew exactly what we were going to answer to the question "What about couples!?" but not on the question "Are you PK?".

Helballa 80-talet is an entertaining quiz with 318 questions about typical thing from the 80s.

name: BrainBox: Köln
description:
From the publisher:

The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible in ten minutes. The first player takes a card from the Brainbox and turns the timer over. The player then has ten seconds to study the picture on the card. When the timer runs out the card is passed to player two and player one rolls the die to see which question is to be asked. The questions are on the reverse of the picture card. Player Two checks the answer by looking at the picture and if it is correct the card is given back to Player One to keep. If the answer is wrong the card is placed back into the Brainbox and the next player chooses a card. Please remember, the answer to the question is on the picture side of the card, so look carefully! The player with the most cards after ten minutes wins! If there is a tie, it's sudden death with both players choosing a card and having to answer all eight questions on the card. The player who answers the most correctly wins! For 1 player Look at the card as above for ten seconds. Then turn the card over and answer all the questions (use a pen and paper to record the answers). If all questions are answered correctly the card is kept. If any answers are incorrect, the card has to be put back in the Brainbox. See how many cards you have after five or ten minutes.

name: Super Mario Advance Board Game
description:
Released in 2002 as toy number 2 out of 5, in the Wendy's Kids Meals. Nintendo teamed up with Wendy's to make items to celebrate release of Mario on Gameboy Advance and Mario Kart on Gamecube.

Features a double sided game board (made up four puzzle sections) you put together. One side is from Super Mario World and other Mario Kart.

Included are space cards to flip over and players move their character piece that many spaces. Each side the board features its own unique character pieces to choose from. Can choose from 6 different characters ranging from Mario, Luigi, Bowser and other popular Nintendo characters.

Game objective is simple; first to the finish line is the winner!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Travel, Video Game Theme

name: Alaska Oil Game
description:
"A Family Game Filled With Fun and Facts." Alaska Oil Game was published by Theme Games of Saratoga, California, with copyright in 1978 by M.A. Welsh.

Alaska Oil Game is a racing game in which 2-4 players compete to move all four of their oil barrels from the oil wells in Prudhoe Bay to their oil tankers in Port Valdez. Movement is based on drawing cards of two types: Oil Moving Cards and Pumping Station Cards. Oil Moving Cards are used to follow a longer, circuitous route, while the Pumping Station Cards use the Trans-Alaska Pipeline system that runs straight down the board for potential shortcuts. Oil Movement Cards can be drawn on any space of the board, while Pumping Station Cards may only be drawn on Pumping Station spaces.

The 52 Oil Movement Cards contain 35 movement cards with values ranging from +1 to +10, 11 themed Go Back cards with values from -2 to -9, 3 themed No Move cards, 1 Go Back to Start card and 1 Advance token to Port Valdez card.

There are 52 Pumping Station Cards, each displaying a pumping station numbered 1-12. Pumping Station 1 is in Prudhoe Bay while Pumping Station 12 is in Port Valdez. When drawn, the player's barrel moves to that pumping station, even if that sends the barrel in the wrong direction.

The first player to move all 4 barrels to their tanker is declared the winner.

name: DrunkQuest: Drink Coasters
description:
From the Kickstarter campaign:

These coasters will have printing on both sides. The back side will just feature the DrunkQuest logo. But the opposite side will feature a unique game rule. These rules will always benefit the player in possession of the coaster. The coasters should be given to the players at random at the beginning of the game. When a player finishes their drink during the game they can flip over their coaster to reveal its reward.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor, Party Game

name: Pasture 51: They Came for our Angus
description:
In this game, players are farmers making a living in infamous Pasture 51, where talk of extraterrestrial activity runs high, and cattle are often rumored to disappear. Farmers are full of it, and are always trying to top each others' stories of what they have seen; some of it credible, and some of it less so. You will attempt to weave the most credible UFO story!

Mechanically, Pasture 51 is a stock (get it?) holding game, where players will decide which cattle they wish to hold while also deciding which cattle are legitimately abducted (adding to the credibility of the stories), which cattle simply pass away in the fields, and which cattle are involved in abduction hoaxes (which hurts the credibility of the stories). There is one pasture card on the table for each of these outcomes, where cattle will graze before meeting their fate.

On a player's turn, he will draw two livestock tokens from a bag, with livestock coming in four varieties. He will choose one to keep in his personal stock, and one to put below a pasture card of his choice.

The backs of these tokens all contain special abilities as well. When a token is put out into pasture, it is flipped into the air. If it lands cattle-side up, too bad, no special ability. If it lands ability-side up, the player will get to perform an ability such as moving a cattle to an adjacent pasture, swapping a cattle from his personal stock with one in the pastures, or witnessing an abduction, which moves a cattle token from grazing in the pasture up onto the pasture card, where it is locked for the rest of the game. Abducting cattle while they are in the right pastures will be key to your success!

After a set number of turns, players will determine the value of each cattle variety. Cattle involved in hoaxes will decrease that variety's value, while those that were abducted by the real deal will add to it. Players then compare their personal holdings against the value of each cattle variety, with most points weaving the most credible tale!
categories: Animals, Farming, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Zippa Lipps
description:
This is a party game that combines Charades and Chinese whispers, with every player involved in every turn.

It contains a playing board, rule sheet, approximately 4,000 mimes, 6 playing pieces, 5 dice and an egg-timer.

On a player's turn, they role four of the dice to select a mime from the lists provided by putting the four numbers on the dice together. Each number on the list has a choice of three categories - nouns, verbs and media.

Once a mime is selected, they then select any other player to take out of the room and mime it to them (within a set time limit) using the normal rules of Charades. No speaking is allowed, so players have to hope their mime is good enough for the other person to get it.

After doing the mime, the first player comes in and selects the next player to go out. The person who received the mime the first time now has to mime it to the new player...and so on until all players have been outside. The last player then comes back in and announces what they think is the answer. Points are then scored and players move around the board until one reaches the finish line.

name: Monster Chef
description:
Who's able to complete the best monstrous recipes faster and get the most stars from customers? Who's completing his chef's goal to grab the bonus stars?

Monster Chef, a game for 2-4 players, lets you mess with opponents' recipes when your plans aren't taking the right path...
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Pattern Building

name: Uptake
description:
The game uses 24 cards from a standard card deck: one red suit and one black suit, minus aces and jokers.
These are shuffled and dealt face-up into a 5x5 grid, the central space being left open.

One player uses black, the other red. Turns are alternate. The goal is to capture an opponent's cards using one of yours of lower rank, until you have the highest ranked card remaining.

Captures are only valid if they take place in the same row or column as the card you want to use, the card-to-be-captured also must be of higher rank. For example, 2black can capture 5red, but 5red cannot capture 2black (or anything below a 6). A capture is performed by placing your card on your opponent's, and removing the captured card from the field.

When no legal moves are possible, the person with the highest ranked card remaining wins the round, and earns the point value of the card. Kings are 13 points, Queens 12, Jacks 11. For example, if 8black and 5red remain, black wins and gets 8 points. If the round ends in a tie, then the person who made the last move wins. The game continues until someone gets 30 points.

name: Hamback
description:
A solitaire Backgammon variant designed for backpackers that uses six counters, a standard six-sided die, and a board of seven lines. The board can be drawn on paper, and the counters can be coins, buttons, or whatever is handy.

The pieces start on the rightmost line.

Roll the die and move a counter forward exactly the number rolled. If you can't move, return one counter to start (or, for the "power" variant, lose the game).

The object is to move all the pieces to the leftmost line.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Circuit Gadget
description:
An Inspector Gadget Game

A Game of Fun and Skill

Object of the game is to move the car of Inspector Gadget,
Circle round to move the ball, without letting it fall, across the different obstacles. Obtain maximum points in the shortest possible time.

You drive the around the circular track using a blower to blow a Polystyrene ball through obstacles. The person who can drive the car around the course and blow the ball throw the obstacles in order and does it in the quickest time wins.

Requires 2 C Type 1.5 Volt Batteries
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Professor Pugnacious: Kickstarter Exclusive Promos
description:
This is an exclusive mini-expansion for backers of the 2013 Kickstarter campaign.

Consists of a pack of five cards, four titled "Master Engineer", and one event card called "Ghost in the Machine".
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Yaminabe
description: In this card game, players are trying to collect food items in order to cook a delicious pot of soup. Each food item card is printed with a positive or negative point value, based on how well it would go in the soup. Players are dealt a hand of cards, and then one player is designated as the Pot Master, a role that rotates each round. The Pot Master collects one card from each player, including himself, and then redistributes the cards face down. Players must decide whether to claim the face down card or trade it with another. The goal is to attain the highest point value after all cards have been claimed.

name: Legends of Rakasa
description:
Hunt monsters, take their parts, forge equipment, brew potions, and battle for glory! Play our story and then build your own!

Legends of Rakasa consists of two base games (Fordra and Monsir), two Legendary Expansions for each base game, and the Alchemy Expansion. each base game comes with enough components to play 1-4 players. Adding players is no problem with no real player cap. Each base game comes with two lands and two road, each land can increase player count by two. 8 to 16 player games is not unheard of with this game. Players can play competitively or cooperatively.

Players start in the village with very basic bone equipment they must venture out to the roads and lands to battle monsters, collect spoils, use those spoils to upgrade their equipment so they can take on more challenging monsters, and ultimately striving to achieve the game objective. Players may also use market utilities items and Potion materials to assist them in their battle.

Rakasa was designed to be a vary versatile game where players may choose to play set objectives and game setup rules or design there own. The game is made up and played on individual land and road tiles with decks of cards for each. This system allows players to adjust their games to fit their interests or preferences.

the base games are set in the Land of Rakasa during the Life Crossing festival. Each year the people of this land celebrate the renewal of life and battle to prove their skills as a hunter. This is done by crafting stronger equipment and defeating the dragons found in each of the lands. Once hunters have proved themselves they can participate in the Mahakasa hunt which is the strongest and most ferocious monster in Rakasa. Hunters who gain parts or trophies from this creature earn the title of Hunter-Warrior, the highest title bestowed to people in the village.
mechanics: Area Movement, Area-Impulse, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Team-Based Game

name: Beluga Cup
description:
You are a beluga whale competing in the annual "Belugas are Best" exotic fish eating competition. Your goal as a competitor is to eat the most fish of the different varieties. At the end of the competition points will be awarded to whoever can regurgitate the most fish of each type. Down with Narwhals!

Beluga Cup is a Decktet game inspired by Balloon Cup and game play is quite similar. Players are attempting to capture "fish" in each of 6 different colors (associated with Decktet suits). These cubes are placed into each of the 4 regions throughout the game and the player who has the highest sum of cards when a region is full will gain the chips. If you have bad cards do not fear! You may play them onto either side of a region thus undercutting your opponent's own play.

At the end of the game each different suit will be scored separately. The player who holds a majority in each will gain points equal to the number of cubes that their opponent has in that same suit. Thus the goal is to have the smallest majority possible in as many suits as possible in order to maximize the points gained.

name: Dragon Ball CCG
description:
The Dragon Ball Collectible Card Game (Dragon Ball CCG) is a collectible card game based on the Dragon Ball franchise, first published by Bandai in July 2008. This is not to be confused with the Dragon Ball Z Collectible Card Game that was released in the year 2000.

The goal of the game is to inflict 10 points of planet damage to the opposing player by use of your warriors. Upon doing so the game is won.

During the game you can assemble teams of characters from the shows Dragon Ball, Dragon Ball Z, and Dragon Ball GT; you can also collect the seven dragon balls to make use of a wish card.

Also, there is a mechanic in the game that allows you to channel chi -- certain cards will be unable to be played without channeling chi of a certain kind (ex; Alien, Earth, Super, et cetera)

name: Thirty
description:
EQUIPMENT: six tokens of the same color and an 18 card deck consisting of three each of aces, twos, threes, fours, fives and sixes. What suits you use does not matter. Aces have a value of one.

SET UP: shuffle the cards then lay them face up in a circle or square to form the track. Then one player decides to be Odd, the other Even. Both take three tokens. Odd places one token on the odd numbered cards of the same number, either all the aces, threes or fives. Even does the same, just on even numbered cards (twos, fours, or sixes).

MOVEMENT: The number value of a card determines how far a token is moved. Who moves which token doesn't matter, only that the Odd player moves an odd number of spaces, and Even an even number, both moving in a clockwise manner. Occupied cards in the path of your token are hopped over and not counted when moving, only one token can occupy a card at any time.

SCORING: at the end of your turn, count how many spaces you moved in total, including occupied cards you skipped over. An odd number scores points for Odd, an even number for Even, regardless of who moved the token. For example, if Odd moves a token on a 5 card, but is forced to hop over an occupied space in the way, this equals six spaces moved, so Even receives six points, though it was not his or her turn. The round ends when someone has gained 30 points, the winner receiving the difference between the winning and losing scores. For example, if Odd has 30 and Even 28, Odd gets 2 points for that round.

GOAL: to gain 30 points after a series of rounds. The loser of a previous round starts the next one. Tokens are not rearranged between rounds, and both players start the round with zero points.

name: Animali da Record
description:
Animali da Record is a card game with 6 different ways to play, for 1-6 players.

Each card shows one animal on the front side, and 4 attributes (length, height, weight and lifespan) on the rear. On the rear there is also a short description.

There are also 8 category cards, 2 for each attribute: for example, they are "the heaviest", "the lighest", "the highest", "the smallest".
During each round, players draw a category card and, without reading the attributes on the rear, try to find/play the best animal according to that category or place it in the correct order between 2 cards.

Whoever plays the best animal wins the cards. Who collects the most number of cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Warp Lane
description:
Conquer the galaxy in an evening! Defeat your friends! Make alliances, only to back-stab your allies when the time is right!

Warp Lane is a fast paced science fiction strategy game for two to six players, employing a simple rule system and no record keeping. It features a simple ship to ship combat system and five ship classes for balanced deep space fleets. Players build their ships, engage in commerce, and confront their enemies with one goal in mind: total domination of the galaxy.

The game board consists of a representation of the galaxy on a hex grid. Every dot on the board is a star system, with the stars grouped in a spiral having six arms. Some of the star systems are connected by warp lanes. The warp lanes have the effect of bridging distant star systems and speeding travel across the galaxy. On the edges of the galaxy are the home systems, which are the bases from which the players start their conquest.

Players will develop and defend commercial empires, and force concessions from enemies by deploying powerful warships and fleets. The game progresses until one player dominates the galaxy!

Now free! Print and Play... download from http://jeffsiebrecht.com

name: Four Fronts
description:
Four Fronts is a Chess variant for 2, 3, or four players, individually or in pairs. Each player has 12 pieces: 6 pawns, 1 each of the king, queen, knight, rook, and bishop, and a "prince" piece that is a hybrid of a bishop and a rook. The board is an ordinary 8x8 black and white chessboard, but extended along each of four sides for the player's starting fields. Along each 8-square side of the board is another six squares, then another four squares, then two, all of them centered. The overall shape of the board then can be seen as a square with jagged edges, and with its four corners highlighted in colors to match the players' pieces. The colored squares are the starting positions for each player.

The game's rules of movement, capture, and winning conditions appear to be otherwise the same as in Chess.

name: Kwando
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Sort six famous personalities according to their date of birth. Is that all? Sounds easy, right — but not so fast! No dates are on the cards, and they're distributed among several
different teammates. Most importantly, you're not allowed to say the name or any dates.

Which team in Kwando will be able to correctly sort the personalities in the right order the quickest by communicating the right information?

name: NHL Challenge
description:
Here is your chance to play for the most coveted trophy in team sports: The Stanley Cup®. This quick, simple, exciting game pits you and a fellow coach head-to-head in a best of seven series. Or, you and your friends can play an entire National Hockey League playoff, starting with up to sixteen teams until it's down to the final two. Pick your starting line-up, skillfully play your Stanley Cup® cards and then roll the dice. The winner can proudly display Lord Stanley's symbol of hockey supremacy. That is, until the time you face the NHL® Stanley Cup® Challenge!

This is also an expansion pack for the award-winning NHL® Big League Manager board game.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Clash Fighter: The Real Time Fighting Card Game
description:
Clash Fighter translates fighting game mechanics into a fast-paced card game where two players compete to build combos in real time! The Standard Edition features six playable character card decks, so two, four, or six players can face off in separate two player matches -- each person controlling a separate character.

The first person to play a Clash card ends real time play, initiating a short turn based phase where damage is calculated. The goal is to deplete your opponent's lifebar while defending your own with strategic combos.

The 12-player Tournament Edition is here: Clash Fighter: The Real Time Fighting Card Game (Tournament Edition)

name: Blockade
description:
Blockade is played on a grid of sixty-four hexagons (in three alternating colors or shades) arranged in a four-sided diamond (rhombus) shape, with eight hexes on each side. Two players, black and white, have pieces in three types: four captains, three commodores, and one admiral. To start the game, the board is positioned with the extreme corners of the board closest to each player. The admiral piece begins on the hex closest to each player. The next two hexes closer to the middle of the board remain empty. On the following three closer hexes are stationed the three commodores, and on the next four hexes the captains.

Pieces are not captured at any point in the game. Admirals may be moved one space at a time to any adjacent hexagon. Commodores are color-bound and may move two spaces to a hex of the same color. The intermediate space need not be unoccupied, only the hex on which the commodore will land. Captains are moved any number of spaces in a straight line from the joining sides of their hex, but may not pass over another piece. To win the game, an opponent’s admiral must be blockaded from being able to move in any direction. Movement may be prevented by either player’s pieces, and once an admiral is blockaded, none of that player’s other pieces are allowed to move.

name: Root the Loot
description:
Midnight: Three faithful ferrets keep watch over the scouts' supply tents but, deep beneath them, "Operation Scout About" is underway.

Root the Loot is a game for two players. One commands three moles on a midnight raid who must pick up as much loot as possible and return it to the safety of HQ. The other controls three ferrets who are guarding the loot and must capture the moles as quickly as possible.

Moles move two junctions at a time through the tunnel network, trying to run rings around the ferrets who can only move one - strategy and tactics for where to move is key to the game. A little memory is involved to remember which mole(s) hold the most loot; this is otherwise a 'perfect information' game with no luck or hidden parts.
mechanics: Memory, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement

name: Bürgermeisterspiel: Werde Bürgermeister in Einbeck
description:
Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Einbeck
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Einbeck. Corrects answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.
categories: Dice, Economic, Educational, Negotiation, Political, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading, Voting

name: Pictionary: U.S. Armed Forces Edition
description:
The classic game of quick draw... with a U.S. Armed Forces Twist!

Whether you're a soldier, sailor, aviator, marine or coastie, this game is sure to be a hit with family and friends!

There are lots of fun new words to draw. Many are military specific, but others relate to everyday life in the Armed Forces. You'll be surprised at the things you can draw.

PICK A CARD - DRAW A WORD - make your teammates GUESS IT in less than a minute. Be the first team to get through basic training and WIN THE GAME!
mechanics: Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Queen's Blade: The Live
description: クイーンズブレイド (Queen's Blade) - THE LIVE is a series of gamebooks, licensed from and fully compatible with Series: Lost Worlds (Nova Game Designs), set in the Setting: Queen's Blade Universe. A distinctive feature of this series is their use of live models to portray the characters in the various battle situations. Furthermore, LIVE characters may differ from their original counterparts (e.g. THE LIVE Airi is no longer undead).

name: A Call to Arms: Rules Supplement 2
description:
The A Call to Arms Rules Supplement series brings you an array of new rules, information, articles and ships. It is an invaluable resource for any A Call to Arms player and will change the way you play your games!

Within Supplement 2 you will find wide variety of new articles designed to expand and develop the way you play A Call to Arms. Whether it is new rules for incorporating fleet carriers and beacon locks, stats for the Narn Gorith fighter, rules for using Captain John Sheridan in your games, or an in-depth study of the Earth Alliance Nova dreadnought, you will find something to get your teeth into. With a special scenario depicting Babylon 5 seceding from Earth, Supplement 2 is packed with great additions for A Call to Arms!

name: On Guard
description:
On Guard is played on a 7x7 square grid of raised circles on which the circular, stackable playing pieces rest. Two players each of have 24 pieces of either yellow or orange, and begin the game by taking turns placing their single pieces (Guards) anywhere on the board but for the center circle. Each player on his first turn must create an Officer by moving one of his Guards onto another.

Guards may move horizontally or vertically to the next adjacent vacant space, and may not jump or capture. Officers may move any number of (unobstructed) spaces horizontally or vertically, even making 90 degree turns, and may jump and eliminate other Officers, but not Guards. Only one Office can be made per turn.

To win the game, capture all the opponent's Officers, or block him from moving any remaining pieces.

name: Monopoly: Nissan
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Nissan, a car company
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Auf zum Mäusefest
description:
You have to be the first to get your family of mice to the big mice party.

This is basically 'Pachisi' meets 'Snakes and Ladders'. You move your mice by rolling the die. Ladders get you up, cats (not snakes!) get you down. When you land on an occupied spot you move the mouse down. First one to get his whole family in wins.

name: Policeman
description: Policeman gives two to four players a chance to chase four suspects around a board representing a city, arresting them in hopes of catching the one real robber. Moves for both the police and the suspects are determined by drawing cards and following their instructions, which involve paths and marked locations on the board's city.

name: Pasur
description:
Pasur is one of the most popular card games in Iran. It is a fishing card game in which numeral cards are captured by making a total of 11. Points are scored for Aces, Jacks, the 2 of Clubs, the 10 of Diamonds, having the majority of Clubs, and for clearing the table. The object is to be the first player or team to reach a predetermined number of points.

Pasur is similar to the Italian game of Casino and the Egyptian game of Bastra.

name: Madagascar (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride)
description:
This Madagascar map should offer similar play to the US editions. It is intended for 2 to 4 players.


NOTE: "Ticket to Ride" and "Days of Wonder" are registered trademarks of Days of Wonder, Inc. This fan-created expansion map is not a Days of Wonder product, but has been created with permission of Days of Wonder, Inc, solely for unpaid, non-commercial use. Some of the text and illustrations used herein may be Copyright © 2004-2014, Days of Wonder, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

name: Bedtime Heroes
description:
Bedtime Heroes is a card and dice game where players try to protect sleeping children from nightmarish monsters with the aid of animated toys.

During a turn players may try to add to their toy collection by purchasing one through silent auction, or they may battle monsters in a bid to earn points.

The game ends when all monsters are defeated - points are earned by defeating monsters, having a big toy collection, and making sure your child is still fast asleep!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Points, Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck

name: Mathological Liar: Grade 2
description: Can you detect which suspects are the mathological liars? This card game is based on fun mini math mysteries. Each round of card play is a new case. Players are each dealt a suspect card. There are 4 suspects per case, one or more who may be guilty. One player reads aloud the case summary. Then, all players silently read their suspect’s alibi. If the math in their suspect’s alibi is correct, then he is innocent. Incorrect math indicates guilt. Players decide if their suspect is innocent or guilty and later take turns vocalizing their verdict and mathematical reasoning. Points are awarded based on correct determination of a suspect’s innocence or guilt and also for describing why the guilty party’s alibi did not jive (i.e., why the math was incorrect). The winner is the player with the most points after a pre-determined number of rounds or time limit set at the beginning of game play. You’ll need to draw on a variety of math skills to solve these whodunit mysteries as each game includes 50 different cases.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Educational, Math, Murder/Mystery

name: Arpaa Turup
description:
Arpaa Turup is a four-player plain trick taking card game from Somalia, played in partnerships, whose name means "Four [packs of] Cards". No doubt it is so called because it is played with a 144-card pack made up four identical 36-card packs.

Cards in this game are dealt in batch of three. After the player sitting on the dealer's left gets the first three cards, the dealing is stopped and this player, having looked at his cards, calls the trump suit.

As usual the highest trump, or if none are played the highest card of the suit led wins the trick. The winner of each trick leads to the next.

Winning the game and the match
At the end of the game each partnership counts the tricks they have taken. The game is won by the party which takes more tricks. To win the match, a partnership must win two games, without losing any games in between them, the number of tricks taken in the second game they win being more than in the first game they win.

name: Crimson Sun
description:
In Crimson Sun, players take on the role of leaders of Upper and Lower Egypt. Playing units of four unique gods (Kuk, Babi, Horus, and Sekmet), players build their forces and attempt to assert influence over four key structures. Players may choose to either draft decks at the beginning of the game, or use a single deck.

During the game, players use the Unit cards in a variety of ways to increase his overall strength, to use special abilities, or to secretly try to gain control over the structures. The core mechanisms of this game are pulled from a previous Small Box Games' release — Bhazum — but mechanical and thematic changes have led to a game that should be a fresh experience for players already familiar with that game.

name: The Wilderness Ablaze: A Solitaire Game of the French and Indian War
description:
The Wilderness Ablaze is a semi-historical simulation of the French and Indian War in the American Colonies during the Mid-1700s. Players assume the role of the Commander of Forces in the American Colonies in the turbulent times where both France and Britain are seeking to increase their nation's territory and power. Can you defeat the French by capturing Montreal and preventing them from capturing British settlements?

OBJECTIVE: As the Commander of British Forces in the American Colonies, you must protect the British Settlements and attempt to capture the Key French Settlements of Quebec, Montreal and Toronto before the Campaign Deck runs out.

GAME FEATURES: The game features a fun and simplistic method for resolving solitaire combat tactically, rules for Heroes that can make an impact on the outcome of battles, and lots of colorful game counters. If you enjoy movies like "Last of the Mohicans", "Pathfinder" or "The Northwest Passage", you will enjoy this game.
categories: Age of Reason, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Autorennen
description:
The objective of this car race is to be the first player to reach the finish line crossing 100 "steps". The movement of the cars is determined by a number die. On certain spaces on the track a color die is used to decide, if the result of the number die can be used or if the player has to skip the turn.

Published in 1920's-1930's.

name: L'Aquila e il Leone
description: L'Aquila e il Leone - La Battaglia di Vicenza - 7 ottobre 1513 is a wargame for two players that aims to recreate the battle that took place in the areas close to the city of Vicenza between the armies of the League of Cambrai and the Most Serene Republic of Venice. The players pull chits indicating which section of the battle field is activated, with a mechanism somewhat reminiscent of the Series: Commands & Colors system. The units are moved on a game map divided into squares and depicting the battle field, and combat is resolved through the roll of 2 six sided dice. A secondary map provides the Venetian armies with an alternative path through the marshes, allowing them to outflank the opponents. The winner is the player that controls two of the three sections of the battle field.
mechanics: Action Queue, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: 9-all
description: 9-all is played with a pair of dice, thirty-six chips, and a board with a section of nine numbered squares for each player. Players take turns rolling the dice and placing their chips according to the outcome. The largest number rolled is what counts, and the squares a player can cover must add up to that number, otherwise they must pass. The first player to cover all nine squares scores a "9-all" and wins the game. If all players fail to cover their squares, the player with the fewest uncovered wins.

name: Klymo
description:
Klymo is played by two to four players, each with his own identical small board and six pieces. The boards are comprised of a 6x6 grid of squares in three alternating colors, with a row of six squares on opposite ends marked. The board is positioned so that one row, the starting row, is closest to each player.

Players take turns rolling a six-sided die with three colors on it to determine placement and possible movement of their pieces on the board. Placements are limited to marked squares in the starting row, of the same color rolled on the die. Movements are limited to adjacent squares of the color that is rolled on the die, and only in a forward direction. The first player to move all of his pieces to the marked squares on the opposite side of his board wins.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Spar
description:
Introduction

Spar is a popular game from Ghana. It is a trick-taking game without trumps, in which the object is to win the last trick.

Spar is usually played by 2, 3 or 4 players, but it is possible for up to 7 to play. The game uses 35 cards from a standard international 52-card pack, the cards of each suit ranking from high to low: A, K, Q, J, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, but the Ace of Spades is normally not used, so the highest card in that suit is the King.

Play

Whoever played the highest card of the suit that the first player led is the winner of the trick. The cards played are not gathered in but remain in a face up pile. The winner of the trick leads any card from hand to begin the next trick, playing it face up on top of the pile, and once again the other players must each play a card: this must be the same suit as the card that was led if possible, otherwise any card.

This continues until five tricks have been played.

Scoring

Whoever wins the fifth and last trick wins the hand and scores:

3 points if the winning card is a 6;
2 points if the winning card is a 7;
1 point for winning with any other card - 8 or higher.

The winner of the hand deals the next hand, and therefore plays last to the first trick of the next hand. The session continues for as long as the players wish - there is no fixed number of deals or target score that ends the session.

Variations
